description:
This place is a hidden gem, made even more attractive by the fact that one gets there (if coming from BART, at least) by walking past all the tourist-sucking North Beach standards. At first glance at the menu, I was even questioning if it was really Italian (never seen sauerkraut on an  Italian menu!). My new/old lady friend chose it as she wanted somewhere quiet to talk. It was so quiet we could hear neighbour's hushed conversations; and they, ours! In fact we ended up chatting to a nice pair of elderly women who were having a convivial night out.
The history of the place is on the back of the menu so that's where one learns that this place has its roots on the Croatian peninsula, in land that is no longer Italian.
The menu reflects that, but does still have Italian flavours: gnocchi, for example, served in a cumin-laced sirlin sauce that was worth scraping off the plate with the crispy bread! I shared my friend's appetizer and she, mine: i had the cold sardines. Could have used a little more flavour but she enjoyed having mad the better choice.
Having overcome my scepticism about sauerkraut in Italian food, I went for the pork loin stuffed with it; very tasty with perfect consistency and a ggod blend of flavours. I also got a taste of the strudel (pasta, not pastry) as we shared dishes. Also highly recommended. Digging into a long lost past, i chose a glass of very  pleasant chianti and that reminds me of the only flaw I can find: the head waiter's English was a ltle tough to understand. And, if he didn't understand us, he just walked off!
Somehow (perhaps at the urging of our new neighbours - from whom we learned there is no corkage fee, as  they left us some of their wine!) we found room to share the tiramisu; light and whelming with various, distinct tastes. I think this place might have been on the Chronicle's top  100 one; like the Cavalier, it deserves to be reinstated.
author: Michael A.

description:
The food was mediocre, I expected way more based on the reviews. the restaurant was fairly empty all evening - Sat night. My friend and I split the salmon, it was cooked fine but boring with a few steamed veggies on the plate. We had the 3 cheese ravioli with brown butter sauce - the ravioli were ok, butter sauce was good but there was a LOT of rough chopped fresh sage all over the pasta which was very bitter and inedible. I told the waiter and he graciously took it off the bill. Strudel was dreadful. The filling was over sweet with too much cinnamon and the dough was heavy - I couldn't eat it (rare for me).

Seemed like either an uninspired or inexperienced chef was at the helm tonight. 

Quite disappointed.
author: Deborah N.

description: This has been one of our favorites for 25 years.  Several owners but same quality and service.  No Gluten Free pasta but plenty of items that are gluten free. The menu says the food is Croatian but close to Italian. definitely a hidden gem. Great value. Good portion size and great food.  Service is very good.  Nice quiet place to visit with friends.
author: Marianne K.

description:
Given the number of reviews and the high Yelp rating, I expected Albona to be more crowded on a Saturday night. I had called about an hour in advance and we were able to get a table at 8:30pm. When Uber dropped us off in a very residential neighborhood, I wasn't sure if we were in the right place. It took a moment to spot the restaurant. By the time we got to the restaurant, all of the other tables were finishing up. We were one of the last groups of the day.

There was only one server and he was busy calculating other people's checks, making coffee, and delivering dishes. It took a few minutes for us to get seated and quite a bit longer before he came to get our order. In the meantime, we read all about the history of the restaurant and Istria.

We ordered the braised veal shank and mushroom risotto. The veal looked beautiful and it was fall-off-the-bone tender. For some reason, it wasn't as tasty (flavorful) as I had imagined it would be. The risotto about 50% mushrooms, which was way more than I had expected. If you're a big mushroom fan, I'd recommend this dish.

I like the old-school setting and the homey feeling. But really, it was a  3.5* experience.
author: Yi Z.

description: One the very best restaurants in Sam Francisco   Nothing fancy and with an exterior front that blends into the houses around it.  If your focus is the food in a pleasant atmosphere this place is what you are looking for.  Everyone at my table had soup or salad and a main course. Every single plate was outstanding.  Even my teenager wants to go back
author: Ernie M.

description:
Super cute little restaurant tucked into a north beach side street. We made a reservation for Friday night @730. This was prime dinner time so I'd suggest a res (they are available on OpenTable) . Our server was so nice - great service ! 

They bring out water & bread to start & be careful, the bread is warm & fresh we wanted to eat both loaves but paced ourselves. Keep some for
Dipping! I wasn't familiar with their wine list so he asked me what I liked. I wanted a dry white and he said he had something not on the menu for me to try. I can't remember the name but he was spot on.

There were 2 of us and we chose 3 dishes,
They brought them out in 3 courses for us & timed it perfectly. They also split everything into 2 plates which was a nice touch. 
- grandmas potato gnocchi was different than it's typically served. It's crispy on the outside and served in a sirloin gravy. You get 8 to an order and they're a pretty good siZe - nice for sharing. 
- shrimp & mussels risotto & I think there were some scallops in there . Perfectly cooked risotto ! They didn't skimp on the seafood. 
- pasta strudel . This was our favorite - it's cheesy w prosciutto, Topped with breadcrumbs and baked. It's rich so I was glad we shared but I definitely wanted more 

Next time we go I wanna try the tiramisu - we were just so full
author: danielle a.

description: Such a great find for our first night in San Francisco. The service was great with it only being one wonderful server and a chef that would check up on tables. Albona is a cozy restaurant the decor is a bit dated, but we were only there for the food and it was delicious!
author: Kaitlyn M.

description: This place is tucked away on Francisco St still in North beach but away from the mob scene. The food is Italian but regional to the Veneto and Istrian peninsula so the dishes are different from the usual fare. Still the menu is diverse enough for most people to find something they like. We started with stuffed calamari (calamai in dialect) caponata and chilled sardines. Next a wonderful ample main course of rolled stuffed pork loin. My wife had the stinco which was super tender.
author: Chris T.

description: This was a hidden gem during our escape to SF. Close to our hotel and amazing! Best mushroom risotto, pasta strudel and Veal shank. Not to mention the vanilla bean pans Cotta with raspberry redupot reduction. My husband and I will rave about this experience for years to come. Salute!
author: Sarah Y.

description: An amazing find! The menu is based on the cuisine of the Istrian Peninsula in Croatia. Very intimate and sweet restaurant. Quiet and relaxing. The owner, Sam, and his wife and the waiter were attentive, pleasant and accomodating. We had delicious meals. If you like beets then a must is a beet tartare called Barbabietola Mixia Con Kren E Prezemolo. We are definitely going back. Make sure you have reservations!!
author: Jan R.

description: Service was a bit slow but the food was good. The restaurant is a residential neighborhood and is a bit out of the way.
author: Isaac R.

description: This place is amazing !!!! Staff was very nice and the food was delicious. Will return for more on a regular basis, just down the street from me and so pleased to have found this place!
author: Ja'mie H.

description: Old clientele and not so nice staff. Food was average at best. Pricey as well. Not worth the walk to find it or the price for below average food.
author: Olivia P.

description:
2 steps on the right from our friend's house. We were here 1st time. Very friendly server (might be busy for just one guy to serve more than 2 tables in the same time).
I had porchini mushroom risotto. Rice was perfectly cooked. Recommend
author: Svetlana K.

description:
While visiting the area, this was truly one of my favorites. Being part Italian, and growing up in an area where there was no shortage of outstanding Italian restaurants, this was very comparable to the quality of food I've grown up with. 

When you walk in here, you may get the feeling you are going to be taken care of- 'CAUSE YA WILL. It's funny, our party of five at roughly 4:30p was greeted with an "Oh I'm sorry I don't think we can seat you tonight." We looked around... then to each other... and each of us gave the look like "Are ya serious guy? There's no one in here!". After walking into the back and checking his reservations, he assured us that he could get us seated with a short wait as a table had cancelled. After only 5mins we were seated. He was very apologetic. This was a running joke at the table for the next hour or so, but by the time we left, that joke was on us- THIS PLACE WAS SLAMMED! GET THE RESERVATION!

Once seated, Sam took care of us completely. Great guy. Always attentive and polite. We wanted an order of the stuffed squid as an appetizer but noticed an odd quantity for our party, he said don't worry, I'll take care of it. Sure enough, they brought out just the right amounts.

The food quality was great. My notable dishes were the Taierini con gamberetti e vongole and the Strudel con pasta fatta in casa. Much like most places around the bay area, of course you can't go wrong with any of the seafood options here. The pasta was cooked to a perfect al dente, sauces were very tasty.

The atmosphere here was another great attribute. Very small and quaint. It really felt like you were dining in your own private nook in Italy. 

Service, as mentioned, was impeccable. Thanks again to Sam and staff for a great time!
author: Ryan G.

description:
What a romantic and classic Italian restaurant to be wining and dining in!  It's dimly lit, quiet and quaint.  No need to beat the crowd to be dining here.  That was nice. 

I came here punctual to make a point that I'm not always late for dates and ordered the wine per the waiter's recommendation. (A women has to prepare and gather herself to freshen up and fabulous, in my opinion, to feel good about herself so that way she can exude that same feeling around her!). The wine was pleasant while waiting for my date. 

The Italian food here is fresh and sauce for each dish is rich.

Panna Cotta for dessert was something sweet for the palate. 

It's a humble restaurant.  Let's keep it that way.
author: Tiffany D.

description:
This little quaint place was so charming and you'd miss it if you walked past it!! 
I liked that the server asked if we wanted tap water - honestly in high-ish end places, the usually only offer flat or sparkling so I appreciated it. 
We started with the mushroom soup and mussels. The soup was good but the mussels were DELICIOUS. 
For mains, we had spaghetti and meatballs and the seafood linguine. The pasta as expected was cooked perfectly and the meatballs were perfect - moist and flavourful. 
The seafood linguine.... ohmygosh. Buttery wine sauce and crisp large shrimp. The clams were salty and complimented the rest well. 
The service was lovely. The atmosphere was really interesting with business dinners, couples and families. 
I'd highly recommend this gem.
author: Jacklyn L.

description:
Incredibly cute entrance and loved the ambiance. This place felt authentic and the waiter was genuinely caring.

The stuffed peppers appetizer was yummy. So was the rest of the meal - I got the rabbit and tried some veal shank. The portions were very generous, though perhaps reflected in the prices. 

My rabbit was great, but slightly dry in some places and less flavorful in the middle. Of course, it was drowning in sauce, so all I had to do was dip it. TBH the sauce was delicious but there was too much. 

The veal shank had a more subtle flavor. Not as soft and juicy as I've had elsewhere though. Dessert - tiramisu and dark chocolate flan - was the best!

I would come back if I was in the area and wanted to splurge on a full Italian meal. With all the other options I have in the city though, it doesn't top my list.
author: Ke D.

description:
Our waiter was okay. We wanted to pace our ordering (get a drink started, look at appetizers, then order a bottle of wine for the table and entrees) - he wasn't super attentive to keep the next drink or food coming (we never got that bottle of wine for the table). And it ended up being a 3 hour dinner in a place we'd expect 2 hours. 
That said, the food was delicious. The soup special was worth trying and the salads exactly how you'd expect. I ordered the pasta: Strudel con pasta fatta in case - kind of like lasagna rolls, very savory with the prosciutto it was almost too salty (almost).
author: Susan H.

description:
5 stars turned into one star unfortunate everything was going well to the end.

I found this place looking on yelp.  It had great reviews and it was close to our hotel.  We made a reservation online which was easy.   Since sitting it took 1hr and 15 minutes prior to receiving our meal.  I ordered the stuffed Lasagna, my wife the spaghetti and friend the filet mignon.  Slightly annoyed that the restaurant was understaffed and I could tell by the waiters attitude.  He seemed flustered and genuinely fake.  This was noted when a couple did not leave a tip and he slightly pouted when they left and ran outside to look at them.  After multiple water refills and a complimentary mushroom soup.  We received our food.  Food was great, but should have been since the food was $10 more than what yelp lists.  

Finally at the end I asked the waiter kindly if he could split our check.  Mind you we only have three people and he only needed to remove my friends steak from our check." And the one of the last two tables in the restaurant (everyone had left). He irritatingly said "you should have asked me before hand!??" Pouted and walked away.  At that point I was mad and about to lash back.  But I kept it in.  It didn't help when he was giving us the angry look while looking at his POS machine.  He finally came back, I cooled off and I said thank you.  All he did was grimace.  

I'm thoroughly disappointed by this experience.  It's unfortunate that the waiter could destroy the reputation of this restaurant because of his attitude.  I understand in some restaurants you may need to "suck up" to some waiters.  But this was just brutal.  I'll possibly change my review, pending a response from the owner.
author: Ian G.

description: Wonderful combination of food, ambiance, and service. Every dish our party of 7 had was delicious, but our favorite was the rabbit. Our servers went above and beyond to make sure we had everything we needed. The atmosphere was friendly, refined, and quiet enough to hear each other. Easy to see why this restaurant has been open for so long and has such good reviews.
author: Greg C.

description: Samuel and his team are extraordinary. Must try! I love it. They are amazing!!!!! From food to service:
author: Alexandra M.

description: THE most wonderful Italian food! The server, Monica was wonderful. She was so busy and did a great job. We did not have reservations and had walked 20 blocks to eat. The owner let us stay and we were to grateful. Albona- your tiramisu was heaven!!!
author: Sarah M.

description: Decent food. Service marginal. If service was great would be 4 star. Seemed as though there was only 1 waiter for the dining room. Didn't open the wine at the table.
author: Bill C.

description:
The food and service here was pretty amazing.  I would highly recommend the seafood soup.  The meal started with bread, a salad, a great wine and then the seafood soup.  The restaurant is small and quite and tucked away off the main drag.  This could make a good date spot or a quite business dinner with a very small group.  The food is "Istrian", from a region on the Italian, Slovenia, and Croatian boarders which gives the food some unique differences from the typical Italian fare.  I would certainly dine here again.  The experience was unique, delicious and the seafood was fresh.  This restaurant is also walking distance from the Fisherman's wharf and trolley stops which allows for an easy commute from the louder and more crowded spots on the tourist strip.

Note: Although it wasn't too crowded at the time we went, I would suggest making a reservation or calling ahead on a popular Friday or Saturday night.
author: Moe F.

description: Overall we were disappointed with Albona considering the yelp reviews. The ambiance & service were great. It's a small, cozy restaurant away from the tourist traps of North Beach. I recommended this place for a couple on a romantic date not a large party like ours. This could have been the issue with some of our dishes. The highlights were the salad, calamari, mussels, mushroom risotto, duck in red reduction sauce & filet mignon. The rabbit was served with a delicious rosemary polenta that we enjoyed. The steak was definitely the best dish of the night. However, there were also some dishes that were big misses too. The tomato soup was bland, the seafood risotto was tasteless & the seafood pasta was a huge disappointment. The pasta lacked taste & any type of sauce. We all shared many desserts and once again there were hits & misses. The Tarimsu was very good. Light & not to much rum flavor. However, the Pena Cota  tasted like Greek yogurt & the apple tart was nothing special.
author: Kevin B.

description: This is one of my favorites restaurants,  customer service is first class, they explain the menu and sugest at your request, grate vine and amazing food. No complains. I love this place, intimate and familiar
author: Maribel G.

description: Nice neighborhood place. Found on yelp reviews accurate. Just what we were looking for. Mushroom risotto was just right and the pasta strudel was great.  Started with the stuffed calamari which was unexpectedly spicy but thats ok for my taste. Used the warm bread to get all the sauce.
author: Frank F.

description: A rare night out with my adult son began with an early meal at Albona. A wonderful meal and thoughtful birthday touches made my night even more special.  The first diners to arrive, we were a bit unsure of our choice, but not for long. Our Host could not have been more gracious,  making us feel welcome immediately and bringing us each a glass of champagne to start the celebration while we perused the menu. So many delicious choices! Although the menu is an omnivore's delight, I'm pescetarian, and ordered a delicious homemade ravioli filled with three cheeses, pine nuts, golden raisins, and freshly ground nutmeg. There were 2 choices for sauce, and I can't pass up browned butter and sage - so rich, but so yummy! My son had a perfectly cooked beef filet, and even *gasp!* ate most of the veggies served with it. We couldn't linger, as we had a show to catch, but our kind host quickly brought another surprise birthday treat to end our meal - and didn't delay us. Such gracious, thoughtful service seems to be disappearing in many places, but I suspect it will live on here for some time. If we lived closer, I suspect we would become regular visitors, still, I'm sure we'll be back! (Parking - there is street parking in this largely residential neighborhood, but I used Parking Panda which found us a secure spot in a nearby hotel.)
author: Julie D.

description: This place. So delicious. We had the gnocchi for the appetizer. It was 5 star fantastic.  I enjoyed the rissoto fungi.  I was impressed the the staff. Very warm and accommodating.
author: Laura K.

description: You won't be disappointed.  Service is great food is fantastic.  Been twice.  This is my "happy place"!  Must have...  Gnocchi.  Lamb is great and so is the veal beef shank.
author: Chris D.

description:
Hands down one of the most enjoyable and romantic restaurants there, let me tell you why this deserves a 5 star rating ,

First of all , I came here asking for a lovely dinner with my wife on our last day of our honeymoon , and it was absolutely lovely , the table was prepared romantically with petals and roses on the table , and a small bouquet on the table which is very lovely.

Second of all , I really appreciated how chef Sam was accommodating to our requirements in which we don't eat pork/ham and alcohol. 

Third of all , all what we ordered were an absolute delicious. I ordered the mushroom soup which was absolutely lovely. We ordered the gnocchi for appetizer another recommended dish. On top of that he customized a pasta for us in order to fit our needs we ordered alfredo longuini with mushroom. And we had the mushroom risotto both were one of the best we had!!!

Last of all , Chef Sam added a costumized trimasu for us as a complimentary dessert , which both me and my wife truly enjoyed. The service was great. 

I'd like to thank Albona restaraunt for the wonderful experience and I'll definitely recommend it to everyone
author: Abdulla A.

description: This is a wonderful, intimate, and welcoming place perfect for a romantic night or dinner with friends. The cuisine is very similar to Italian, Venetian style, but with a twist, and expertly prepared. When we were there the service was very attentive and capable, and the place wasn't busy. This is one of the quietest restaurants in the City, and a great night out!
author: Paul K.

description: We had the rack of lamb and the pan seared salmon, both of which were delicious! Here's a shoutout to Sam who warmly greeted us and took excellent care of us! Looking forward to our next visit to Albona!
author: Lou S.

description: Absolutely some of the greatest tasting food. It was an enjoyment with every bite. I would recommend this place to any person traveling to the area. The owner/chef was so hospitable. He made us feel like we were part of the family.
author: Aaron K.

description: So delicious ! Sam accommodated us in a flash ! True italian atmosphere if you know what i mean ! You'll love it ! Thanks Samuel for the hospitality!
author: Kevin B.

description: Tasty dishes, attentive & knowledgeable service, cozy but elegant atmosphere. Plus the prices are extremely reasonable given the quality of this cuisine. From appetizer to dessert, every aspect of our experience was exquisite!
author: JJ W.

description: This restaurant was awesome. Intimate and personal service. Nice selection of menu items that made it hard to decide what to order. Everything looked good and the actual food did not disappoint. We were happy not to have passed on dessert, which was also quite delicious.
author: Andrew S.

description:
Food in reverse chronological order: generous portions. Rabbit was sweet and flavorful, with onions polenta and carrots. Veal was tender but not as seasoned as the hoppy animal. Appetizer calamari was perfectly cooked and soft. Bread was so so. Butter soft but nothing special.

Service started off extremely slow! We waited 16 minutes between entering and the server taking our drink order. Also he seemed to have trouble understanding us even though it was not too loud... but he picked up the slack and everything came out quickly after that. Was flexible when we didn't like the first Chardonnay we ordered. He boxed up our leftover food.

More mature clientele. Talkative but not boisterous. Pleasant music played softly in background. Nice atmosphere for date or taking family for special occasion.
author: Erik R.

description:
This was a very intimate Italian restaurant with a bit of history and context mixed in with the menu. I loved reading about the history of this Northern Italian place. We had made reservations for 5:30 and arrived to a restaurant with no other diners, but the waiter came out immediately and promptly took our orders. As we dined, the place started to fill up and it seems many people love the homey feel of this place. We ordered an appetizer, a salad, two entrees, and a dessert and were very full at the end. The flavors were a bit more "earthy" than I am used to from Italian restaurants and I loved it.

The service was very attentive and our water glasses never empty. They even went through the trouble of picking out raisins from the strudel for us haha! Overall a really pleasant experience, and kind of unique compared to many other Italian restaurants.
author: Maureen C.

description:
Fantastic delicious food in a traditional Italian North Beach setting.  No other restaurant serves this regional Italian cuisine.
Authentic unique and well prepared food.
Generous portions.
author: I R.

description:
Went here last night as my family took me out for a belated birthday dinner. What a great local place out of the way and totally old school Italian. Started off sharing some apps, 
squid stuffed with toasted bread crumbs, parsley, and garlic; roasted in marinara sauce, Beet tartare mixed with a touch of horseradish and mustard and pan-fried potato gnocchi in
a brown sirloin sauce laced with cumin. All the apps were prepared perfectly and brought hot to the table. The bread in the basket is so delicious and crunchy that we had to have a second basket, we were warned not to eat too much bread because the food is so rich and plentiful, but we did anyway. Entrees were great braised veal shank in a Burgundy wine and rosemary-glaze served with soft polenta, Rack of Lamb with Dijon mustard & herb crust served with a potato, eggplant and pesto napoleon, and Adriatic stew with Pacific Rockfish, mussels, calamari & prawns. All the food was so delicious presented well and the service impeccable. We had two bottles of wine an Amarone and another red I can't remember. The gelato for desert and Panna Cotta W/ coulis of port wine and berries was great and we left full, happy and with great memories.
author: Bill F.

description: We took a friend here for her birthday as it has become our favorite restaurant in the City. As always, the service was impeccable and the food outstanding! We each ordered an appetizer (salad, stuffed calamari, sardines) and shared. We each had our own entree - I had the mushroom risotto, she had the peas & saffron risotto, and my husband had the spaghetti and meatballs. All of these were excellent and prepared just right: the risotto is the best since I lived in Italy! For desert we had the chocolate amaretto flan (truly a masterpiece!) accompanied by glasses of Visciola (a cherry infused wine). Another memorable meal at an outstanding restaurant.
author: David C.

description: A hidden gem. This hole-in-the wall has amazing food. So happy to have stumbled across it.
author: Shane M.

description: Incredible food, service, and atmosphere. This place makes you feel incredibly loved because of the dedication they put into making your experience so comfortable.
author: Meryl D.

description: This is probably the best food I have ever had. Hands down the happiest restaurant I have ever walked in to. Quiet calm atmosphere. Cozy. Tiny dinning area but well worth it! We made dinner reservations and it served us well on New Year's Eve night. The chef and owner SAM was our waiter. What a wonderful man. He spoke so passionately about his food and gave wonderful recommendations. Honestly, support this business because this family is well worth the investment. Best tiramisu ever. So in love with this spot.
author: Calli D.

description: Where do I start. The is food here was absolutely amazing. Sam, the chef and owner, was extremely pleasant and made us feel right at home. He immediately brought over 2 glasses of complimentary proseco to welcome us along with some hot bread. Started off with the mushroom soup and stuffed calamari in a marinara sauce with fresh basil.  The fresh marinara coupled with the basil made for a very refreshing taste. Now on the the main course...  I ordered the seafood stew which was filled with white fish, shrimp, calamari, scallops, clams, and mussels all in a nice nice brown sauce. Artecia had a mushroom risotto which she asked Sam to add scallops and extra garlic (as she put it... when you think it's too much add more). Both dishes had great presentation and came with an explosion of flavors to make for a happy pallet. Finished with an apple strudel and a scoop of ice cream (apples, raisins and nuts). The tiramisu was smooth, desiccant, an beautiful in the words of Artecia.  Overall we had a great experience and would definitely recommend this place. It has a great atmosphere and food to match. Hope to cross paths with Sam and his amazing culinary creations in the near future!
author: R C.

description: Albona is a ten year tradition when I come out to attend Open World.  All the dishes are hand made and wonderful with unexpected surprises. The intimate setting defies big city dining and the service is exquisite.
author: Deb A.

description:
This place is A M A Z I N G ! 
You can taste the freshness in every bite. A definite must while in San Francisco.
author: Liz O.

description:
How did this place slip my radar? We were looking for a spot close to our show at Bimbos, so took a chance. It is absolutely worth every 5 star rating. From the outside, you could easily pass it by. Inside is old school San Francisco, with amazing food.

We started with a salad and gnocchi - the salad was good... but the gnocchi? WOWZERS! imagine little balls of mashed potatoes, delicately fried & then plated in a beef gravy. Yeah - it's something dreams are made of.

I ordered the proscuitto streudel with béchamel - it was like nothing I've ever had. Served like a lasagna, just amazing. Hubby ordered the raviolis with 2 sauces - and again, amazing. Service was great, food was fantastic. Forget Bimbos, we will come back here often!

I wish they had a liquor license, but their wine list was reasonable & the bottle we ordered delish. Parking in this area can be hard, but the store at the end of the street offered spaces for $20 which made it easy.
author: Maureen B.

description: Albona is absolutely superb, both the food and the service. Each of us had a different dish from fish, to pasta, to risotto and veal which couldn't have been better. Sam went above and beyond on service, allowing us to try different drinks we were considering as well as making recommendations. We would highly recommend Albona all around.
author: Gina C.

description: Food was very different. Not many vegetarian options and not good for kids. Some things were over-seasoned (ravioli with sage butter, which also had raisins in them), while others were under seasoned and bland (seafood risotto). Overall food was expensive for what it was. Expected a lot more.
author: Kevin H.

description: Love our little neighborhood regional restaurant. Every visit is a treat. The food is a nice change from the usual Italian faire from tge town of Albona.
author: carol a.

description:
A good find during a recent visit to San Francisco to celebrate DH's birthday. If he were writing this review, he would give Albona five stars and maybe more.

We both found the asparagus soup was a very special dish. It was not cream based but still creamy in taste and texture.

DH's lamb chops were thick and tasty. Easy to have a clean plate even with a generous serving.

I did not want a large entree so opted for the pasta "strudel" which was quite cheesy but a bit too salty for my taste.

To end our pleasant meal we shared a delicious homemade apple strudel with vanilla ice cream.  Every bit as good as what my Bohemian MIL used to make.  DH had a complimentary dish of gelato (with a candle!) to recognize his birthday.  Nice touch.  Espresso was good.

The wine list was interesting.  A little hard to choose as we were not familiar with the Italian wines.  And to complicate things, several of the wines on the list were no longer available.

We dined on a Tuesday evening and when we arrived at 7:30 there were only a few other customers.  Several more parties arrived later.

Service was friendly and professional.  While overall we liked the ambiance of the restaurant, there were a few things that caused me to drop a star.  The wine menu was not up-to-date and had stains on it as did the main menu. Also one of the banquette benches was badly worn ... leather seat was torn and very ratty looking.  Fortunately we were not seated there as I would have been uncomfortable.
author: Elaine P.

description:
Oh my God... This place is amazing! My teenage girls wanted fettuccine, which was not on the menu. But they made an amazing variation!  It was delicious! 

I had he lamb chops... Probably the best I have ever had.  The sauce was so good I had to request more bread to wipe my plate clean!  

We finished off with Tiramisu which was so good! Ordered a cappuccino which I usually add cream to, but it was so good I drank it black!
author: G J.

description: This is by far my favorite Ristorante in San Francisco. The owner and staff are marvelous and the food is outstanding.
author: Irene C.

description:
I finally tried this hidden North Beach neighborhood gem with a guest from out of town.  I was nervous about getting seated around 7pm on a Thursday night without a reservation, but the friendly host found a table for us. 

Note:  they STRONGLY recommend having a reservation.  The dining room is very small, so this recommendation makes sense.  

The menu is short, but throughout showcasing Istrian cuisine.  What exactly is that? Yeah, I had to look it up too.  Istria is near Croatia and shares cultural aspects from  Croatia, Slovenia and Italy.  

Not only were we greeted by the friendly host and later our server, an actual chef came out to visit with us!  He was very welcoming and gladly answered any questions we had about the menu.  He actually talked me out of of getting a pasta dish and encouraged me to go for something more "adventurous".  I really enjoyed the personal perks of our dining experience.  

We started our meals with the Insalata mista and picia salads.  Both were excellent.  Although it may be too pungent for some, I specifically enjoyed the truffle vinaigrette in the picia salad.  

For my main entree I ordered the Polo impana con salsa de capori, a pan-seared breaded chicken dish.  It was excellent, but since it was fried, it was a tad bit oily.  The chicken was finished off with a light, tasty caper sauce. Mashed potatoes accompanied the chicken and were creamy perfection.  A small side of perfectly steamed broccoli florets accented the chicken and mashed potatoes.  

My dining partner ordered the Strudel con pasta fatta in casa.  This rich lasagna-like dish was excellent.  

We finished the meal with Bonet, a dark chocolate and amaretto flan.  It was outstanding!  

The portion sizes were quite generous and we both had doggy bags to take home.  

This is a very special place to share a intimate and unique meal tucked away in a quiet neighborhood street away from the hustle and bustle of North Beach.   I strongly recommend it!
author: Andrea H.

description:
Albona sits on a quiet street in the North Beach neighborhood.  With just 24 seats, its a relatively small place.  Its brightly lit inside - I would suggest dimming the lights and putting candles at each table. 

The menu was provided to us on legal-sized paper.  We had to ask for the wine list, it was another (slightly more wrinkled) piece of paper.  There were a handful of wines to choose from, but a very simple list overall. 

I ordered the "Peto de Polo con salsa de rosmarin".  It is essentially a roasted free-range chicken breast sitting in a sherry and rosemary sauce.  There are roasted potatoes, carrots and zucchinis surrounding the chicken in the sauce.  The quantity of sauce was plentiful - it was a bit of a bath.  I give the dish a B in terms of both flavor and plating. 

The service was fairly good, but nothing to write home about. 

On the plus side, street parking in the area is available for those willing to walk a couple blocks.  And all of their desserts are made in-house which is impressive for a small establishment.
author: Joel B.

description: I went here for "date night" with my fiancé and am so glad we did!! Everything was perfect, from the ambiance of the restaurant to the service from the host and waiter to the food. We ordered the arugula salad (awesome), gnocchi appetizer (awesome), sardine appetizer (very good), braised veal (amazing), and the rabbit (the best!). Everything was absolutely delicious and the top notch service made it even better... highly recommended!
author: Alicia F.

description:
What a great experience at Albona.  We ate here a few years ago and remembered liking it but haven't been back since.  Since we had last minute  guests visiting SF and they really wanted Italian food in North Beach, we thought we would take them to Albona.

Lucky for us, We were able to make reservations for 6 people at 6:30 on a Saturday last minute.  The venue is fairly small but cozy and had ambiance.

For appetizers we ordered "grandmothers specialty" pan fried gnocchi in brown sirloin sauc laced with cumin.  The flavors were so distinct and almost a Mediterranean flavor.  The gnocchi was tender and melted in your mouth.

For my entree, I ordered the risotto with mushrooms and it was delightful.  Chunks of crimini and porcini mushrooms, perfectly cooked risotto and not too saucy.   My husband had the ravioli with three cheeses, pine nuts, and golden raisins in a fried sage and butter sauce.  The filling for the ravioli was so meaty I thought there was meat in it.  It tasted so good!

For dessert, I finished my meal with a 10 year Graham's tawny port.
author: Maria V.

description: Went there for a second time, 6 years apart, since I don't live in San Francisco. Had a great meal with exceptional service. I'm going to make this place a regular stop anytime I'm in sfo.
author: Thomas R.

description:
Albona is a cute little mom and pop Italian Restaurant nestled in Nob Hill, away from the main drag. I had my doubts because most of the Italian joints in this neighborhood are extremely touristy and overhyped. While Albona was a cute, traditional place for dinner, it wasn't a destination and catered alot to the older crowd. I wouldn't be surprised if many of the 5 star reviews came from loyal neighborhood patrons, because the service was so wonderful. Perhaps if you are one of those Noe Valley Italian Restaurant 5-star reviewers, you may like this as well.

It was my anniversary, and the manager brought out complimentary champagne. He offered complimentary dessert also when I made the reservation over the phone (they're hard to get a hold of!), but dessert already came with my Travelzoo Voucher ($69 for 3-courses for 2 people - what a steal!). Surprisingly, there were no restrictions on the menu for which 3 courses to select. Typically, restaurants will limit you to the lower priced items and/or make you share dishes. Great deal but note: they include tax/gratuity on the full price of the meal. 

I was disappointed with the quality of the food overall, if I were to return it would merely be to rule out some potential dishes I didn't try. Some things I wish I had ordered instead were the mussels (appetizer), rabbit, any pasta, chocolate flan and panna cotta. 

* COMPLIMENTARY BREAD ROLLS (2 STARS):
No points docked here, I'll take free carbs any day! The rolls were however quite a disappointment, they felt warm but stale like they were store bought, a bit stale and reheated in the microwave. The hard butter tore this roll apart.

* CALAMARI AL FORNO CON SALSA MARINARA (2 STARS) - $12: 
Three medium sized squid, stuffed with toasted bread crumbs, parsley, and garlic; roasted in marinara sauce. I squeezed the stuffing out, did not like the bread crumb heavy stuffing and the sauce tasted very... prego like. Overall I was very disappointed because I love squid!

* CAPUZI GARBI CON PROSUTO E LUGANEGA (2.5 STARS) - $12: 
Braised sauerkraut with onions, apples and prosciutto with 3 halves of italian sausage. The waiter recommended against this because it has a strong pickled flavor, but I couldn't resist because I love sausage! I thought the sausage was OK, salty and dense - underwhelming for $12. I much prefer Rosamunde's ovepriced dogs.

* COSTOLETTE DE ANIEL (4 STARS) - $30:
Rack of Lamb with Dijon mustard & herb crust served with a potato, eggplant and pesto napoleon. I enjoyed the rack of lamb, at a price point of $30 I would definitely get it again considering the famed Kokkari rack costs a whopping $42, although it is still not cheap. 

* INVOLTIN DE PORCO CON CAPUZI GARBI E PROSUTO (2 STARS) - $27:
Pork loin stuffed with sauerkraut, prosciutto, apples, and plums served with red cabbage sauté. The pork was a bit salty, dry... nothing about this was redeeming except it was a decently sized portion that could fill you up. 

* STRUDEL DE POMI (2 STARS) - $8:
Apple strudel with cinnamon, pine nuts, and golden raisins with vanilla ice cream (plus $3 = $11). This dessert was OK, but reminded me of the frozen desserts at Safeway that you bake at home, or a buffet. Supposedly these are all homemade desserts but I was quite unimpressed, perhaps it would have been better with a flaky butter crust instead?

* TIRAMISU (2 STARS) - $8:
This tiramisu was soaked way too much in rum. Huge pet peeve of mine. The cake became grossly soggy and squishy, and there was not enough marscapone cream to balance it all out. I regretted ordering this and wished I had ordered the panna cotta and the dark chocolate flan instead.
author: Jess C.

description:
Underwhelming and not as advertised. 

Service and wine selection excellent. Food good quality, but very average. Fresh ingredients and good taste. Just not an outstanding experience.

Ambiance not bad.
author: Glenn T.

description: Soooooo delicious!! Loved the prosciutto salad with truffle oil. That alone was worth the trip. Rack of lamb was perfect. Great service.
author: DIane S.

description:
This place is awesome.  Albona is a very "down to earth" no-frills, hidden gem tucked away in a very obscure location in North Beach away from the main drag of Italian eateries. . Service is great, food is unique and savory, atmosphere is very homey - You feel like you're eating in someone's home dining room, very intimate.

Came on a slow sunday evening. The owner/head chef (of 18 years!) walked us through the menu and told us the specials before the main service started. I went with the stuffed pork loin (bomb) and my uncle had the veal shank. Both were awesome. The owner even treated us to a caprese-type salad AND a coffee gelato on the house!  he knew we were celebrating a birthday...  Treat yourself here, you won't be disappointed!
author: Matty S.

description:
We were looking for a restaurant within walking distance of our hotel and stumbled upon this great find on Yelp. We called to see about a reservation and they agreed to seat us within the hour. We didn't realize how lucky we were until later in the evening when a very large party arrived for dinner. 

This restaurant is tiny and extremely romantic. The candlelight gives everything a beautiful, soft glow.

The service was outstanding. Very solicitous but never intrusive. The pacing of the meal was perfect. 

I had the mushroom risotto. It was delicious. The server helped us select a wonderful red to go with our meal. The food was an interesting combination of sweet and savory. The cooking style was so unique, I am not sure I have ever had anything like it in the past.

To be honest, it was one of those perfect nights, when you fall into something unexpectedly amazing and pass the evening in a haze of gratitude that this is your life.
author: Susan C.

description:
Visited this place on a slower Thursday night for dinner. Overall, this is the idea date night and upscale yet relaxed experience with the best pasta I've had since being in Italy years ago.

Food - 5 stars I ordered the Arugula salad with prosciutto to start and it was delicious. The dressing was just right and the flavors were wonderful. For my main I had the Strudel con pasta fatta in casa. This is the best Italian pasta dish I've had since being in Italy. I could eat a bowl of the tomato cheese, etc sauce by itself. My friends kept taking my sauce. The pasta was cooked perfect. Delicious. 

Drinks - they only serve wine and its a fairly good variety. 

Service - Its a little slow but the waiters are very helpful in making recommendations.
author: Jessica C.

description:
I've known him for sixteen and half years. We've eaten in many restaurants, mostly, I think sushi restaurant.  For my belated birthday, he said, "I found this restaurant not far from my house. I've never been there before. I wanted something that is not sushi." Hmmm.. Did he read my tumblr piece that amply named "Sushi boat restaurant and men who loved sushi"? Or did he read my inner monologue of "I can't do sushi any more!" when another friend who wanted to go for sushi last Friday suggested Ebisu and I had such a strong allergic reaction to it (Yes he and I went there 16 years ago) that I almost punched that other friend who had absolutely no idea why I was so upset. 

Well, Italian it is, except - it was not. It's Istrian, it's technically Croatian food. As I walked into the restaurant and I was thinking, hmmm.. a bit quiet, let's hope the food would be good. Well, the food was good, it was excellent. I went straight for sauerkraut and rabbit. Interesting execution on the sauerkraut which is wrapped in pancetta and served on the side is sausage. Very interesting. I trust Michael Bauer and he likes it here, eight years straight.

Afterwards I did research and I found that it is the only Istrian restaurant in the west coast. I like one of a kind of things. I blindly trust my dining partner's taste. He's got fantastic taste, both in culinary and fashion. This came to be such an experience. - it's one of a kind restaurant. 

Tried his lamb chop, it seemed fried, but very tender and tasty. I was busy telling stories and he was just smiling the whole time, laughing at my not funny jokes. I thought to myself, it must be something in the dishes because I'm really funny. You can tell when the restaurant knows its service because the wait staff came to check our progress and was staying in the background because I was on a roll telling not so funny stories (note to self: I will indeed keep my day job.) Then when we had absolutely no room for dessert, they brought out some mouse cake - dessert on the house they said. It was good but too much food, we took a bite and had to call it a night.  But how wonderful they gave us dessert on the house! 

While eating the rabbit, I kept on thinking, given that this was one half rabbit, where did the other half go? Since it was not deboned, did I just east the leg or did I eat the arm? 

I have been looking for good rabbit for a long time. I also will take every opportunity I can to get sauerkraut. In conclusion, this restaurant serves weird but fantastical dishes - it's a bit of Italian, a bit of eastern European and a bit of Austrian / German. It's sophisticated and unusual, add on good quality food and excellent service, it's a five, through and through.
author: Victoria E.

description: Loved this restaurant.  It is small and intimate and a little off the beaten path.  We had a wonderful experience from start to finish.  The service was excellent!  I just cannot say enough good things about the staff.  The food was the best that I have had in a long time.  I had their soup of the day, a cream of asparagus, there was no cream or butter and it was still rich and creamy.  My main course was the Carpi with fried sage and butter.  So rich and decadent.  I highly recommend this restaurant.  I will definitely go back next time I am in San Francisco!!
author: Michelle D.

description:
We always love this place.  We wish we could get in the neighborhood more often. 

Everything about Albona is unique.   The food is a combination of Italian and German (extreme eastern region of Italy).  The location is off the beaten path in North Beach.  The service is SO friendly.

You can go in two directions on the menu and they're both good.   You can go Italian and have a gnocchi appetizer and linguini with clams for the main.   Or, you can go German and have asparagus soup with pork loin and sauerkraut.  It's a wild mix but so good. 

Really,  you vill like it!
author: Jim K.

description: Old school place off the beaten path in north beach. Food was solid - loved my lamb chops. Friendly service. Good date place.
author: Eric C.

description: The food was superb. Most delicate gnocchi in a fabulously unusual regional sauce. Thank heavens they give you a spoon to scoop it up! The regional fish stew also had an amazing red wine reduction with generous fresh shellfish selection. The best and freshest caramelized pear and Gorgonzola salad with another amazing glaze. Our 11 year old loved the spaghetti and meatballs. satisfying but not oily or heavy... Just fabulous tastes. Very nice waiter and chef.
author: Denise M.

description:
We ate at Albona on a whim for our Anniversary. The food was all so excellent I can't even say what was my favorite!  We had the Wild Arugula and Prosciutto salad with Truffle Vinaigrette, the dressing was delicate with just enough bite from the vinegar. Then we had the soup of the day, Creamy Mushroom, no dairy but it tasted just like it had been made with cream!  Finally we had the Pasta Rolls with Prosciutto and then baked in casserole. It was seasoned perfectly and the tomato cream sauce was the best accompaniment. 

The wait staff was very attentive but not overbearing, the manager came out at least once to check on us and the ambiance was casual and friendly yet just as fancy as we wanted for our special dinner. 

Overall, 100% on point, Albona is a place we would definitely visit again!
author: Anne R.

description:
Very nice initial Saturday evening experience at this North Beach ristorante Istriano, including a greeting and check-in by the owner/chef.

Dinner for two with three pasta dishes, followed up by a fine rack of lamb. A glass of prosecco, followed by a fine bottle of Montepulciano di Abruzzo. Espresso and three dessert items. 

Service left us well-tended and happy.

I recommend Albona for your couple or friends. The atmosphere is intimate, and I would not go beyond a table for four to preserve it.

Enjoy!
author: Reyn J.

description: Chef Samuel and his staff provided an amazing experience for my wife and myself. Tomato soup appetizer was spectacular! Spaghetti and meatballs were fabulous! Desert was wonderful! Thank you for an amazing experience Chef Samuel and we will definitely be back!
author: Chris S.

description: The service: superb. The ambiance: romantic. The food: top notch. One of the best kept secrets in North Beach.
author: Buck N.

description:
Had dinner here while I was in the US a couple of weeks ago. The Pasta rolls dish with the baked prosciutto, lappa cheese, bechamel, tomato sauce and cream - hands-down the best meal I had while there.

It was ridiculously delicious!

The restaurant was quiet and intimate. Had a lovely wine list and the service was excellent.

Recommended. Will definitely go there again next time I'm in San Fran.
author: Ros M.

description: This is a small and I intimate Resturant on a residential block near Fishermans Wharf.  It's very easy to miss but that is because it is truly a hidden treasure.  No pomp, or hype here.  The food is 5 stars offering north east Italian/Croatian dishes.  A must for anyone visiting the Bay Area.  By far the best you can eat.
author: Franco C.

description: Went here due to the write up showing both Italian and Croatian food fare.  Took a risk honestly because I was with several work friends.  Great decision.  Just delicious!!   The meats melted Off the bone and the salad was fresh , large and super crisp.  Small but really nice wine menu.  Sam the owner made it all very personal and friendly!!   Going back for sure!!
author: Cheryl F.

description: Party of 10 and everyone one of us thought our food was fantastic. Wonderful service that went way beyond. What a jewel worth finding.
author: Kathleen P.

description:
This place is a hidden gem!

I have lived in the Wharf for over 9 years and this is one of the best  restaurants around. They treat you like family but the good kind. The food is delicious, the ambiance is cozy, and the service is fantastic.
author: Toby D.

description: One of the best mushroom risottos ever.... Literally tastes soooo creamy and cheesy and trufffffle-ish!!! Yum... I definitely will be back just for that! Other dishes were all great too, namely the lamp and pork loins. This restaurant is definitely German influenced though, serving sauerkraut with their pork (which works!).
author: Betty T.

description: The best! Next time I'm in SF I will be back! Love this family owned spot (support your local businesses). Came for a date night; super nice restaurant, romantic but fun at the same time. Started with the gnocchi (amazing) then shared a pasta and the filet... everything so yummy and well priced. The wine was amazing, service and food perfection. We will be back!
author: Kara M.

description: This is one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco. The food is amazing but it truly does not compare to the service. The wait staff is extremely kind and very patient, especially with big parties. Would recommend to anyone that wants a great spot to eat in a cozy, welcoming atmosphere.
author: Hannah P.

description: We discovered Albona late one evening after a long trip. The server and chef were most welcoming and we really enjoyed the food: stuffed calamari, the salmon special, and pasta with clam sauce. We even had dessert and an after-dinner drink. Delicious and relaxing.
author: Ileinie W.

description:
Gosh this place is good. I came here with my bf for an early valentine's date dinner because we couldn't get a reservation at the other restaurants we wanted to try. However, thank goodness for those booked restaurants! Since we came from out of town, we were debating on canceling our reservation to try something else we saw since this was in a small quiet street that looked a bit sketch, however we are both so glad we ended up coming here.

We ordered the calamari which was pretty amazing, not your average fried calamari. The calamari was cooked perfectly, so it was still a bit soft.

My boyfriend went with the rack of lamb, which was not incredibly amazing compared to my dish....which was the Strudel! If you're debating on what to get, do yourself a favor and get the Strudel. Thank me later. 

For dessert, we ordered the Panna Cotta, it was decent. I'd skip out on dessert here and stop by BiRite Ice Cream.
author: Rebecca W.

description: Ate there last night. Waiter was incredibly helpful in guiding us to a superb red wine. We both had the raviolis which were beyond compare. Our mista salads were among the best I've ever tasted. Have been coming to this lovely restaurant (yes, linen not formica tabletops) for many years. It never disappoints.
author: Robert Y.

description:
Wow.

It has been a long time since I've enjoyed such a combination of service and quality. The mushroom risotto , lamb , veal - HOLY hell!!! 

Manager Sam makes you feel like family. He very well may be the best man at my wedding. Hard working honest folks.

Can't wait to be back.
author: Jordan Z.

description: We went there on Christmas night. We had reservation but had to wait for over 5 min to get seated. Service was a little poor perhaps because they were busy. Ambiance is great and the place is really cozy. Maybe a little less brightness would make it more romantic. The food was really good. We had the veal and ravioli.
author: Omid A.

description: Ok! By far One of the best Italian restaurants I've ever been to. I love that it's in a quiet neighborhood hole in the wall type place. The owner/'s chef were so accommodating and friendly. The staff was fantastic. It felt like home!!! I can't wait to go back.
author: Maria N.

description:
The. Best. Dining. Experience. EVER.  Unique.  Memorable.  Unforgettable.  Exceptional.  Simply remarkable and sensational on every level you could imagine.
  
Located off the beaten path, Albona was recommended by a friend of a friend.  I knew I HAD to dine here before leaving San Francisco.  I called first to make reservations and was told they were 'full'.  Nothing available.  I explained to the courteous man on the phone that I was from Chicago, heard great things about their restaurant, and that I was only in town for 1 more day.  I left my phone # and asked to be called in the event a table was available.

I received a call later from the Manager the same day stating he had a table for 2 available as he was informed I was from Chicago and that he was more than happy to accommodate me. The conversation alone left a fond impression on me.  I was ecstatic to say the least and had no expectations going in...I was told this was a restaurant to check out, but never imagined the treasure I was about to discover.  I thought this was Italian, when in fact this cuisine is a combination of Italy, Croatia & Slovania known as Istrian.  

We cabbed it to Albona and upon entering the unassuming building off a quiet side street, I was taken by the very intimate and charming room.  It was rather small, but very comfortable.  My friend & I were seated immediately.  The waiter was outstanding.  As I stared at the menu consisting of everything 'tempting', I wanted to know what their specialty was.  What is on or off the menu that I should try?  (I always ask for suggestions whenever I'm 'new' to a cuisine).
He offered wonderful recommendations, including various wines.  This waiter was charming, engaging...and my girlfriend & I were thoroughly enjoying the banter...and flirting..

Appetizer:  Grandmother's homemade fried potato gnocchi in a brown meat sauce w/cumin. Calamari al forno (stuffed w/bread crumbs) in marinara.  Before receiving our app's, the manager came over to greet us, and poured our wine.  He was so friendly, we couldn't stop talking as he came to check on us often...we loved his attention..(he was really, really cute too...I could literally just talk about *him*, but...) onto the food.  The gnocchi was nothing like a traditional pasta gnocchi.  These were more like round morsels of fried dough.  Very much like pieces of panzerotti dough made with potatoes (that's exactly what this reminded me of).  In fact, I even mentioned this to Mike (Manager).  He smiled when I said that, but wasn't going to 'give away any secrets'.  They were divine as was the complimenting sauce.  The squid was delicious as well.  Tenderly filled sitting in a tasty tomato sauce.

For entree's I went with the signature, Strudel con pasta fatta in casa (homemade).  Friend had the risotto con funghi.  Both were Mike's recommendation.  The strudel was much like a 'rotolo'. Baked with layers of lappi cheese, béchamel, prosciutto, & tomato cream sauce.  Amazingly good.  The risotto was cooked perfectly.  Every dish was outstanding.

After indulging in deliciousness and a bottle of wine later, Mike came by to bring us complimentary dessert...he asked what we'd like to have.  I was stuffed at this point and couldn't eat another bite, but he insisted.  He came back with 3 different desserts!!! Tiramisu, Bonet & Gelato.  All heavenly (not to mention Mike..;)  It was probably around 10 or 11pm as he sat with us, bringing out more wine, aperitif's, etc...etc...and the restaurant was now empty.  He was closing up, but yet we stayed - he insisted.  We weren't complaining. And the night went on, and on, and on..till around 1am!....we exchanged emails (yes, that's all we exchanged...sadly..).  

I will never forget Albona's or Mike.  It was the perfect ending to a perfect trip (if only he didn't already have a girlfriend ((who happened to stop in & sit with us also))....double *sigh*...).
I love you San Francisco...
author: Nancy L.

description:
Five stars as always. Stunningly good, wonderfully executed and extremely fresh food. You eat and drink while being treated like family. 

Must go.
author: Zak S.

description:
Totally hidden gem, this cozy, comfortable little place.  

Sam, the owner, just rewrites the book on warmth and hospitality.  We had never been for Istrian food, and wanted something representative.  Sam was ready with recommendations to their top dishes.  And fear not vegetarians!  There are plenty of fine choices for you and Sam was very accommodating, even offering to put together a little two-dish sampler special for my wife.  

I started with the gnocchi in sirloin sauce, "grandma's specialty"  It is not to be missed.  Light-as-a-cloud little dumplings in a hearty gravy with just a touch of cumin.  My wife tried some un-sauced parts of the gnocchi, and loved them.  Next time we will ask if they have a vegetarian alternative sauce for her.  But I will still get a second one for me with that awesome cumin sirloin sauce.  She had the peperonata and it was fresh, fragrant and very tasty.  

For our mains, she had a half order each of the penne and an off-the-menu vegetarian version of their mushroom risotto.  Both were excellent!  We would especially would recommend the risotto, it was just perfectly done.  I ordered the veal shank with polenta.  It was very nice too, beefy, succulent, comfort food.  

Dessert was the apple strudel, which was nice and tasty but came out too hot, like nuclear hot!  It took a long time to cool to an edible temperature.  We also ordered the panna cotta.  Rich, and creamy, it was our favorite of the two desserts.
author: Joe P.

description:
Leave it to my erudite friends Jonathan and Syd to find the hidden culinary jewels in this city. After all, they were the ones who introduced me to the charming La Ciccia in outer Noe Valley a few years back, and we went to another out-of-the-way Italian restaurant halfway between North Beach and Fisherman's Wharf called Albona. Whereas La Ciccia is purely Sardinian, Albona is decidedly Istrian. Istrian? Yeah, I didn't know where Istria was either until I looked at their website afterward. It's a town in Croatia south of Trieste, which is on Italy's eastern border next to Slovenia. Confused? Me too, but the food is not confusing. It's quite stellar as a matter of fact - primarily northern Italian dishes with a definite Eastern European accent and a slight Mediterranean twang.

It's a tiny place but not terribly difficult to make a reservation. Despite its stellar Yelp ratings, Albona keeps an awfully low profile in a city full of obsessive foodies. They offer free valet parking which they tell you when they confirm your reservation. After working a decade under the tutelage of founder Bruno Viscovi, chef Samuel Hernandez took over the kitchen three years ago. Now I have no idea if the quality of the dishes wavered in the transition, but judging from what we ordered, I have to believe Bruno would be quite pleased. We started by sharing a couple of their appetizers. First up was the $9 Chifeleti de Mia Nona con Sugo de Carne al Cumin (Pan-fried Potato Gnocchi in Brown Sirloin Sauce with Cumin - see photo).  They bill it as "grandmother's specialty", and you could picture Bruno's grandma making the eight pillow-like gnocchi and sauteing them to a crispy brown.

Next was the $12 Calamai al Forno con Salsa Marinara (Squid Stuffed with Toasted Bread Crumbs, Parsley, and Garlic Roasted in Marinara Sauce - see photo), which was surprisingly tender and hearty at the same time. Probably the most exquisite dish of the evening was the risotto - the $18 Risoto Vegetariano con Zaferan (Risotto Peas and Saffron Threads) - so melt-in-your-mouth delicious with just the right consistency and freshness (see photo). We then shared a pasta that sounded too tempting not to try - the $19 Strudel con Pasta Fatta en Casa, which were fresh pasta rolls stuffed with baked prosciutto and lappi cheese baked with toasted bread crumbs in a bechamel and tomato-cream sauce as a casserole (see photo). It was a bit like manicotti but much silkier in texture with a nice savory flavor to contrast with the dairy.

Of course, we needed to try one of their entrees, and we landed on their $29 Stufato di Agnello (Lamb with Vegetables Served in a Broth), where the lamb took the form of riblets, loin and sausage, all perfectly tender, mixed with root vegetables and zucchini squash and all of it in a broth infused with mustard, horseradish, lemon zest, and fresh thyme (see photo). It was the kind of comfort food you would expect to find on my dream farm in the Tuscan countryside if I happened to be an extraordinarily talented cook. We didn't want the meal to end, so we had to try one of their specialty desserts. We decided on the $8 Crema de Gelato, a frozen triple-cream vanilla gelato mousse with brandied cherries (see photo).

Decadent enough on its own, but Chef Hernandez was feeling generous and gave us the Strudel di Pomi as a bonus, a genuine apple strudel with cinnamon, pine nuts and golden raisins dusted with powdered sugar (see photo). Needless to say, we were sated and quite proud of our team approach in trying out a good sampling of their specialties. Albona has been around for 23 years, but amazingly, I never had the unique pleasure of a dining experience here before. It's probably because it sits on an otherwise residential street looking very nondescript. Now that I know it does exist, I will need to come back for more of Bruno's grandma's home-style dishes.

FOOD - 5 stars...home-style dishes mixing culinary delights from Italy, Austria, Croatia and other nearby countries that end in a vowel, impeccably presented
AMBIANCE - 4 stars...compact but low-key and comfortable on a less-than-busy Sunday evening
SERVICE - 5 stars...first-class with personal attention from Chef Hernandez
TOTAL - 5 stars...now I know where Albona is!
author: Ed U.

description: The food is really really good, the service is good, and the restaurant is quite. I spend my two year anniversary with my BF here. I had a good time here. It's a nice place to come.
author: Serena W.

description:
I only have the best things to see about this place. Ate here on a Friday night before a comedy show around the corner and let our server know that we were going to a show around 7:30 and he thanked us for letting us know, and our meal was perfect timed for our show. We started with some wine - my glass of chianti was very pleasant. Started with the small salad, and it was refreshing and tasty - lightly dressed with some nice veggies mixed in. But my entree... holy mother of pasta. I got the  stuffed baked pasta (strudel) with prosciutto, cheese, bread crumbs and fresh julienned basil on top... It was one of the best dishes I've ever had. The sides of the dish were a bit crispy where it had been baked which gave it great texture and mouth feel, and soft and gooey in the middle. Perfectly portioned too - it was very hearty, but not too big, so after I wolfed it down, I wasn't feeling too full. Very cute interior and great service.

Can't wait to come back here, as I had one of my favorite dishes ever.
author: Sarah B.

description:
Yelp led us to Albona Ristorante, I was completely unfamiliar with Istrian cuisine, but my husband is Croatian and Italian, and he's pretty great so how could Albona be bad? It couldn't. We made friends while waiting to be seated and we were warmly welcomed by Sam when we were seated. He picked up on my husband's last name and we were quickly acquainted and it felt like he was a celebrity since the owner Bruno is Croatian and Italian, too. 

We started with a lovely bottle of white wine from the Amalfi Coast, enjoyed velvety mushroom soup, the house gnocchi - which is nothing like the Italian potato dumplings, but still tasty in their own right. Then, we stuffed ourselves silly on the fantastic lamb chops and scrumptious mushroom risotto. 

When they offered the dessert menu we couldn't possibly eat anymore, but they brought us their strudel to make up for their tardiness bringing the check. It was barely sweet just like those we would enjoy at Croatian picnics held in Chicago.

$119 was a small price to pay for such a special experience.
author: Kellee K.

description: It's been a wile since I have written any reviews but I felt compelled to do one here. This place was awesome with overall great food and service. We we in the city in a Saturday night without any reservations and called here at the last minute hoping for a table as the location is walking distance from be piers. We didn't really find anything there and it's always crazy and too touristy anyway. Wow what a find the Albona was!! We will definitely put this hidden jewel on our dining list when we are in the city and need a place to eat. All the dishes we had were superb. It's best to reserve a table as the seating is limited. Thanks Albona for fitting us in on a Saturday eve and making our SF day perfect!
author: Glenn P.

description:
Came here with a Travelzoo deal for two for 3 course meals each.

We were greeted warmly right as we arrived.  The restaurant was warm with a charming neighborhood feel.

We had a calamari appetizer and a mussel appetizer.  Both were delicious!  A bit on the briny side, which my mom loved!

My mom had the seafood pasta (another hit!) and I had the lamb.  The lamb was well prepared with some mustard / mint sauce -- very rich! 

For dessert we had tiramisu (tasty) and an apple strudel (kind of like an overstuffed crepe).

Overall, well executed food with wholesome ingredients!  
Albona feels very classic and old world in a charming way!
author: Kathryn C.

description:
First - dont waste your time on their credit card required reservation system. This place was 1/2 empty when we went.  I understand restaurants not wanting cancellations, but that only makes sense if you are booked out and this would have prevented revenue.  This place probably loses more money than it makes with this cancellation policy.

This is a nice old school SF Italian restaurant. If you want to do a quiet nice date night, this place fits the bill. The staff was nice. The food was ok. Nothing that I would be racing back to have again, but nothing that turned me off.
author: Markus S.

description:
Regional Istrian cuisine in an intimate and romantic atmosphere. 

It was not part of the plan, but with some guidance from Yelp, and a little bit of luck we ended up having dinner here. I was afraid that as walk-ins we were not going to be able to get a dinner table, and I would have been correct if not for a bizarre situation. We were second in line out of three 2 person groups. The first group was arguing with the maitre d about having made a reservation while the maitre d insisted they had not. The maitre d said they had a table available anyways, yet the couple decided to leave. We snagged the table. The wait for the couple after us: 45 minutes. They also decided to leave. 

I was a bit concerned about the service given the exchange we had just witnessed, but service was really friendly and informative throughout. Strangely though, there were definitely open tables that could have been put to better use, so perhaps they have to improve their logistics. 

The Istrain food was definitely different from what you typically expect from Italian. The potato 'gnocchi' were more akin to a different variety of dumplings and the cumin beef sauce they were served in was definitely unique, yet very tasty. 

The seafood risotto was not bad, though not particularly wow-inducing either. Their homemade ravioli was simple, yet good. The panna cotta was also pretty good. 

Overall, I had a positive dining experience. From what we tried, perhaps the prices were a tad on the expensive side, but nothing out of the ordinary. I would definitely return to try some other of the recommended dishes.
author: Augusto T.

description:
Don't get confused with Yelp's category of "Italian" for this restaurant - this is an Istrian establishment. ("Istria? What is that? Oh, it's in Croatia. Oh so is this Croatian? Or is this a mix of Italian and Croatian and a billion other things because apparently there's strudels and saeurkraut on the menu" - thoughts that ran in my head as I read the menu) Either way, the food here is good. Really good. Creepily good. Fantastically majestically good. 

It was my mother's birthday and I had a reservation at "Perbacca" for a while until I last minute decided that it wasn't going to be her style. After doing some yelp-soul-searching, I discovered upon Albona and made a quick reservation for the night. We were lucky to find a parking rather quickly and descended upon this restaurant quickly as it was freezing outside. 

FIRST IMPRESSION:
It was a small, intimate restaurant; not overly fancy but not too casual. The atmosphere was...I would say "'polite" but can you describe a restaurant as polite? There was classical music playing softly in the background which my dad absolutely loved. We're all classical music junkies in our family and it is rare to find a restaurant to be playing that. 

WHAT WE ORDERED:

seasonal soup of the day (mushroom): I'm not a fan of mushroom. Like I will throw up if I even smell it. So...I didn't touch this. However, my mother (an avid mushroom lover - yack!) raved over this. Apparently, this mushroom soup was the best she's ever tasted.

calamai al forno con salsa marinara: squid stuffed with white fish, toasted bread crumbs, parsley, and garlic; roasted in marinara sauce. My god. This stuff is amazing. I'm used to eating fried calamari with marinara sauce and scarfing it down like a lunatic. This squid was fresh, chewy, NOT fried, stuffed with a delicious goodness of fish that didn't taste like fishy fish, it tasted like oh-this-is-good-what-is-this-magic fish mixed with other magical ingredients. One of my favorite dishes of the night.

catch of the day (halibut): this was my mother's order. I'm not quite too fond of halibut so I only had a bite or two. It was refreshing, light, and really well prepared. The execution was impressive because I feel like fish can go so wrong (maybe I just have bad experiences with smelly fishy fish and overcooked salmon).

Strudel con pasta fatta in casa: I ordered this based on the rave reviews on Yelp. I normally wouldn't order this - prosciutto and lappi cheese in a pasta roll? That sounded a little too much, too rich for me. However, I ventured out of my comfort zone to try it. The strudel was definitely delicious and tasty, however I found it to be slightly too salty for my taste. It overwhelmed my taste buds and it was much too rich for me to finish by myself. I ate like about half of it and then boxed it for home. 

Costolette de Aniel: this was my dad's order and it was hands down, no argument here, the best dish of the night. It was a Rack of Lamb with Dijon mustard & herb crust served with a potato, eggplant and pesto napoleon. The lamb was perfectly executed and the best lamb I have ever tasted in the history of ever. My dad agreed and oh, boy, he has eaten a LOT of lamb. The sauce was perfect - very tasty without being overly salty. And the potatoes...ohhhhh the potatoes...

strudel de pomi: I always look forward to dessert, me being the sweet tooth that I am. Looking at the menu, i was quite disappointed with the selection, seeing nothing that looked particularly intriguing. I checked handy dandy Yelp and found that most people ordered the apple strudel. So, the strudel we got! And oh the strudel we loved. It wasn't mind blowingly phenomenal but it was good. Really good. The strudel was sweet and tart at the same time, warm and comforting. The gelato on the side was a nice touch (though definitely not worth the extra $3!)

Overall, a wonderful experience. The waiters were attentive and friendly, always making sure our water was filled even though we had the bottle on our table. The ambiance was cozy and intimate. The bill turned out to be $145 with tip, which isn't too bad really for a birthday dinner. However, it is pricey if you're just stopping by for a quick dinner. A well deserved five stars. We will be back!
author: Hannah L.

description:
My husband and I ate here a few months ago - I failed to review this place, but wanted to do so now, as we had a very pleasant experience.  

My husband has always been a fan of Italian - easily his favorite cuisine...while my love of Italian did not happen until we ate our way through Italy two years ago.  Since that trip, it's a true delight to stumble upon some authentic, delicious Italian food - and this place does just that.  

First - the food.  We shared the arugula salad to start - I'm obsessed with arugula (particularly when paired with apples or pears), so this was an easy choice.  This salad was fabulous - delicious dressing that was full of flavor, but not too heavy.  The proscuitto was very tasty as well.  We also split the gnocchi app - which was okay, but we weren't a big fan (it wasn't what you'd think of as typical gnocchi - the texture was more like a "tater tot" as my husband would describe it.  I think next time we'd skip this and opt for another appetizer.

For our main (which we split - and was plenty for the two of us) we ordered the penne arrabiata.  This was very tasty - great sauce, and perfectly cooked al dente pasta.  Highly recommend this. 

The service and atmosphere in this place was also very good.  The place is very quaint and cosy - it is very small with very few tables, which definitely adds to the experience.  Our waiter was also very attentive - but not too attentive (if you know what I mean).  

Overall a very pleasant experience.  Definitely recommend.
author: Rachael S.

description:
What a treat!
A neighborhood gem that you wouldn't notice unless you were looking for it.

From the moment we walked in until we left we were a part of something very special.
We started our enchanted evening with Mushroom soup & pan-fried potato gnocchi (in a brown sirloin sauce & cumin). Both were very tasty.
We continued with squid stuffed with fish, toasted bread crumbs, parsley, and garlic; 
It was mouthwatering good.

For entree my husband had lamb chops & I had stuffed loin pork. We were both happy with our choices. The food was very rich & saucy. We wished that we didn't have  so many appetizers before our entrees. We were feeling quite full half way into the meal.
A nice bottle of red made our meal even more enjoyable.
For dessert we shared a Panna Cota. It was light & lovely.

Service was attentive & friendly.
Atmosphere was very warm & cozy.
The restaurant is very small so I would strongly recommend reservations.

We will definitely be back to try other wonderful creations from the menu.
author: Irina K.

description:
Quaint and nice restaurant off the main roads!  Thanks to our Yelp reviewers we found it and were very impressed.  We shared their Chifaleti as an appetizer - plentiful to share and very flavorful.  We ordered the Strudel con Pasta and the Involtin de Porco - both were fantastic.  I'm not a big sauerkraut person, but my oh my, the Involtin made me a believer.
