It's almost the same thing as the fried potato balls you'd find at Gregoire... with curry. These were really good; order it because it's something different. The calamari was pretty good. I personally dislike the flavor of squid, but the marinara -- nice and acidic as it should be -- was absolutely delightful. I didn't care much for the filling inside, but the marinara made up for all of it. 

For my main course, I ordered the chicken with white wine and capers with mashed potatoes and broccoli. For starters, on the menu it says that the chicken is "pan fried," so I was surprised to see that when I got mine it was two large chicken breast cutlets with the white wine sauce on it. I was under the impression that the chicken would be cooked in the sauce, but hey, coming from a kid whose favorite food is tonkatsu, I was fine with a cutlet (although I probably wouldn't have ordered it if I knew it was a cutlet). To be honest, it was nothing to write home about. The chicken was done perfectly, it was crispy, the mashed potatoes were delightful, and the sauce -- while not in that much quantity -- was pretty good. Nothing to write home about, and not sure if it was worth the $25. The portion was massive. if you come to Albona, come with an empty stomach -- the portions here for the entrees are large and definitely "perfect for sharing," as Sam explained. My mom ordered the veal, which could have had a little more salt (but as a Chinese American I typically like things on the saltier side), but was absolutely divine. My dad ordered the Adriatic Stew, which was good, but nothing that amazing. For dessert we got the strudel, which had an awesome apple filling, but the crust lacked the puffy puff-pastryness that you would expect a strudel to have. Don't pay the extra $3 for the ice cream too; it's really not worth it but it is a nice touch if it's included in a deal you have. In all honesty, the best way to explain the food -- at least from our experience -- at Albona is good. It's not amazing, it's not phenomenal, it's most certainly not bad, but it's good. Just good, and at times if you order the right thing, it's really good. But once again, just not amazing. 

Throughout the entire Saturday night I was there, the service -- as explained earlier -- was phenomenal in the beginning. But as the restaurant began to become more and more crowded, the signature service at Albona -- while still 100% better than average -- kind of disappeared into the night, and I most certainly never felt the "family" or "long time friend" feel that many on here raved about. All the waiters and waitresses -- along with Sam of course -- were kind, caring, and good at what they did, but I felt like we weren't treated as well as the reviews here talk about (even though, once again, the service is better than average.) 

The jist: Don't walk in with too high expectations, come in with an empty stomach, don't be afraid to try something new, and most importantly, be ready for a night filled with a crap load of good food that fits harmoniously and angelically with good friends and family. That's really the best way to sum up Albona. Check it out. 

While this is at heart a 3.5, I'm just giving it a four because it's a modest family-run business, and the people there just give it the extra push.

Food: 24 | Decor: 20 | Service: 24
author: Bryce F.

description: My family and I went here for a nice dinner in San Francisco. The place was very nice and the waiters were great. They spoke spanish with my parents and english to my brother and I. We started off with the gnocchi which was absolutely delicious! I ordered the pasta strudel which had prosciutto in it. It was pretty tasty, but it was too salty for my liking. My brother ordered the rack of lamb, which he enjoyed. My mom ordered the halibut, which I tried, and it was great! My dad ordered the veal shank, which also was great. It was cooked perfect and tender. For dessert we ordered the chocolate flan, tiramisu, and the espresso gelato. The gelato was decent and had good flavor. The chocolate flan was really delicious due to the consistency and bold flavor of chocolate. My favorite dessert was the tiramisu! It was perfect and savory. I loved it. We got to meet the chef, Samuel Hernandez, after our meal! The chef didn't charge us for the desserts and said they were on the house! Overall a great experience!
author: Ismael P.

description:
I really liked Albona Ristorante - its set flush into the city block of Francisco St and it  would be easy to walk by without noticing it.  If you're staying in the Fisherman's Wharf area I highly recommend the short walk over for dinner.

I tried the Caramalized pears with gorgonzola chesse for an appetizer and it was delicious.  The pear was sweet and nicely offset by the cheese.  For my main meal I went with the rack of lamb.  It was perfectly cooked and tasted great.  To drink I had a glass of Cabernet Sauvignon that went great with my meal - and this is coming from primarily a beer-drinker.

Inside, the clientele and ambience is slightly formal but I was welcomed warmly despite wearing a t-shirt.  The wait staff were friendly and helpful throughout.
author: Phil B.

description:
With all the food options in the city, this place is definitely not worth it.  One can get much higher quality food at their prices.  I wanted to try this restaurant because the menu sounded wonderful, but was disappointed.

For appetizer, we shared the "Minestre stagionali," a pretty basic minestrone soup.  It was nice and warm for a cold day, but I could easily put something together from a Campbell's can and it would also be MMM good.  For dinner, I ordered the "Strudel con pasta fatta in casa," which is a pasta and prosciutto baked in bechamel sauce.  Sounds good, right?  It was decent, but not as good as it sounds.  My husband had the "Arosto de coniglio," a braised rabbit dish.  It tasted like braised chicken, which is fine if it was a great braised chicken, but it was not worth $30 we paid for it.  The biggest disappoint was their dessert.  We had the "Crema de gelato," which is supposed to be a gelato mousse.  I like gelato; I like mousse; I have to like this one!  Well, it was like chocolate Cool-Whip, which is acceptable at my kid's birthday parties, but not at an adult restaurant.

Speaking of my kid, I requested a high chair for the little one when I made our reservation.  When we arrived, they told me that they do not have a high chair.  Instead, they gave us a booster chair that swung back and forth on their cushioned seats -- pretty dangerous for a kid.  He ended up sitting on our laps during dinner.  If Albona had informed me that this is not a kid-friendly restaurant when I made my reservation, we would not have brought him.  There are also several fine-dining restaurants in the city that have stable high chairs and are more child-friendly.

1 star off: average food
1 star off: over-priced
1 star off: scary, unstable booster seat that almost made me pee in my pants
author: Ally W.

description: A perfect restaurant.   Split entries, appetizers and pasta's as the portions are very large and then you will be able to sample more dishes.  A secret gem.
author: Angelo D.

description:
One is always a little concerned when a restaurant has been around a while that the menu, staff and decor might be getting a little tired.  Not so here, at least on two out of three counts.

It's a small restaurant - no good for larger groups, but cozy, clean, upscale and romantic.  We found plentiful street parking a block or two away.

They strangely called us and asked us to come a little earlier for our 8:15 reservation made on Urban Spoon, which can be an imposition for those of us coming up from the South Bay.  Nonetheless, traffic was light that Monday and we made it up about 45 minutes early ... it turned out that they were seating plenty of walk-in traffic around 8:15.

Being small ( they had two servers working that night ) the pacing was sometimes slow.  Service, however, was effusively friendly and personal.

They offer beer and wine by the glass or bottle.  A few Croatian wines on the list were offered by the bottle only the night we were there.

The menu is from Istria - a little section of Europe stuck between Slovenia, Italy and Croatia.  Tastes are heavily savory, with strong sweet and sour components.  Though a little saucy and heavy for our tastes, the food is well-prepared and complexly flavored.  The Chifeleti are extremely light balls of fried potato pasta, and probably one of the most interesting things on the menu.  The stuffed calamari appetizer was also very good in an excellent red sauce.   The pasta strudel dish, advertised as one of their specialties, was decent, but somewhat heavy, with familiar flavors.

We had a nicely done rack of lamb and an interesting half rabbit - both large entrees.  For dessert, the Bonet had strong carmelized flavors, and the Crema de Gelato was nice and light, almost like a semifreddo.

Overall, the service, though slow at times, was some of the most effusively welcoming we've seen in the city.  Portions were large, and the food was interesting.
author: Albert H.

description:
I cannot say enough good things about Albona and Chef Sam. We have been back several times since we first found this incredible restaurant last year and it has never disappointed in food, service, and charm.

Our most recent meal was last weeken as a sort of "end of summer" Sunday dinner. The fried gnocchi has become a staple every time we come back and it was just as delicious as always. I had the mussels for an appetizer as well and the were so meaty and tender, it was like tasting the ocean itself.  For entrees, we had the fish of the day king salmon and the filet steak.  Both were amazing as usual.  Dessert consisted of tiramisu and the chocolate flan.  Of the two, I think the flan (the one I picked) is the better option.

What was a delight was that chef Sam recognized us from our multiple visits before and as usual was he extremely genial and funny self. We'll definitely be back again very soon.

Parking protip: even though there is free valet, we always find ample free parking on Bay street which is just one block over.
author: Mercutio k.

description:
I went here with a group of co-workers.  They take reservations and I heard are very nice about it, they don't make it a horrible experience for you it people don't show up.

The service is stellar here.  The food was also fairly good.  I wished there were more options for vegetarians to choose from.  Their soup that night was not veggie friendly.  Also their salads were very limited if you didn't want any meats on them.  For for the main course I believe there were 2 items for me to choose from.  I shared a cheese ravioli with another girl.  It was overall pretty good.  I think my favorite part was the bread and butter.  Yum!  Also how sad at the same time.  LOL.  

But if you are a meat eatter, this place is pretty good.  My friend was very happy with his meal.  So my review is based as a vegetarian.
author: Michelle M.

description:
In a cavalier moment, I might be heard to say that this place is better than Chez Panisse;  it certainly produced the "Wow" moments that never came at Berkeley's famed bistro.  But let's be honest:  Chez Panisse has an epic reputation and the diner goes in with fantastic expectations;  Albona is about as unknown as its facade is unremarkable, and if I had any expectations at all, this close to the tomato-based spaghetti joints of North Beach, they weren't all that great.

Yet let's also note what other Yelpers have:  This place is as expensive as Chez Panisse and any other culinary temple of San Francisco, so those who have noted the expense aren't out of place;  entrees are in the mid to high twenties.

The food was very, very good.  It was closer in character to the tomato rich spaghetti dives nearby, than to Cotogna over in Jackson Square, which is a bit more modern in its take on Tuscany, and we left thinking as we did on leaving Cotogna, what a good meal we had.  I'm not having such moments as often as I'd like, given the expense of dining out.

I'd ordered the braised sauerkraut with onions;  and the sardines with glazed onions, red wine vinegar, golden raisins and pine nuts (served chiled); and for an entree---being utterly uninspired by anything else (which at the moment all looks delicious) the "Strudel con pasta fatta in casa"  ($42. already, and that was just me, without the opening cocktail, and wine).    

The strudel is described as pasta rolls filled with prosciutto and lappi cheese, baked with a crumb crust, bechamel and tomato sauce.  I ordered it more out of curiosity but it was really quite the item.  Mild, rich without overdoing it;   Others had the fish stew, venison, and veal, which was labeled "Stinco de videl a la Triestina"   Strudel and stinco.  How can you go wrong?

We'd stumbled across this place while walking back from the Wharf a few months back and had wanted to go back.  The old post-1906 facade gives no hints, and only has a tiny window.  Inside it's a bit dark, and somewhat fussily comfortable, like a relative's house---gramps came over on the boat.  We were clearly the youngest people there---even with me and the partner having twenty years over our friends.  It was not painfully quiet---which I would hate.  People talked but didn't have to yell to be heard, so the ambience was nice.

To me the place seems a bit old fashioned in appearance and food, without being stale or held back by some dogma of the owner.   It's a lot better than most of the other places in North Beach, and different than Cotogna, different but good.

I'd think this would be a great date place (unless your date has a thing for older people, you shouldn't have to worry about distractions) or for anniversaries.  But don't let the idea of special occasions hold you back. I'd go eat here anytime.

And oh yes, the service was spot on, very friendly without trying to join your party.  Parking is an issue, but why are you driving in North Beach, anyway?  There are garages nearby, don't be so cheap, use one.
author: Paul T.

description:
Albona has been one of my favorite spots in the city for over a decade. Their salads and other starters are incredibly balanced and delicious - recommend the soup of the day or any pasta dish. Any risotto is great to share with a date as a starter or 2nd course. The mains are fantastic - the penne all'arrabiata is a personal favorite with its balance of beautiful San Marzano tomatoes and spicy peppers.

The best part of Albona is not only great food, but amazing and personal service in an intimate atmosphere. All the servers has been incredibly attentive and helpful and I always leave wanting to come back again soon.

Decent wine selection, as well.

Highly recommend!
author: Hannah K.

description: The food was sad. The service - involving what seemed like hordes of people - was clumsy and fussy. I totally don't get it. I would say this is the kind of Italian food I would expect to get in a small town that does not have a vibrant restaurant scene, and that does not know mediocre from great Italian food, so anything goes. And at these prices, it's insane. The fig salad with brie was just OK.  My pasta was fine, but not great: slightly overcooked, without anything to distinguish it. I was at a large table, and only one person, who ordered the salmon, seemed to genuinely enjoy his food. $42/person, without alcohol, for something slightly beneath Italian comfort food.
author: Morris R.

description: The food was great.  The rack of lamb is really juicy and cooked to perfection.  I was looking forward to have the rabbit, but they are out.  I might have to make another go for it.
author: Jitendra S.

description: During the last years I have been to Albona at least 10 times, however, because of my last experiences I decided not to go back, at least for a while. Last Thursday I had dinner at this restaurant for the first time in nearly 2 years. This time it was much better than the last ones. My dinner started with mussles and they were delicious, the bread was very good too. We did not leave even a drop of sauce, we left nothing but the shells. For main course I had chicken breast with maraska cherry sauce and vegetables. It was excellent. My partner had Penne a la arrabbiata, and she enjoyed it too. To finish our dinner we had panna cotta and tiramisu and both were excellent, as good as the main courses and the appetizer. Overall it was a great experience, I am looking forward to the next time at Albona.
author: Stacie P.

description: I visited this restaurant while I was in SF on a business trip. The food is amazing! I will definitely return when I am back in town
author: amy t.

description: My husband and I happened to find this restaurant after consulting my favorite advisor for good food-YELP. I was able to reserve a table for the following evening. Sam greeted us and gave us a rundown on the specials as well as a recommendation for entrees based on my preferences. We ordered the gnocci as an appetizer. It was housemade and so good we could have licked the plate clean. The rolls were amazing, and each of our entrees were expertly prepared. We finished with the chocolate flan which was creamy, smooth and delicious. Our dining experience was excellent and I would happily return here again. Bravo to Eddie our waiter and Sam!
author: Raquelle Z.

description: Quaint and cozy cottage like setting. It's nice to experience something older and hearty. I am all for the modern approaches to food, but having the experience of a small establishment with labor of love is a true happiness. They do the basics right. Warm crusty bread, soft butter. The Beet Tartare was awesome. Risotto could have used a little more seasoning, but was hearty. The tiramisu really hit the spot. I would definitely go again.
author: Irfan D.

description: A nice romantic dinner. Unique flavors, great service. A hidden spot that I will return to for the flavor of Istria.
author: Vicki L.

description: Solid place for dinner. Made reservation on a Saturday night, were seated right away. We had 2 appetizers, 1 pasta dish and we each order an entree. Appetizer were sardine and stuffed calamari, both were great appetizers, highly recommended. Seafood pasta was good, but didn't stand out for me. I had rack of lamb for my entree, perfectly cooked. I normally don't like the taste of lamb but this one somehow hide that strong lamb taste away. Owner/manager was very friendly. The service was just a little bit slow but they course out our order for us well. Overall a great experience. 4.5 star is right.
author: Jimmy R.

description: Great intimate ambiance, really good salmon dish. Rabbit was OK too, I'd say 4 out of 5. Great service, very quiet part of North Beach, away from the not-so-classy strip clubs.
author: Catalin D.

description: Great find. Such a quaint place, off the beaten path, with excellent food. Must try! Brought clients and they were thrilled.Can't recommend it enough.
author: Mitch B.

description:
The food was amazing.  We were blown away by the lamb!  The couple that sat next to us told us that it was their 2nd night in a row dining there.  

The service was also excellent.  Our server was really smiley!
author: Lily T.

description: The food was fresh and served hot.  The potato gnocchi in sirloin glaze was yummy.  Also the arrugula and apple salad was good.  The waiters are gruff. The ambience was old European.  A bit pricey, but what isn't in San Fran?
author: Sarah B.

description: Stuffed pork loin was one of the best meals I have ever had.
author: Lisa B.

description: The people here (mostly Sam) are fabulous. We decided to have our anniversary dinner here based on yelp reviews- and we were not disappointed. We were immediately sat and promptly greeted with complementary wine and a "happy anniversary". They were attentive and kind throughout our meal, and the food was great. I would recommend trying!!!!!
author: Shannon R.

description: Amazing food. Owner will insure you are happy. Did for us.
author: Jason S.

description: I was in SF this past weekend for the Nike Womens half Marathon, I could not stress out of enough how much I loved this place to carb up.  The food was perfectly cooked, the desserts and coffee were yummy!!!! Make reservations, the place is busy.  Food is spectacular and the service they sell is incomparable.  I will visit this place again, no doubt!
author: Elizabeth T.

description:
Unique food dishes that are wonderfully prepared.  The restaurant has a cozy and romantic vibe it.  Last night, the chef came out and introduced himself and told us that he would be personally cooking our food.  

What we ordered:

Chifeleti de mia nona con sugo de carne al cumin 
grandmother's specialty: pan-fried potato gnocchi in 
a brown sirloin sauce laced with cumin- very tasty to start off the night

Calamai al forno con salsa marinara 
squid stuffed with toasted bread crumbs, parsley, and garlic;
roasted in marinara sauce- this was the better of the two appetizers.  I recommend this one.

Strudel con pasta fatta in casa 
fresh pasta roll filled with slices of prosciutto & Lappi cheese; baked in a casserole with toasted bread crumbs, béchamel, & tomato-cream sauce- we were told that this is a unique dish.  Delicious!  I am glad this dish was recommended to us.

Capriolo a la Cacciatora con patate roste 
Venison medallions with golden bell peppers coulis & Kalamata olives.  This dish came out with asparagus spears instead of the bell peppers.  Very good dish.  Medium rare was recommended to us to ensure the meat wasn't tough.  


Sorbetto de fragola-  Strawberry sorbet

It's quality, not quantity here.
author: Brent T.

description:
What a great place.....the owner and chef, Sam, is such a sweetheart. I've eaten here before and it was so good that when they offered a Bloomspot deal, I jumped at the chance to come back. 

One of my favorite things is to stretch out a fabulous dinner over a good bottle of wine and just sit back and relax. Albona is the perfect place to do that! Ordered the crab cake app and it was to die for. Really, it was just like crab chunks in a light dressing. Nothing fried, no breading, so it was pure unadulterated crab. This is how its done, people!

For pasta I got the fried sage and butter raviolis, which where so good I would have licked my plate clean if I wasn't in public. I followed that with the veal shank, which just shredded off the bone. The polenta it was paired with offered just the right amount of creaminess which was perfection with the veal. Dessert was Panna Cotta, which is my fave. Although I was stuffed, I still chowed down!

This is such a great date spot. I promise you, you're wife will be impressed guys! It's intimate and sweet, without being pretencious at all. What a neighborhood gem!
author: Emily M.

description: I was very excited for some good Italian food. Unfortunately, the only good thing I got for my $50 meal was a drinkable glass of wine.  In the city of sourdough bread, they serve tasteless dry rolls with butter.  I asked for olive oil. It tasted like vegetable oil or low quality olive oil for cooking. My arugula salad was drenched with the same rancid oil. My ravioli in brown sage butter sauce turned out to be doughy ravioli sitting in a sea of melted butter. Tasted no brown, no sage.  Left all the rolls uneaten, the salad half uneaten, the ravioli half uneaten.  Worst $50 I've ever spent on a meal.
author: Suzanne K.

description:
Was in town for business and was looking for a place near hotel and found Albona.  Loved the old world feel and the staff was wonderful and helpful when necessary and invisible when not.  Menu was very diverse and food was very good but not great so only gave it 4 stars but liked it enough to send customers there the next night and when back in town would eat there again.

A note to patrons, this is a nice restaurant, showing up in camouflage cargo shorts, ratty tshirts and trucker hats was not appropriate for this place.
author: Alison A.

description: purchases a groupon for this place and was a bit hesitant even though this place has over 4 stars. Most places I've gone to with groupons lately weren't good which is probably why they are giving groupons away. However, this place was delicious we had the mushroom soup, prosecco was great. and the seafood linguini was very good too! Tiramisu was best I've tasted yet! Small restaurant very cozy and charming service. Great place to go to and definitley recommend to anyone!
author: Vicente P.

description: I would highly recommend this location.   Food has tremendous amounts of flavor and my wife and I will be returning again.
author: Cj S.

description:
Great hidden gem that's hard to come by without the word of mouth since it's hidden in the neighborhoods of North Beach. My favorite dish is the Peto de polo a la Maraska. The chicken is so tender and marinated in a unique rich cherry sauce and the cherries just add an extra pop of sweet flavor. The herb risotto that comes with the dish was delish too and perfect to balance out the rich maraska sauce.

I also tried some of the Linguine con granzo e pesse (a seafood pasta), which was very flavorful as well, but I still prefer the chicken due to my sweet tooth. I also heard that the Costolette de aniel (rack of lamb) was excellent as well.

Good sized portions; you walk out stuffed and satisfied after the meal. Great ambiance too, however I didn't appreciate towards the end of our meal our waiter started being less courteous (perhaps it's due to the restaurant becoming more busy, but that's still not a good enough excuse). By the way you cannot use more than 2 credit cards to split the bill. We learned this from our waiter giving us excuses regarding the long hours he works everyday and then that he's too busy to do anything for us at the moment. I mean really, what waiter will actually say that to his customers?
author: Lily A.

description:
I was really excited to check this place out based on the pictures, but they didn't have any of their fish dishes which were really what we were hoping to get :(
Every thing else was quite average I would say. I had the Strudel which was a small but rich dish. It was just ok!
author: Shirin E.

description: So this review is a bit belated, but we went here for a set menu on New Year's Eve. Let me just say, it was the best dine out experience my fiancé and I have ever had!! They truly set the bar high for service and... The FOOD. The combinations of flavours were all very unique and the dishes were extremely well balanced. We had the pleasure of joining them for a 6 course meal. After offering compliments to the chef, he unpretentiously came to the table and fill our water glasses. I had to ask him if the dishes were his work, and his eyes lit up with such happiness and sincerity. He was truly passionate about his work. I would recommend anyone to give this place a try. It was worth every penny!!
author: Jake O.

description:
We purchased a Bloomspot deal for a 4 course meal worth $120. Usually when I use these deals and i show up at the restaurant they are kinda like, "Ugh, they are using a coupon" and we seem to not get their top-notch service. At Albona that never happened and we were welcomed in right away. The main chef even said thank you for using Bloomspot!

We were greeted by the chef who was extremely friendly and very knowledgeable about the food. He was courteous, funny, and a joy to talk to.

We ordered:
Scallops and the filled squid for appetizer
Mussels / Shrimp Pasta to share
Lamb and Assortment of Seafood dish for entree

Everything we got was delicious! I would say the best thing we ate was the mussel pasta! I used the bread to wipe the plate clean. Having that Bloomspot deal totally made the trip worth it. Even without the coupon I would come back and eat here again because of the impeccable service and most of all, FOOD
author: Steven C.

description: Perfect dining experience. We have dined here a number of times over many months. Samuel and his wife are the backbone of the restaurant.  He often  checks on diners after dinner is underway. Extraordinary in any restaurant. The  menu creations are labors of love. The real test is that the restaurant is often sold out. All tables taken. Noise level low. Service great; food delicious. There is no place like this place near this place, so this must be the place. Five stars.
author: Ronald C.

description: Cute little place away from the busier sections of North Beach. Very intimate feeling (I think there were maybe two servers). The dishes had some italian classics but you could really taste the germanic and balkan influences in the dishes. Everything we had was sublime - it includes a dinner Strudel with mozzarella, pear salad with gorgonzola, and an amazing pork loin with pears, apples, plums, and sauerkraut.
author: Scott D.

description:
We had one of the best meals here last night. We eat out a lot and it's rare that my husband raves so much about every course.  The insalata mista may have been the best salad he ever had. The gnocchi was delicious and shared by the four of us.  it's fried and rich so just a few bites was all we needed because we also ordered the crab salad to share. I had the chicken (nice sauce but I ordered it to share and would have had the fresh fish if left to decide on my own). The other three entrees we're pasta and we're delicious. 

In addition to the food the service could not have been better.  My husband is still raving about the great restaurant we found.  

Only caution is the menu is not extensive but had plenty of variety. Even so, one in our party is sensitive to many foods but the kitchen was willing to simplify the pasta to meet her needs.
author: Molly W.

description:
Here we go...
I was excited to go to this place after reading the reviews and the 4 and half stars.
First impression was nice nice menu  great server ( the younger one with a Spanish accent) . He explained to us the specials and part of the menu very professional waiter..now that where it goes bad.
To start we had a mushroom soup and a arugula salad. Soup was tasteless and too much pepper . Salad was very simple arugula with 2 piece a prosciutto and some apple side very basic home salad..
For main course my gf had pork loin .. Terribleeee dish .. Way too much sauce not testy at all sauerkraut   With no flavor andyaelf had the pasta with cheese and bacon ... Note 4 out of 20 for the pasta. As a michelin restaurant the dish was a joke.
Ok maybe  the owner /chef was off that night!!!!(hope for them).
Dessert tiramisu was soso ..
Even the couple next to us ate
20% of their dish and ask for the check without being enthusiasm of there food..  
Well without the great service foe this young guy i would have put 1 star. The las t thing a guy ( older dude) was
Very mean ..
That was
My worse experience in SF..:(
Ok i went from 2 to 4 stars cuz the owner called me to apologizes. He was sick that night and refund our dinner!!!  So i will try again next time i go up in san Fran...
author: Frenchy G.

description:
I thought I had reviewed Albona here on yelp before! 
A couple of weeks ago, we went to celebrate Darling Daughter's birthday. Sam had the night off, bless his heart, but he told our waiter to bring us a bottle of delicious Prosecco. While we sipped our Prosecco, we chose appetizers and entrees. The sauerkraut wrapped in prosciutto and served with sausages was everyone's favorite. Inland Croatia is heavily influenced by Hungary and other Eastern European culinary traditions, so it was a delightful twist on Mediterean cuisines. We loved everything we ate: Ravioli with steak, a "strudel" of pasta, Risotto funghi, and the seafood "stew" that is a more delicate version of Cioppino and then the DDs and I shared an espresso gelato to die for, and an Amaretto chocolate flan I would have fought for. We also tried a new dessert wine, Visciola, which was heavenly.  Every time we go, I can't wait to go back. The service is impeccable and I love an "old San Francisco" look of white linens and waiters in black pants, vests and white shirts. I can't think of anything I don't like. The new owner, Sam, is charming and knowledgeable and just a joy. Go make friends. you won't regret it.
author: Donita S.

description: One of my top choices in SF.  Been many times over several years and never a complaint.  Do book in advance, it's small and popular.
author: foy s.

description:
4.5 star Deliciousness!! 

Appetizer: 
Had scallop (3.5 star) & stuffed squid (3.5 star). 

Was a bit bitter when I realized when they gave us one less scallop and one less squid.. (we saw the table next to us. We had bloomspot but it didnt specify smaller portion - but we had plenty of food overall so wasnt too upset)
Entree:
Had seafood pasta which was a 5 star, veal was okay (and polenta was a bit dry), lamb was a 4 star. 

Dessert: 
Had gelato and chocolate flan. Both delicious. 

Excellent service too!
author: Jen K.

description: Some of the most spectacular food we've eaten in a long time! Each dish with a twist, we've tried 3 appetizers and 2 entrees, 1 meet and 1 pasta dish. One was better than the other! Chef and owner, Sam Hernandez was also our server and the host, so cordial and friendly that we felt as visiting a family who we haven't seen in a while. Even the small size of the restaurant resembled an extended living room-dining room space. There are so many choices to eat in San Francisco, and while we always strive for the new places, we will definitely go back to Sam's and his wife's cuisine, to try more of those incredible dishes, including deserts, which we completely missed out this time, since we were completely stuffed:) If you're close to  Fisherman's Wharf, we recommend that you skip commercial tourists' restaurants, and walk 8 minutes south to Albona, to enjoy some five-star food at a reasonable price.
author: Danijela T.

description: My mom was recommended to visit this place by multiple people so we went when she was in town. Not good. And pricey. So old fashioned too. :-(
author: Kacey A.

description:
I got the Bloomspit deal for this place, and was pleasantly surprised.  Often I find with Bloomspot deals, they say 4-course tasting, and what you end up getting is a miniature sized version of the menu item. Not here - this place let you pick everything right off the menu, and gave you way more food than you could ever eat. 

To start, it is a cozy one room, 13 table place.  The owner/chef/waiter is wonderfully kind, excited to have you visit his restaurant and most helpful with everything. 

We had the muscles and calamari to start, both with marinara - Delicious.  My boyfriend is Italian and quite particular about his marinara sauce.  This hit the spot with both of us.  The muscles were huge and delicious. 

Next we shared the seafood Risotto - quite good. 

For entrees we had the Rabbit and the special fish, which was Wild King Salmon.  The Rabbit was HUGE, literally a half rabbit, with the most delicious sauce.  The Salmon was perfectly cooked with a great rub, sitting in an amazing wine, butter, lemon sauce.  Way to much food, and they were happy to let us take it home for dinner the next night. 

To top everything off we had the Panna Cotta and the Tiramisu.  The picky Italian boyfriend even said the Panna Cotta might be the best he has ever had. The tiramisu was perfectly put together and delicious. 

We will definitely be back :) and I recommend it to anyone!
author: Sarah F.

description: Super duper solid. Wish the bread were better. Also, the service wasn't as attentive in our experience as the reviews warranted. Other than that - the strudel (aka lasagna), the veal shank, the calamari, and the scallops were all divine. And the prices were more reasonable than expected. Nice ambiance - mature, good acoustics, comfortable. Definitely solid. Take your parents for a birthday.
author: Andrew K.

description:
Albona offers promotional deals on Travelzoo and others,  They use creative billing on the discounts.  The final bill includes an 18% grauity on the amount before the discount including tax.  This is not consistent with CA law which only taxes the actual amount of the bill.

So the bottomline is that there is little savings in the ppromotional dinner price since the diccounts are consumed by the math used.

The food is average with generous portions and along with good service.
author: michael c.

description:
I visited Albona to celebrate my 50th birthday.  A group of us were in town that weekend for the Zinfandel festival (ZAP) which just happened to fall on the same day as my 50th.  I wanted a nice place to celebrate that evening with some good friends.  Albona looked like a very interesting choice as the cuisine is a cross between several different types of food which makes it quite unique.  There is heavy influence from Italy which is why I assume it is listed here as Italian.  But even the Italian-style dishes have there own unique twist to them.  There also seems to be heavy influences from Austria/Germany (pork with sauerkraut, lamb stew and rabbit) as well as the Eastern Mediterranean (spices).

I made the reservation a couple of weeks prior to our arrival and the person on the phone was very helpful.  He was very honest with me and told me that it would be difficult for them to seat us at peak time because of the small size of the restaurant.  I had a group of ten people.  We originally made a reservation for 8:00 P.M.  I later called and changed it to 5:00 P.M. which actually worked out better for them.

We arrived about 5 minutes early and were warmly greeted as they were finishing preparing the dining room for the evening.  We were asked to wait a few minutes while they completed setup.  This was only a couple of minutes.  I let them know that we had brought some special wines along to celebrate the evening.  Once they overheard that it was my 50th birthday the waiter told me that he was going to waive the corkage charge for us that evening.  I told him that wasn't necessary but he insisted.  At the end of the meal I offered our waiter some of the wine and he toasted with us.

I had reviewed the menu online and had already decided what I was going to have.  I started with the grilled sardine appetizer which was served with sweet onions, pine nuts and golden raisins (almost like a marmalade).  These were delicious and just set the stage for a remarkably great meal.  My entree selection was the pork tenderloin stuffed with sauerkraut and prosciutto with a side of baked apples and plums and some sauteed red cabbage.  I finished with the apple strudel with cinnamon, pine nuts and golden raisins with a scoop of homemade vanilla ice cream.  They also brought me a panna cotta dessert for my birthday which I shared with the table.

This was one of the best meals that I have ever eaten.  Everyone in the party was very satisfied with their meals.  The service was impeccable.  The entire staff was very friendly and personable.  You could tell that they loved what they were doing and that their hearts were in the preparation of the food.  I don't think that I can possibly recommend this place high enough.  When in San Francisco I will definitely be back.
author: Karl M.

description:
We visited on the advice from friends, so glad we did. From first entering we felt at home. The ambiance, decor and service were wonderful.

We were seated almost immediately and our server explained the menu with professionalism. My wife and I both started with the Insalatina mista salad and Capesante con salsa rosa - sautéed scallops in a wine sauce. Both were excellent choices. AS our entree's I opted for the Veal Shank and my wife ordered the catch of the day, halibut.  Both were served on time and cooked to order, wonderful choices.

The portions were just enough, full but not filling yet alas, no room for desert. Yes, we plan on visiting often.
author: The Spy Who Came To Dinner D.

description: This  place is so tasty. The strudel is to die for. The tiermisu is so good. Excellent service and ambiance. I come back every year.
author: Bryan C.

description: Wonderful intimate italian restaurant.  Samuel was very welcoming, the food was light and delicious and the service was excellent.  A great find!
author: R S.

description: Excellent.!  Food was simply amazing and the service even better.  Exceeded expectations.  Will be back!
author: marc v.

description: Very disappointed. I had the raviolis and my husband had the filet mignon. The salad we shared was nothing more than lettuce with a few strips of prosciutto on it. Nothing special. My raviolis came with two types of sauces. One was butter and was very greasy the other was a dark meat sauce with meat chunks in it which overpowered the pasta. When I called to make reservations the person who answered was very friendly but when we arrived the guy at the door had a sour look on his face and was anything but friendly. When we asked to move because of the draft he seemed annoyed. The leather bench I sat on was torn. There were only 2 parties of 2, ourselves and then a a party of 4 came in. The place was not full so why the annoyance?  Our waiter was nice. The atmosphere was cozy but very dated. We had the pana cotta which was fine, my husband's  wine was fine. He liked his filet but the sides were nothing special. I think for the price they could update a few things. Your first impression of a place is how you are greeted when you walk in and so this left us both cold from the start. Too bad because we were so looking forward to loving this place.
author: Doreen B.

description:
I was in San Fran with my dad for a little bonding before I got married. We went out diving to see great white sharks! After a long day and long shower, we were starving. We walked out of the hotel and I pulled out my handy dandy iPhone with the Yelp app.

I was like this place looks awesome, so we started walking. The place was packed, we said we were from out of town, and it wasn't like it was on our radar or anything, but they said "No no, please wait. We'll make room for you."

We had an incredible meal, amazing service, and the owner (or manager, or someone like that) even stopped by and chatted us up for 5/10 minutes, including the Italian/Croatian background of the place.

I can't wait to go back!
author: Rob G.

description:
Excellent! We had a great dinner and a very enjoyable time here. The owner Samuel was a great host and gave us the best service of any restaurant that I've ever been to. The restaurant is warm and inviting, small but not cramped or loud. Very intimate but good for a small group of friends or a romantic date night.   

I had some friend from NYC in town and wanted to to take them to a unique spot. I'm from a Sicilian family and grew up in New York and usually don't go out for Italian food but Albona is not your run of the mill North Beach restaurant. The Croat/ Slovenian influence makes it a one of a kind dining experience. 

We started out with the stuffed squid, gnocchi, prosciutto with truffle oil over rocket, a large salad and a nice bottle of Croatian white wine. All were excellent.

For entrees I had the the stuffed pork loin which was a nice hardy meal best for cool SF nights and my buddies both had the linguine with seafood. They both thought it was great.

For dessert: We had the tiramasu  and a chocolate parfait. Excellent.

Samuel joined us at the end of the meal and opened up some of the Croatian red wines for us to try. They were unique and I would highly recommend them for something different.  

The bill came and many things that were ordered he did not charge us for, including no corkage  fee for a bottle that we brought. 

Get off the beaten path and check out Albona for a great dinning experience.
author: Jeff D.

description:
We recently rented out Albona for a lunch reception for our wedding and I can't say enough good things about how great this place is!! 
First of all we went there ahead of time to try out their food as regular customers to see if we liked it. Sam, the owner, greeted us and asked us if our visit was a special occasion. We informed him of our reception shopping and he excitedly said he would bring us a little of everything that night so we could begin our menu prep. It was the first time we had been there and we felt welcome and cared for. Not to mention the food was amazing! The whole night all we could say was yum. We left feeling confident we had found the right place for our reception. We settled on a price, created our menu including a wine selection and went on our way.
On the day of the reception Sam did not disappoint! He decorated the tables with flowers, printed out our menu for our 4 course luncheon and his staff was attentive and friendly. Throughout the lunch I looked around the room with each course and all of our guests kept commenting on how good the food was. We chose the arugula salad with apples and prosciutto, the gnocci (is to die for!), the pasta strudel and then for the 4th course our guests chose from either the salmon, veal or chicken with the brandied cherry sauce. I can't wait to take my hubby back. Just writing this review is making me hungry.
One note for you wedding planners, this is not a big venue! We had 25 people and the place could probably only seat a little more than that comfortably. But ask Sam anyway, he is more than helpful.
author: Rana B.

description: From start to finish we had a great dining experience! The food, service and ambiance exceeded our expectations...we'll be going back!!
author: Gail G.

description:
I think this place deserves a 3.6. I was going to give it a 4...but youll see why.

first off, make a reservation. I dont know why you need to on a thursday night, but just make one. =) many people started coming in around 7pm.

this is a really small place. the ambiance and decor is really nice. its perfect for nice family gatherings (quiet) or for dates. =)
service was awesome and very attentive.

ok its food time!
so i got a Strudel con pasta fatta in casa. this is a baked dish and comes with pasta rolls filled with thin slice of prosciutto & lappi cheese covered in bechamel & tomato-cream sauce. it said it has bread crumbs on it..but i didnt taste it. hahaha. the dish looked small, but it was quite filling. i got sick of it after the first half because i normally dont like or eat ham..and all the cheese was a bit overwhelming for me. the sauces and pasta itself were delicious! I felt like i could have make this dish..it wasnt anything special to me. My taste buds are a bit different, but I think the general public would love this dish.

halibut special: the halibut was tasty and cooked just right. it was absolutely amazing . i wish i got that instead of the baked dish. (and halibut is my favorite fish) I can still taste it in my mouth..deeelliicccious! it also comes with steamed veggies. 
Warning: if youre a big eater, i suggest you get something else..this was not enough for my friend.

mushroom risotto was yummy, but i also got sick of it very quickly. my bf and i ended up finishing each other dishes in the end. I am a big fan of mushrooms and it was juicy and tasty! i could have eaten 1 lb of them or more. hahaha. the rice seemed not fully cooked to me..but im so use to asian rice.. it was kind of hard, but i had to chew it to get the full flavor of it.

I dont quite agree with what everyone says. i have had better italian food before, I just wasnt satisfied with Albona. although, i did enjoy their fresh baked breads and their fresh butter!!!! i could have ate those and the mushrooms all night long. hahaha

one more thing to point out....as I was getting change, I was standing near the kitchen. and someone had ordered the biscotti and I saw the waiter take out a pretty, gold box and popped 3 biscottis on a dinky, beautiful plate and served it with elegance. I HATE RESTAURANTS WHO DO THAT. I know the biscottis were probably glorious, but the menu does say HOMEMADE DESSERTS.. not good to cheat your customers.

Warning: if youre a big eater, this place WILL NOT fill you up. 

- a full strudel was 17 
-a full mushroom risotto was 17
- halibut special is probably around 20 something.
( i paid 22 total including tip and tax)

i believe our bill was around 86 dollars.
author: Jen T.

description: From Joe who took my reservations over the phone and greeted us when we arrived to Marco our waiter, my girlfriends and I were charmed by the staff. They were very attentive and the food was delish. If you are looking for an intimate restaurant that has it all - great food, atmosphere and great staff, then this is your place!
author: Vanessa J.

description:
Late is better than never right? I'm so embarrassed, because this was from NYE dinner 2 years ago... Hah!

Anyways, the place was a little difficult to find, mostly because we didn't know what to expect. Outwardly, it didn't look like much. There were small windows, and closed doors, and it honestly looked like it was closed. It didn't really look like any of the restaurants we had ever been to.

The interior was also equally very small, and although at the time I was uncomfortable and I thought "oh, this restaurant must not be doing well" at the beginning of my meal, by the time I left, I was extremely glad that I had reserved the spot. The restaurant has *very* limited seating. I don't think it can seat 100 people, even. Maybe 40 people. By the time we left, the restaurant was almost at maximum capacity, and bustling.

We were greeted by the owner and another waiter, who took my coat to the coatroom, a first for me. We got seated in a very cozy corner (later, we found out that the people who were supposed to sit after us was supposed to be his MOTHER). The menu for the night was a 6 course prix fixe affair, so it took a lot of the guess work out of ordering. However, our waiter, being the owner, was super knowledgeable about EVERYTHING in the menu, and even told us that he's been eating the food since he was very small, so it really reinforced our faith in the food.

We started off with some Prosecco. When we went to draw out our IDs, expecting him to check, he said that he would humor us in looking at them, because, as we saw later throughout the night, the clientele is mostly older people. The Processo: delicious. We went to our amuse bouche: three fried gorgonzola balls. And, as soon as we got them, the owner RAN over to us, and said "EAT IN ONE BITE!" and explained to us that because the middle is liquified, if you bit into it, the innards would gush out and spill over our black shirts. I think he ran over because boyfriend was going to stick his fork in it. It was pretty good, and went well with the Prosecco, as he had said. 

Our next course was a celeriac soup for him, and a salad for me. I guess I wasn't in the mood to really eat a salad; I ordered because I thought I needed to eat some vegetables. The soup was very good, though, and I thoroughly enjoyed the apples in my salad. I also found out that I'm not terribly fond of white truffle viniagrette. 

The third course was a little disappointing, and Alex said that our waiter looked a little sad that I didn't finish mine. I would like to say: I don't like all seafood. I don't eat much seafood. When I eat sushi, I usually eat shrimp, eel, octopus, and salmon. That's it. With that said, I got a chilled crab cake, and he got scallops in a rose sauce. His was delicious, but I found out that night that I don't like scallops after all. I was... not impressed with my crab cake. It was too salty, and I had no idea what the clear gelatin surrounding it was. So, I was a little grossed out, and gave it to Alex to eat, who couldn't bring himself to finish it either. 

At this time, we were getting full really fast. We notified Michael (the owner waiting on us), and he said that he would space us out slower. 

Anyways, we went on to our palette cleanser, which was a mandarine sorbet. So delicious! The owner said that when he was little, he thought it was awesome that restaurants gave two desserts: one before your entree, and one after. I wish I had more.

By that time, we had finished our Prosecco, and got some California white wine, which was so delicious.

We both got filet mignons. Cooked very well. I don't even know what to say about it. The peppercorns didn't bother me. They were very mild and soft! My mouth is juicing up at the memory of the meat, though. That was the second time I had filet mignon, and so far, it's the best I ever had. It was cooked (by default) to medium rare, and the owner had told us that the furthest they want to go is medium, because that would've ruined the cut of meat.

Our last dishes: coffee and dessert. We got a nougat-vanilla ice cream, and a chocolate cream torte. They were both very, very good. The coffee was something that I really needed by that point, because I took some Sudafed at the beginning of the meal to help with my cough and headache. I don't even know what was my favorite, but they both complimented each other and the coffee very nicely. 

Thus, dinner ended. We got the bill, which came out to be $235 after tip. Overall, the meal was excellent, and the service was wonderful. I want to come back and eat here again, maybe on Valentine's Day. 

I do recommend this place. It's on Francisco street between Taylor and Mason (I believe), and open from 5 to 11 PM. Free parking, too! Make sure you make a reservation! It's an overall fun restaurant to dine at, and a very friendly atmosphere.
author: Hayne P.

description:
While under the heading "Italian" don't expect Italian food in the traditional sense.  This restaurant is Istrian, its cuisine is definitely influenced by the location of Albona, overlooking the Istrian peninsula bordered by Italy, Slovenia and Croatia.  But to be clear, the food was delicious, well prepared and our wait staff was attentive.

Albona is located in a neighborhood (and if you google the address, it will take you to the back door, not the front so be prepared for that).  It's a small place, or do we say intimate? But not uncomfortably so.  We started with the Chifeleti de la nona con sugo de carne al cumin ($9.00); which is Grandmother's Speciality, pan fried potato gnocchi in a brown sirloin sauce lace with cumin, delicious and something I've never had before.  We followed with Calamai al forno con salsa marinara ($12.00) a bit expensive for 6 pieces of Squid, stuffed with fish, toasted bread crumbs, parsley & garlic; roasted in marinara sauce, but cooked perfectly.  The squid was so tender.  For our second we had Strudel con pasta fatta in casa ($19.00) easily split between us; Fresh pasta rolls filled with slices of baked prosciutto & Lappi cheese; baked in a casserole with toasted breadcrumbs; béchamel & tomato cream sauce...delish!  (and filling)...so it's a good thing we also split the final Involtin de porco con capuzi garbi e prosuto ($27.00) a beautiful dish of Pork Loin stuffed with braised sauerkraut, prosciutto, apple and plums - see not your typical Italian.  But then I like atypical food.  

The wine list is good with plenty of by the glass choices.  We brought in a bottle and bought two whites by the glass and they waived our corkage - always a nice courtesy.  Of course, we did taste our waiter some of our wine, so that always helps too.  

All in all, a wonderful experience.  And the cable car stops just down the block, so it's very easy to get to.
author: Lindy B.

description: Poor service, poor description of their own menu, and very defensive. A bad start occurred when I was informed they did not have any Croatian wines...not one of the 3 or 4 on the menu. Tomorrow I was told. Second, my wife ordered a pasta dish with brown butter sauce but received a marinara sauce instead. When she questioned our server, he told her she was mistaken and showed her the menu description, which unfortunately for him, said nothing about a red sauce. He apologized but after that he ignored us, turning us over to another server. My dish was OK, the adriatic stew, but I've had better. I was hoping to try the rabbit but they were out of that as well. We visited on Friday, typically the beginning of a busy weekend.
author: Anthony G.

description:
This is an excellent place just a few blocks away from all the touristy North Beach/Columbus Ave crowd. They even have complimentay valet parking, but we found a spot to park without a hassle. 

The sardines were amazing and quite substantial. The carmelized onions on them was fantastic. It was so much that I only ordered the eggplant appetizer. My partner had the pork loins with sauwercraut inside. Amazing! She had way too much, so I had some of her portions. 

The waiter and service was impeccable. And the Italian wine list was good. We had Abruzzo red by the glass and it tasted like a good pinot noir to me. 

They had rabbit on the menu which I will try next time!
author: Ron P.

description: Excellent.  All things we ordered were fantastic including the mussels, gnocchi, lamb, and veal shank.  Perfectly seasoned, delightful sauces - wow.  It's a bit of a haul for us but will try to go back.  The decor is upscale, charming, the atmosphere is pleasant, service is great.  Torn between 4 and 5 stars - only issue is that it's a tad pricey, up against some steep competition in the city for 30+ dollar entrees, and I agree with other diners the dinner rolls were not good (ours was soft, but like someone forgot to add salt to the recipe).
author: Chris F.

description:
Love this place.  Been here numerous times.  Great Croatian - Northern Italian food.  Honestly, the rabbit, when available, is perhaps my favorite dish in SF and we haven't had an off dish yet.

Ad to that super friendly staff, nice quiet atmosphere (you know a place that can actually have a good coherent conversation with your group) and did i mention the FREE VALET parking. In SF that's as good as gold!  All this makes this place a oasis in the North Beach Italian scene.
author: Zack S.

description: Great restaurant. Calm atmosphere and unlike most other restaurants in SF, they aren't trying to hard and are instead sticking to authentic menu items made well. Great service and ambiance.
author: Lilea E.

description: Just ate at Albona again after five long years. And was re-wowed. Sam's taken the full spirit and love that Bruno birthed this place with and has made it shine. One of the very best meals and experience in a restaurant that I've had in years.
author: lance l.

description: One of my favourite restaurants in San Francisco. I had the crab salad and the braised veal shank. Both were executed to perfection, the ingredients were fresh, and  they just tasted delicious. This small restaurant is highly underrated in the Bay Area food scene. The ambiance is intimate and romantic because of its small size and peaceful surrounding environment. The service was good and the prices were reasonable.
author: Eric Y.

description: Would highly recommend this place.  Feels very off the beaten path but really packs service and quality nicely.  Their food is perfectly prepared while not being stuffy.  Don't be alarmed if the small restaurant isn't packed with patrons; just relax and enjoy the attentive service and excellent food.  The Panna Cotta capped the night off perfectly.  Some of the best I've ever had.
author: Blaine W.

description: The servers were very friendly and attentive. The food was also very good. As an appetizer we ordered the mussles, they were the best I've had in SF. The rack of lamb is to die for. I had the bonet for desert, a cholate flan, if you like chocolate you have to have one, very rich but delicious. over all the whole dinning experience was spectacular.
author: Jim G.

description:
I don't eat much Italian.  I had a deal here (I can't keep track the companies anymore) that expired and Albona still graciously accepted it. The staff are polite and charming; they were warm without doing that overly fake Italian socializing that they like to do on Columbus.  I seriously wonder if the hosts at those restaurants are drunk out of their minds.  

We had a bunch of dishes that I now can't recall, all of them pretty good, but the strudel con pasta fatta in casa was definitely the highlight.

I've had better Italian food, yes, but overall I liked this place.  It was cute.  So I'm giving them five stars.

P.S. Free valet parking!
author: Erika C.

description: Everyone loves Italian, but why waste your money to go to this place. Food was too salty and there was nothing special about this place.
author: Ryan M.

description:
This place is Istrian, meaning it was originally part of the Venetian Empire. Not your traditional Italian place; in fact, it's now part of Croatia, I believe.

History/Geography lesson on the menu!

Complimentary valet parking, most civilized. They will put your car on the sidewalk for you!

Food was good; portion sizes perfect, in my opinion. Attentive but not overbearing service. Everything was tasty, no complaints.
author: Edward C.

description: Had dinner at Albona a couple of weeks ago after  a hiatus of about a year.  I have been going here since Bruno Viscovi (now retired) ran it [favorite quote: "No vertical food!"]  It continues to be excellent.  2 recommendations: the chifeletti (deep fried gnocchi with stunning sauce) and the rabbit (equally great sauce.)  Try the Croatian wines.  Nice people, cozy ambience, (usually) pleasant and civilized diners at other tables.  The prices are very reasonable for the quality.  This is what a good neighborhood restaurant ought to be.  Not everything needs to be a Temple of Gastronomy.
author: Daniel M.

description:
It's been 3 months since we visited San Francisco from Dallas and had to go back to our newest find among the great restaurants of this great city,  Albona's didn't disappoint.  We celebrated my milestone birthday and our gracious host made it a very special evening.  Yes, as has been discussed here many times, the gnocci is unlike any you've had before.  Tender in a great brown sauce.  The osso buca and rack of lamb were succulent (don't use that word too often), fall off the bone tender, with memorable flavor.  Service is above average, prices are really reasonable for the quality and size of the portions, and you still need to keep room for the wonderful desserts.  Strudel and gelato were two of the best.  

Looking forward to our next trip to SF already and, of course, to Albona.
author: Wylie P.

description: I had my wedding reception for 20 guests here and we rented out the whole place for an entire Thursday night. When I called and left a message about wanting to have an wedding reception, the owner, Sam, called back and invited both me and my fiance for dinner on the house. He suggested a few simple course menus and we were able to pick from several appetizers to 4 different options of main course. They were very accommodating and friendly. My friend and her husband, who both get to be wined and dined by fabulous restaurants, totally raved about this place the next day. They were thoughtful to provide additional flowers to boost my center pieces we brought in. We were very pleased and feel like we spent our money wisely.
author: Ellen W.

description: Very good Italian food. I'm giving them 4 instead of 5 stars only because their menu feels a bit small and the place feels really packed. Overpriced as every other Italian restaurant in San Francisco
author: Igor P.

description:
This place is a hidden gem!  It is nestled in between houses in a residential neighborhood.  The inside was small, but this lent to its charming and cozy vibe.

The food was amazing!  I had pan fried chicken, broccoli, and mashed potatoes with a lemon caper sauce.  After dinner, the chef brought out complimentary strawberry sorbet that they make in house.  It was delicious as well.  Service was prompt, courteous, and very attentive.  When I'm in the city (near the Wharf), I would definitely come back.
author: Danielle D.

description: The food was pretty good. Busy restaurant but the service is great. Prices are fare for the quantity of food on your plate.  I really enjoyed my experience here.
author: Tristan Greg U.

description: We had friends visiting from out of state and decided to try Albona on a Saturday night.  It was fantastic.  Food, wine, and service was great.  Definitely will go back.
author: Ken E.

description:
Five stars for being the best Italian restaurant in Fisherman's Wharf!  Complimentary valet parking upon arrival with the gentlemen wearing a white coat.  Intimate clean restaurant with white linens, flowers and freshly printed menus. 

The specials of the evening were eloquently described in detail which that night were the soup and fish entrée.  Both were excellent.  

For the appetizer we shared the Calamari and Scallops.  The Calamai al forno con salsa marinara is squid stuffed with toasted bread crumbs, parsley, and garlic; roasted in marinara sauce.  The Capesante con salsa rosa is Day-boat Scallops sauteed, Butter, shallots & sparkling Dry Rose.  Both cooked to perfect temperature and flavorful. 

We were a party of six, and ordered almost every entree on the menu.  Every dish was hearty and delicious.  

I highly recommend dining here, esp if you have out of town guest staying in Fisherman's Wharf.
author: HY L.

description:
I was looking for a special place in San Francisco to celebrate Valentine's Day which happens to be also my girlfriend birthday. After a long research on the internet I came across this place. Here is my review:

I love the comfortable ambiance, the staff is very polite and the chef sometimes comes out of the kitchen to make sure everything is fine. I love that they have a few wines from the north east of Italy like the italian Pinot Noir (or Pinot Nero) which is much lighter than the Californian version. Perfect pair with chicken or even seafood. Try the scallops appetizer and don't miss the Panna Cotta for dessert, so far the best I've ever had!! Yummy! 

If I lived in SF I'd be a regular!!
author: Val J.

description:
Highly recommend this restaurant if you would like an elegant yet friendly & relaxed environment to enjoy gourmet Italian food. We were warmly welcomed by all the staff and their service was impeccable. For food, I would recommend the pan-fried 
gnocchi as an appetizer and ravioli stuffed with cheese, pine nuts, and golden raisins covered in a sage butter sauce for your entree. Yum!
author: Kalynda G.

description:
Loved everything about this place!

We had rugola salad with prosciutto and scallops for appetizers. Both are really good esp. scallops. Ravioli stuffed with three cheeses and braised rabbit as en entrees. Everything was delicius!
Also, their pana cotta is amazing! 

The owner was extremly nice!
author: ana m.

description:
Great neighborhood restaurant, highly recommended especially if you're not in the mood for the flashy, hipster scene. Service was amazing. I had the veal Shank, it was fantastic! The pasta strudel was out of this world. 

One warning... If you go there by cab, call for one to retrieve you when finished dining. Don't expect any to be driving by to pick you up.
author: Maven V.

description:
I'd have given it 3.5 stars if I could.

The place had a warm, welcoming vibe.  Food and service were both up to par.  We had the lamb and the rabbit - slightly unusual, but it did taste like chicken.  

The orange vanilla creme brulee suffered from an overly zealous dose of both sugar and the color "orange".  In my mind, creme brulee should be somewhat understated and subtle, but it was neither.
author: Kristen S.

description:
One of the best meals of my life.  Period.  The food was northern Italian, but something very very special.  The chef graciously guided the four of us through the menu, and made sure we had the most delicious options at every turn.

For appetizers, we had the scallops (perfectly done and in an amazing sauce), the gnocchi (savory and delicious), the stuffed squid (good, but out-shined by the other dishes), and the sardines (which tasted very much like herring, but much less pungent).  The scallops and gnocchi were both very impressive. We paired this with a Croatian white wine the waiter was nice enough to open and let us taste before deciding to order. At this point, we were already so impressed by the service and the food we could have all walked away satisfied.

But when the main courses arrived, Albona elevated itself to something truly unique and unforgettable.  I had the rabbit, which was one of the most juicy and flavorful rabbit preparations I've ever had.  Everyone around the table had a taste, and everyone was blown away.  We also ordered the chicken - succulent, and juicy, and served with the most amazing cherries (left in cognac for 3 months!).  The pork with sauerkraut  was impressive, but the best dish by far was the lamb.  Lamb rib, loin, and sausage, each prepared with such care, the whole table was overwhelmed.  The loin in particular was as good as any steak I've ever had.

After so much deliciousness, there was no way we wouldn't try the desserts.  We ordered two, but the chef insisted on bringing us four - and with good reason.  We ordered the tiramisu and the apple pie, which were both very good, but the dark-chocolate flan with cherries, and panna cotta he brought us were both absolutely out-of-this-world!  I'd recommend you stay light on the appetizers, and make sure to leave room for these two desserts.

I simply cannot praise this restaurant enough.  Go.  Go now.  Bon appetit!
author: Josh L.

description: Food and device were excellent. We had the gnocchi and stuffed skid for appetizers which was very good. I had the mushroom Rissolo which was excellent and my son had The strudel pasta which was also excellent.  I had the Apple strudel for desert which was very disappointing   Overall great experience!
author: Clayton A.

description: Excellent service.  Food was very good, although my dish (rabbit) was a bit sweet.  Good wine list.  Enjoyable.
author: Dave S.

description:
Yelp-o-licious.

A gem in an area better known for it's touristy restaurants and crap-tacular hotels. The benefits of patronizing a family-run business came through from the moment we arrived. After giving our car to the free valet, the owner's nephew welcomed us in, joking warmly as we waited for our other guests to arrive.

Bruno the owner was there, making a point of stopping at each table and chatting freely with all his patrons, old school. The entire staff had a great attitude, from the servers to the bussers. 

So they win on personality, but food? A hit there too. I started with the stuffed calamari which I definitely recommend. The sauce was so delicious my plate had nothing left when they took it away. For my main course I chose the lamb, again awesome. Given how wonderful my appetizer and entree were I had to spring for dessert and indeed the apple strudel was well worth the calories.

Atmosphere-wise it's obviously not a trendy spot, but the perfect place for a dinner when the parents are in town. Between casual and dressy it's somewhere in the middle. Typical patron was 40s and up, also the restaurant is small so make sure you call ahead.

So there you have it, a real winner. Can't wait for an excuse to go again.
author: Jeremy S.

description:
Real nice place and Sam the owner seated us and explained his business to us
Small, fair priced for san fran and we would go there again
author: Steve S.

description: A delicious dinner. This place is unique and special and must be experienced! The gnocchi appetizer was light and flavorful, the pork dish was incredibly tasty and the mushroom risotto lived up to its reputation. A lovely, little taste of Europe.
author: Marc O.

description: The food was very bland the rabbit that I had was absolutely disgusting unfortunately this place is really overrated the staff is nice the place is really small and cute but unfortunately the plate that I had the playpen my wife had to play that my father had were used to eating at really nice Italian places in this definitely is not one of them really regret coming
author: T t.

description: This place was great. I had rabbit with polenta... It was to die for. The sauce was excellent. The place is good food but it isn't pretentious. To top it all off..... A chocolate flan :)
author: Ryan M.

description:
This place is a hidden gem in North Beach.  I'd walked by many times and barely noticed it.

The decor on the inside is off but everything else makes up for it many times over.  The food and service were fantastic and the prices were fair.  I highly recommend the rabbit.
author: Raja B.

description:
I wish I could give this place 10 stars. Orgasmic food.  Amazing service.

The food alone would make this restaurant worth five stars, but what makes this place extra special is the service.  In fact, I just go back from celebrating my husband's law school graduation and wanted to write a review right away.

The place is small and the atmosphere is intimate.  It is off the main tourist-y part of  Columbus.  Plus, free valet parking in North Beach.

Our group had the lamb, pork, fish of the day, the pasta, soup, etc.  It was absolutely delicious.  My dad is from former Yugoslavia and when he found out that the Istrian he went to to ask the staff if anyone was croatian ( he wasn't)  The chef is the second owner.  He was so friendly and kind.  He really went all out.  The chef came out and personally checked on us and served us.  They gave us complimentary servings of  the arugula, mushroom, and apple salad.  He also  brought us dessert on the house when he found out that we were celebrating my husband's graduation.  It really made the whole experience memorable.

Dishes are 20-30 a plate, but the food and service are well worth it.  I would go back again in a heartbeat.
author: Olivera J.

description:
Rave reviews for Bruno and family who operate this lovely gem of a restaurant decorated like a simple European country inn tucked away on a residential street in North Beach off the main strip.

My sea bass was served  luxuriating in the most wonderful sauce!  The calamari appetizer had already arrived in a tasty  marinara sauce with our lovely red wine. Others at the table were thrilled with their lamb entree and gnocchi appetizer.  

With dining space limited, reservations are an imperative. Valet service was free on Saturday night. 

As is customary, Bruno, the owner/raconteur made an appearance to recount historic information about the cuisine, compliment the ladies and personally oversee the ordering of our desserts.  I would recommend the chocolate torte made with ricotta cheese in a biscotti crust.

This is one of those rare, family-run restaurants where the meals served are as memorable as the warmth of the dining experience.  I would not miss it.  Many a fancier place has not left as great an impression.
author: Lynn S.

description:
ate hear last night; cant believe Ive been missing this place all the time Ive lived in SF! dont make the same mistake! 

food: amazing
service: amazing (but a little slow due to the food being made to order and them wanting to get it perfect)
ambiance: pleasant, quiet and clean
overall: home run

Eddie the waiter and Samuel the cook both made sure everything was perfect last night (and, no, I didnt know them before last night)

our party tried the following:

APPS:
green salad: more than you normally; and for $6 there was plenty
soup of the day: 3 kinds of mushroom, proscuitto, peppers, chicken stock - pureed w/out milk/cream - how could it be so rich!!!
squid stuffed w/ fish/bread crumbs w/ spicy tomato sauce: you HAVE to try this (but be warned though worth it this serving is expensive/on the smaller side)
mussels: giant plate of deliciousness in light tomato sauce; and I am not a huge mussel fan
veggies in oil: eggplant, peppers, celery, pine nuts, etc. - great for bread

MAINS:
fish of the day: FRESH, 6 oz+ serving, expertly prepared
seafood stew: not your typical ciopinnno, but a Croatian take on this dish - came w/ 3 giant prawns, 6 small scallops, 10 mussels, 3 oz fish and some calamari to boot
veil shank: only main/app I did not try on this review but my aunt was chewing on the bone it was so good (and maybe why I didnt try it LOL)

DESERTS:
Im lactose intolerant, but I can tell you that people wolfed down 2 bonets and a giant apple struddel after the above giant meal

you should DEFINITELY check this place out - its worth every penny and then some; I will certainly be going back
author: Mark B.

description:
I had been looking forward to a visit to Albona for months.  We finally decided that this would be the perfect date night cure to a busy work week and catch up after busy travel schedules had kept us apart.

My boyfriend and I had a reservation for 7pm on a Thursday. Upon arrival, we were sat promptly and given menus. No server announced themselves or came to tell us about the specials. Eventually, someone noticed our menu stack and came to take our order and bring our wine. 

The first course was pan fried gnocchi in a sirloin sauce. To me, the potato tasted burnt. The sauce was very salty. Someone arrived with some bread. There was a really obnoxiously loud table of 8 behind us which made it hard to hear each other.

Before we'd made it to course #2, the waiter who had taken our order slammed headlong into the corner of our table next to my boyfriend, completely up-ending the flat top on a diagonal. The bottle of wine fell, spilled towards me, and began dumping onto me and the booth side I was sitting in. The table cloth was soaked in red wine and I was trying to save my new dress. The kind gentleman next to us was our savior here - he caught the wine bottle, helped us upright the table, and suggested we slide over to his table, as he and his wife were leaving for the theatre.

The server was less than helpful and certainly far from apologetic! I was dabbing my dress with water to try and get the red wine out - now at the theatre couple's table, still sitting in front of their old bread, water, and crumbs...and a second server brings course #2 and just plops it down in the middle of the mess! No cutlery, no water,no napkins, half our wine is in the booth next to me or on the floor. No apologies.

No offer to replace the wine. We did get new bread, napkins and water. We never got new bread plates. We're not the types to want white glove service and people dotting on us to catch out crumbs. We didn't make a fuss or make high demands and we were still hoping the food would be the thing to make the evening.

Course #2 was the pasta strudel, which had a nice combination of tomato, bechamel cream sauce, pasta, ham, but was a bit soupy - difficult to enjoy at this point.

Course #3 took a while to come. We ordered the $29 seafood stew special and it was completely disappointing. It came with mostly rings of calamari, 4 overcooked mussels, half a scallop (a total sliver that was not even shareable), a couple chunks of what they claimed was seabass but tasted like overcooked halibut. The sauce was really rich in a way that did not pair well with the seafood and it was so over-seasoned it tasted like someone had dumped a bouillon cube and a bunch of salt in some half-and-half and poured it over the seafood.
