At the end, the waiter brought over an open bottle of wine and tried to offer to top us up...as if this would right the evening. No thanks.

We got tiramisu to go - because we just wanted to go home at this point, but we still had hopes that something would be good at a restaurant like Albona that has a surprising history of good reviews.

I worked at a nice Italian place years ago and if something like this ever happened to a customer, we would have comped their whole meal. All-together, we still paid $80 for a partially comped stressful, unsatisfying meal with crass, cranky service. My boyfriend is such a sweetheart he still left a good tip on top of this. We ate a bite of the tiramisu when we got home. It was a small, dry sliver of cake: a sad, stale end to the evening.
author: Lindsay M.

description: Make sure to get a reservation. The restaurant is small and quaint and the food is excellent. The waiter steered me to excellent choices, veal shank and dark chocolate flan. My husband had a pasta dish with shrimp and mussels and said it was delicious. We will go back!
author: Ann H.

description: Small and cozy place off the beaten path. Really good food. Wait staff inflexible but timely. Limited wine by the glass. Limited beer selection and bottle only.
author: Shannon G.

description:
This is my favorite restaurant in San Francisco!!! Every time we go to Albona we are treated like royalty.  The staff is friendly and helpful.  The food is delicious.   Every dish has a wonderful twist to it, that sends your taste buds on a roll coaster ride.  I actually hesitate to write this review for fear that Albona will become to popular.  The restaurant setting is quaint and charming.  

And don't forget dessert!!!   Panna Cotta is my favorite.
author: Greg N.

description:
Mmm. I had an amazing dinner here.

I ordered the rabbit, which was very tender. The sauce was a bit sweet for me, even though I like a mix of savory and sweet. The polenta was good and creamy.

My cousin got the strudel pasta. She really enjoyed it, but the serving was a bit smaller than expected. They gave a great wine recommendation for the pasta, seeing as I dont drink.

We also got the dessert-- the sorbet trio. It came with peach (yum!) dark chocolate (i just dont like dark chocolate but it was pretty good) and strawberry (this one tasted like strawberry slices sitting in syrup that some places use in smoothies or shakes.)

We came on a wednesday night, and the restaurant had only a few other people there. Its rather dim inside, and seems to cater to an older crowd. However the food here is really good, and is worth a try no matter your age. And with free valet parking, you have no excuses. :) I will come here again in the future.
author: Alison A.

description: Here's great. Food is "clean, fresh, delicious"Also service is good. Price is okay. One of my fvorite italian restaurant in san francisco. Hope they keep the three of them "clean, fresh, delicious" so that I can keep going there!
author: Hoyeon L.

description:
Samuel is a magnificent chef and the entire crew provided an exquisite dining experience for my girlfriend an me. We were treated to delightful surprises throughout the meal as we were there in celebration. Perhaps they fed of our energy. 
A glass of champagne, an appetizer of the chefs creation, what I thought was cioppino  but I'm told was something else but full of seafood, fragmented sentences, and capped off with my first encounter with panna cotta. 
Even still, I was eyeing the rabbit, gnocchi, and risottos gracing the neighbors table. I'll have to go back. 
Oh and the mushroom soup I've been searching for!? I've found it. I know it's not at the top of your list but if you like to get down, get down with that!
author: Brett R.

description:
This is a delightful find.  A real gem, which I never would have discovered without Yelp :-)

I had dinner here on Friday night and the place was abuzz.  The Prosecco was great and a good way to start the evening.  We both ordered the small prosciutto salad with truffle oil.  Initially, it didn't look like it had any vegetables but the greens and apple were great.   

We also had the special catch of the day, which was super tasty.  The food is a bit rich so just prepare yourself.  We ended up shutting down the place :-)

They also have Valet ...
author: Ayelet B.

description:
What a FANTABULISTIC find!!!!

Amazing food and warm service by Chef Sam that blew us away.
One great dish after another with splendid service and ambience. We tried the carmelized figs with Fontina cheese. Was Perbacco!

My mushroom ravioli with truffle was very good as an entree and the guy blissfully savored every morsel on his lamb dish. Dessert (panna cotta) was allright, we thought it was a little too creamy and we've had better.

In all, a wonderful evening, cant wait to go again!
author: Shwetha R.

description: Ate there last night after not having been for a few years. Happy to report that the food was as fantastic as I remembered! Don't miss the stuffed calamari! The ravioli were sensational, and I loved my lamb shank as well. Service was excellent, very attentive. The atmosphere is rather plain, but pleasant.
author: Ken M.

description:
Wonderful. Beautifully prepared food, tasteful dining room, cozy and very friendly. No bone marrow, no pork belly, no foam, nothing out of a squirt bottle. Nothing cooked in a plastic pouch. No celebrity chef! Yay.

Try the Croatian wine. 

Had the sauerkraut and sausage appetizer, lamb main course and strudel dessert - everything, down to the ice cream on the strudel was home made.
author: Ben C.

description:
The food was absolutely amazing. I had never tasted such a succulent filet mignon. It almost tasted like a beef version of Prosciutto. It was AMAZING.

 The restaurant atmosphere was cozy with tables pretty close to eachother. The chef came out and served most of the dishes and was very friendly and easy to approach (he even fufilled a special request by another table to make calamari!).

 The desserts were homemade and the chocolate tarte was to die for, as it had hazelnuts cooked into the cake. YUM. 

Collectively my group ordered all the menu dishes and each and every one did not disappoint. Bravo! I will most definitely come back again.
author: Lilly D.

description: Chef Sam was a terrific host!  He took great care of us and the food was outstanding.  I started off with the mussels for an appetizer.  The sauce had plenty of flavor and went well with the homemade, fresh out the oven, warm bread.  My pasta dish was perfect as well.  I will be back here for sure on my next visit to San Fran!  Many thanks to Chef Sam and his wife for a wonderful meal.
author: Bob T.

description:
This place was fabulous!  Ate there this evening and enjoyed every moment.  

Sam (the chef) and Eddie (our waiter), were sweet and attentive.  They offered suggestions when requested and were very concerned with how we were enjoying the meal.

The ambience was very nice and intimate.  The restaurant was quiet (even when full) and it was easy to have a conversation.

I agree with the previous reviewer- the food was amazing!  We had the soup of the day (tomato), the small insalata mista, the strudel con pasta fatta in casa and the costolette de Aniel.  The soup was delicious with a rich, deep taste. The salad was very fresh and light; a good size for one person as an appetizer.  The strudel was great- served piping hot from the oven and surprisingly light. My husband devoured his lamb- he barely restrained himself from gnawing on the bones!  It just melted in your mouth.  I could go on and on about the meal, one of the best we've ever had.

We will definitely be going back soon!
author: Amanda H.

description:
I was very excited to try a new Italian restaurant on Saturday but it turned out to be a big disappointment.  
Here are some reasons:  
Waitress brought the wrong wine first but apologized and brought the right one. She didn't pour the wine during the meal, not even once.  
Gnocchi that was recommended by many but tasted like mashed potatoes.  
Pork loin stuffed with sauerkraut which was recommended by the waitress as one of their signature dish was so dry I was only able to eat maybe 1/4th.  

Our waitress and the chef never came by to ask how the meal was and didn't get any attention when the table was cleared with most of my food untouched.   But the chef managed to visit and chat with customers around our table.

They also set another couple next to us when the restaurant at the time had many open tables.  One of the couple kept coughing through out the dinner which didn't help with the entire unpleasant experience.
author: J K.

description:
A surprisingly small restaurant north of the North Beach/Columbus Ave. area.  Serves Italian dishes from an area of Northern Italy that borders Croatia and has some Germanic influences.  The dishes were all very tasty and the service was first rate.  

The best part about this restaurant is the free complementary valet parking!  Unheard of!  

The history of the restaurant is printed on the back of the menus.  The original owner and chef from Istriano finally retired and sold the restaurant to his executive chef.
author: Doctor G.

description: The food and the ambiance were amazing -- the complex nature of the flavor of the two dishes I had was enhanced by the fact that the food wasn't heavy. My guest said the fish of the day (salmon) was the most amazing dish she'd ever enjoyed. Loved the place and recommend to others looking for something unexpected and unique in The City.
author: David S.

description:
Wow what can I say other then bravo.

We made reservation through open table and got seated early
The place is very small and cute so reservation are a must.
Our waiter (who later we found was co-owner) was fantastic!! 
I enoyed the nice atomosphere and pleasent service

I had the lamb and it was amazing! My friend has the seafood alfredo and also was great
The tomato soup there is amazing!

There is really no complaint...flawless dinner. Check this place out its perfect for a date and the food is amazing...will go again soon!
author: Eric S.

description:
YOU HAVE TO GO HERE IF YOU ARE IN SF!!!

This place is one of the nicest dining experiences I have ever had. I went here for valentine's day with my boyfriend and we had the time of our lives. The food was exquisite and it even came with unlimited high class wine imported from italy and france (aka not house wine!!) They even surprised us with hand made heart shaped gnocchi as a starter which was such a nice touch for the holiday. Bruno the owner met every single person in this small intimate restaurant. You can't even tell from the outside that an amazing dining life lies within this place, but trust me you will not be disappointed with your experience here. The ravioli was prepared perfectly and the staff even worked with me boyfriend when he surprised me with a gift at dessert!! If you go say hi to Bruno!!!
author: Sarah G.

description:
I love visiting San Francisco. I love my fellow yelpers who do not lead me astray. Twice now I wanted to try a great italian restaurant and twice my yelp community have guided me down the right path. This time it's through the small door of the Albona Ristorante. It's a tiny place with staff that love what they do.

We started off with grandmother's famous fried gnocchi with gravy - 4 little bites and it was gone! So good.

Then the salad special of the night - fig with brie and some greens. THE BEST SALAD EVER! I just hope one day I can have it again.

Dinner comprised of the Strudel con pasta fatta in casa - fresh made pasta pinwheeled with prosciutto. Every bite melts in your mouth! So delish! And the Pollo impana con salsa de capori was delicious too. But as the veal shank passed by I was wondering, "should we have ordered that instead?" The conclusion - we have to come back and order that and try the other things on the menu!

Dessert was a chocolate flan - very yummy and it was accompanied by the best cafe latte ever!!

A restaurant for us only gets 5 stars when everything, everything is good. From start to finish this place rocked!!
author: Mariver C.

description:
Very good food. 

Terrific service.  My party arrived very late, but the chef and staff stayed to accommodate us; they even showered us with numerous on-the-house appetizers.
author: Ian S.

description:
We strolled in here quite drunk from the Napa vs Sonoma wine tasting which was scant on food.

There was one other group in the restaurant, but the place was nicely insulated from all sound.

Our waiter gave us honest suggestions and a quick overview of what the restaurant was known for.

We ordered the fried gnocchi, fish stuffed squid, marinated sardines, and the funghi risotto.

The gnocchi were perfectly done, not over-fried at all.  The sirloin sauce went so well with them as well.

The fish-stuffed squid was perfect as well.  Tender and flavorful.

These two dishes set the bar high.  The natural sardine flavor was masked too much by the marinade.  This doesnt mean they did the dish wrong or anything, it just wasn't to my preference.  The quality of the fish was great.

The risotto was a nice way to round out the meal.  I think more of the mushroom flavor could have gotten into the rice.
author: H C.

description:
We decided, on short notice, just to try something different from the normal places we go to when in The City.  Altona was just down the street from out hotel and looked like the right kind of atmosphere.

We arrived and we're seated within minutes (on a Friday night, too) sin reservations.   The scent of fresh capers and deliciousness was just enough to get the nose interested,  but not overbearing.  I am relatively picky, and while the menu was different, it still offered several attractive options.  I settled, rather quickly, on the strudel con pasta.  My girlfriend immediately jumped at the salmon in garlic/caper/butter sauce.

Both meals were delicious!!! The salmon was cooked  quite well but the sauce was a bit overpowered with the caper flavor. The strudel con pasta was frickin' amazing.  The sauce was creamy but not thick and the pasta was tender; both in great combination with the prosciutto.

The waiter made good on his suggestion of a white wine to go with our meal.  The wine wist was small, but so is the establishment. The waiters were very pleasant but not overbearing and the manager was very kind.

One drawback was the noise.  One table, centered in the room, was a little on the boisterous side, which was not the fault of the restaurant, but hearing a lady who was probably about a .20% BAC started off as entertaining but quickly got annoying.

All in all,  a very pleasant experience at a nice little restaurant.  It's not my favorite ST restaurant but it's worthy of a visit for a (mostly) quiet, quaint dining experience.
author: Joe A.

description: Big fan of this spot. Was easy to get a reservation here - maybe because its so close to Tourist-landia? Very good food. We had the arugala salad, gnocchi app, and penne arrabiata. Everything was very good - gnocchi was more like a potato-tater-tot...still delicious but not what you traditionally think of as gnocchi. Skip that, and try another app. Overall, great atmosphere, great service, great authentic italian food.
author: Sean S.

description: My rating is more like a 3.5 but I always round up on the first visit. I am going to take exception with the five star rating the food ranged from good to great., the service was solid and the ambience was okay. I do agree with the fairly critical review that said the ravioli was dry. It was tasty, but was dryer than I am use to and resulted in my rating my food average. My wife however raved about the halibut and I did enjoy the tiramisu.
author: Gregg S.

description: This is our favorite San Francisco restaurant.  Great food - a blend of Italian and Croatian.  The service is also terrific.  Highly revcommended!
author: Mike W.

description: I can't say enough nice things about this place. We have gone two years in a row for our anniversary and its been such a wonderful romantic dining experience. They really do all the little things to make you experience special and memorable. Everything we have had is delicious, and we love how they are willing to tell you how everything is prepared when you order to help you decide. Looking forward to many more anniversaries at Albona.
author: K A.

description: Awesome food. Got stood up by allegro Romano down the street. It was my bf and my 3 anniversary. Long story short, we had to walk around San Francisco to find a place to eat and got turned down everywhere because they were all full. (Can't blame them it was a Saturday night). We finally stumbled upon this place and the owner or manager was extremely nice and made a table for us and even checked in on us a couple of times throughout dinner. The food was delicious, and the staff was super friendly. Will have to come back!
author: A B.

description: Thank you, Yelp for helping us find the perfect dinning experience.  From Sam Hernandez, the owner, to our waiters Joe and Marco we thank you for creating an extraordinary and intimate dinning experience.  Our waiters were attentive and the menu offered great choices with unbelievable flavors.  Great food and staff.
author: Bob C.

description:
Food:  I had the catch of the day - sea bass.  Incredible texture and fullness and weight to the fish in your mouth.  Exquisitely prepared.  The hubs had the braised rabbit and I ended up guiltily enjoying Thumper after we traded dishes half-way through.  Rugula salad with truffle oil was a wonderful wetting of my appetite.  

Atmosphere and Service: intimate and excellent, respectively.  Waiters are detailed without you noticing - the standard.

We went with wonderful company and everyone at the table enjoyed the evening.  We had two bottles of one of their Italian red wines that  was a nice, complementary choice with our meals.

Dessert: the tiramisu lightly eased on my tongue.  I recommend the Bonet.  Both desserts were balanced in sweetness and weight.  Pleasing end for your palate. 

Altogether I thought the meal for the group was quite reasonably priced.
author: Liz K.

description: Fantastic! Came here on a date and I would strongly recommend it. I had gotten a Bloomspot coupon that was for 2 of everything and every dish was phenomenal. The waiter was so sweet and attentive. The atmosphere was classy yet relaxed and romantic.
author: Angela S.

description:
This is a cute little neighborhood restaurant, almost like a living room. It's interesting that it is Istrian cuisine: nowadays Istria is mainly in Croatia, so since I am half Montenegrin, I was curious to try.

We had a salad to start and then I ordered the rabbit and my husband the risotto. Both were very tasty but the rabbit was a little dry - not as juicy as for example at Florio's on Fillmore. 
Also after we had had our main course and wanted to pay to get home the waiters got quite neglecting and we had to wait forever to get our bill. Those two points are why I am not giving it 5 stars. But we will definitely be back. It's perfect for a romantic date night.
author: Alexandra D.

description: Obvious high quality and unique region of Italy (now not).  It started out very strong with an amazing Caramelized pear and Gorgonzola salad.  Wow!  Then stuffed pork loin wasn't as great - too much sauerkraut and too little meat per piece.  Chocolate flan (not a fan of flan but it was recommended) had some type of liqueur around it that wasn't planned nor appreciated.  I didn't finish a chocolate dessert!  That says something.  Nice ambience and super service overall.
author: El Jefe J.

description:
My wife and I ate here just before the New Year and had a really great meal.  We were seeing a show at Cobb's and wanted something close.  Picked Albona based on the yelp reviews and we definitely were not disappointed.

I had the soup of the day (a "winter" soup) to start, which was really delicious.  For dinner, my wife had chicken with mushrooms and roasted potatoes and I had the arriabiata pasta.  Both were excellent.

This is a fairly small restaurant with fairly tight tables, but really comfortable feel.  Definitely on my list of places to come back to.
author: Richard M.

description:
My college friends and I took a trip up to San Francisco and me and another food freak in our group were tasked with finding a restaurant that would take a party of six on a Saturday with a day's notice.  After much scrambling on Yelp and Opentable, we booked the single available opening at Albona and hoped for the best.

All six of our party walked away from that meal fulfilled and happy.  I could not have asked for more from this restaurant in terms of warmth and authenticity and spectacular food.

The place is family-run and comfortably established, and the owner - a nephew or other close relative of the original owner - works the phone line, the host station, and the dining room with genuine affability and an obvious love of the restaurant.  I spoke with him on the phone about four times making various small changes to our reservation (parties of 5 - no 6 - no 5 - no 6 - are hard to manage) and by the time we met in person he treated me like a familiar, without a hint of annoyance.  Our waiter was similarly friendly and charming, as well as attentive and helpful.  The service was really wonderful.  Our waiter had clear favorites on the menu and led us in the right directions with our food.

And sweet Saint Francis of Assisi, the food.  Albona is an Istrian restaurant, the only one I've been to or even heard of, and it's named for the original owner's hometown in Istria.  The cuisine is regional Italian, but with influences from Austrians, Hungarians, Greeks, you name it.  If I come across another Istrian restaurant, I'm going in, no questions asked.

First off, the bread basket was great - the sourdough had a nice thick crust and the rolls were soft and ideal for sopping.  There was plenty of sopping when we'd cleared any hint of solid food off our two appetizer plates.  If you're going to listen to anything in this review, let it be this: "chifeleti de mia nona con sugo de carne al cumín."  This was the original owner's grandmother's specialty - pan-fried potato gnocchi in a cumin-laced brown sirloin sauce.  It was insane.  The gnocchi was fried a just-crispy golden-brown on the outside and stayed impossibly fluffy and potatoey inside.  The sauce was deep and hearty with an aromatic trail of cumin.  Everyone wanted more, and everyone took bread to sauce to clean the plate.  We had a similar experience with the strudel con pasta fatta in casa, a fresh pasta roll stuffed with prosciutto and Lappi cheese, then baked in a casserole with toasted bread crumbs, béchamel, and a tomato-cream sauce.  Does that sound decadent?  Because it was.  It was creamy and rich and over-the-top delicious.

After those appetizers, you would think it all went downhill, but the entrees were excellent.  Being good friends and Asian and all, our group went semi-family style and everything was superb.  The winner among winners was the lombo de aniel ai feri - the grilled lamb noisette marinated in red wine, olive oil, vinegar, fresh herbs, and mint.  I've never had lamb so tender, and the generous forward application of fresh herbs was among the best I've ever encountered.  I was skeptical about the use of mint, but it was the icing on the cake - just a tiny hint that was noticeable but beautifully in tune.  The lamb was served with simple sautéed vegetables and roasted potatoes which were homey and well-cooked.

My order was the brodeto de pesse a la Istriana, an Adriatic seafood stew with red wine and balsamic-tomato sauce, served over grilled polenta.  This was not as good as the meatier dishes, but it was still awesome, loaded with shrimp, mussels, and calamari, with earthy grilled polenta to soak up the sauce.

Of the other entrees, I would recommend the arosto de coniglio, sugo in agrodolce con ginepro.  In English, this is braised rabbit with onions, juniper berries, honey, brown sugar, and balsamic, served with polenta.  The rabbit just fell off the bone, and the sauce was divine, with complex developed flavors.  The stinco de videl a la Triestina, a braised veal shank glazed with Burgundy wine and rosemary, was good, but it paled next to the braised rabbit.  If you need your chicken, the peto de polo a la Maraska was a decent sauteed bird breast in a fantastic brandied cherry sauce with whole cherries.  It also came with a gorgeous herb risotto.

For dessert, we split the panna cotta and a trio of chocolate, strawberry, and mandarin sorbet.  The panna cotta was simple and delicious, with a coulis of port wine and berries.  It was laden with vanilla bean and boasted a smooth thick texture.  The sorbets were all very light and feathery, almost icy but not unpleasantly so.  The desserts were more familiar than the savory fare, but we did well not to skip them.

The bill was worthy of a nice dinner out but even with wine, it was reasonable, especially given the A+ dining experience.  We were all full and happy when we boarded the trolley back to our hotel.  Albona is the sort of place you leave grinning.
author: Steph C.

description:
Small intimate restaurant (seats 40).  While technically in the North Beach area, it is actually closer to the Fishermans Wharf area.

We had no problem getting reservations at the last minute on a Monday evening but it was full the entire time we were there.

Menu was a little limited and not your typical Italian but good.  Service was attentive and very friendly but sporadic as they only had 2 guys doing everything for all 40 diners.
author: Anita P.

description:
Love love Love this place!

For the 2nd consecutive year in a row, my girlfriends and I dined at this little jewel box to celebrate a birthday! My friend and I ordered the pasta strudel and asparagus soup. Absolutely to die for.  If you have not tried the pasta strudel it is amazing.  The service was impeccable and the chef/co-owner Michael made us feel like family.  I would absolutely recommend this place.  

On another note....For those of you who have never been to Albona and actually tried their food, please do not make negative comments about the place. It is heaven for real foodies.
author: Carla B.

description: This restaurant is really a gem. The Italian inspired Istrian cuisine us inventive and unexpected. The owners are very friendly and knowledgeable, the 4 dishes we had plus dessert were excellent  (the pasta strudel is a sort of canneloni dish, but with their spin and is superb) and the ambiance nice but not pretentious. The owner/host had us do a mini wine tasting to pick out our red (Nero d'Avolo) and then they added a second dessert on the house which is their tiramisu - spectacular, one of the very best I've ever had (made by the wife/owner)! A real find, reasonably priced, and a Lot of Fun!
author: Kurt T.

description: Old school Italian / European restaurant in the North Beach area that actually is not a tourist trap. Very small operations so they are all about the customer experience. Very unique and authentic dishes that are well cooked and prepared from pastas to secondis. The chef even comes out to serve and explain. This is a very traditional place so crowds tend to be a little older but a fabulous restaurant nonetheless.
author: Ed L.

description: Intimate, serene atmosphere. We felt like treasured guests"We've been waiting for you," the manger said when we arrived.  A glass of proseco was poured for each of us. The veal shank fell off the bone;the pasta arribiatta was spicy and perfectly cooked. Four of us at three courses for$150. Buon Guosto
author: Wendy C.

description:
Great food and wonderful service. Smaller menu than some places and a bit different than the one available online, but the food and experience were very enjoyable. 

Note that they don't have a full bar, just beer and wine - not a huge wine list, but plenty of good choices. 

Good desserts too - one of the better tiramisus I've had and the gelato was delicious.
author: Michael M.

description: If I could give it more than 5 stars, I would. Everything from the quaint and peaceful ambiance to the stellar customer service, this place is positively fantastic! The day boat scallops literally melt in your mouth and the Sangiovese wine was superb. Sam (chef/owner) was so attentive and helpful with his service and recommendations. Customer service this good comes along but once in a lifetime folks, eat here and enjoy every second of it!
author: Tori M.

description: Food was very fresh and very delicious.  Definitely recommend for a leisurely meal.  The Owner was out among the tables, as well as checking in the kitchen.  He was very personable and made us feel welcome.  Would definitely go back -- the food was very, very good.  Would recommend reservations, particularly on a weekend -- we were there during the week and most table were taken, but it is not a huge restaurant.
author: B K.

description: Overrated. The reviews are misleading. Friendly, but too few waiters for the tabletops they hope to handle. The food is good-- not great. They ran out of wine and specials. In a city of great restaurants, look elsewhere and avoid a free dessert for poor service.
author: Jon P.

description: Marvelous. Sublime service, great food in a great understated atmosphere. Highly recommended find.
author: Andrew K.

description: We dined here in December 2012 and I have been dreaming about the gnocchi ever since!  We went back tonight and I ordered them again and they were just as heavenly as I remember.
author: Kristin H.

description: I can't stop talking about this place.  What a gem.  It's so unique and authentic.  The fusion of italian and croatian was so awesome, I enjoyed learning the history of the region as well.  It's a very small tucked away spot, off the beaten path a little bit, it doesn't feel touristy at all.  Great wine, great comfort food, you will be in a wonderful food coma after this warm meal on a chilly wet SF night.
author: Theresa W.

description: It's a tiny and cozy place, and everyone is so personable. It was awesome that they truly wanted us to have a good experience. The chef kept coming every now and then to check that we were enjoying everything. He opened a bottle of wine, asked us to taste it (we're not experts so we said it seems fine), he was not satisfied and asked a colleague who decided it was not good, and so they got us brand new bottle! He also made entree suggestions, and the food was good too. Overall it was a really fun evening made even better given the fact that the restaurant staff was so friendly and attentive.
author: Anusha S.

description:
I am the quintessential foodie.
It's not uncommon that there is a restaurant I haven't tried; there are only so many days in a week or year.  It is uncommon, however, that I have not heard about a good restaurant, though.

Albona Ristorante Istriano is tucked away on a residential street in the North Beach area of San Francisco.  During its business hours, if you didn't know about it, you would drive right by it without even noticing that it was opened for business.  In fact, you could walk right by it and still not know that behind these doors is what I now consider to be one of San Francisco's best dining experiences.
For a few years, I've always considered Acquerello to be San Francisco's best-kept secret - but it has now secured its place in the San Francisco dining scene.  My next mission is Albona.

We are very lucky in San Francisco to have some amazing food available within city limits.  But a recent trend I have noticed in San Francisco is that many of these finer dining establishments offers amazing appetizers and "second" entrees, but the main dish is almost consistently sub-par and lackluster compared to the previous courses.  Case in point - "A16 in the Marina, "Local" in SOMA, and even "DOSA" in the Mission.

I will say off the bat that Albona hit a homerun for each course.  Istrian cuisine, as it turns out, is simply good food that carries a strong Italian history with a flair not commonly found in Italian food.

First, it's a small restaurant that exudes "family-run operation".  I imagine the uncle as the chef, the cousins working as servers, and the owner as the host.  While the owner, Michael Bruno, is the host (and server, as needed), I know not if everyone else in the restaurant is actually family.  What I do know is they all, from each individual server to busser, worked together as a family should where each individual had a vested interest in extending the utmost in service.  Watching their interaction with each table like a hawk in preparation for this review - I confirmed once again what I always believed to be true:  when you own a restaurant, you owe it to your business to BE THERE.

In Albona's case, Michael Bruno isn't just there; he brands that restaurant, and ensures that every representative of his establishment is an extension of himself, and his style.  This extends all the way to the  food.

My first experience with the owner was on the phone.  I called en route to the restaurant to ask if we'd be seated immediately if we came in ten minutes.  He checked, said yes - and we arrived right on time to see a line of people waiting in the small front area.  Due to having after-dinner plans, I started getting worried that we'd have to wait, but alas, he came to the front, checked that I was the one who called, and seated us immediately.  Gotta love a man who is true to his word.

The menu at Albona reads beautifully with Italian names, and English descriptions.  We selected two appetizers and two entrees, and we chose Prosecco as our imbibe of choice for this evening.  We told our server that we'd be sharing and they went the extra mile to split it for us in the kitchen.  It's these touches that catapult a good dining experience into an amazing one.

First up was the gnocchi, pan-fried in butter and served amidst the most tantalizingly good brown sauce that has ever graced this tongue of mine.  Not only was the gnocchi interesting and more similar to croquette type texture, the sauce was deep in flavor, but most noticeable was the delicate but ever so noticeable use of cumin in what could have been a basic Italian dish.  One bite and inevitably, our eyes rolled to the back of our heads and we savored each piece.  For something  close to $8, it was a large portion that was split onto two plates - and quite filling.

Next super-star delivered to our table was the stuffed calamari.
One order consisted for four nicely sized squid, stuffed silly with an amazing fish concoction consisting of red snapper, salmon, and other goodies.  Every single element of  this dish stood out and was delightful to my tastebuds.  But most stellar was the ever-so-basic but amazingly delicious red sauce that accompanied the perfectly cooked squid.  Consisting of the right amount of acidity, sweetness, and depth, it took every ounce of my being not to slurp the remainder off the plate.  Unlike the deep and heavy flavors of the buttery gnocchi, this dish was light and playful, but every bit as memorable.

The entrees were superb.  

The remainder of this review can be found at http://wp.me/pF4av-C - word limitation on Yelp prevents me from posting the whole thing!
author: Grace K.

description: The food, ambiance, and background music were all fabulous!  I will dine here every time I visit San Francisco in the future.  BTW, the sauerkraut was AMAZING!!
author: William H.

description: Yum. Try the chicken with cherry sauce (it's far better than it sounds) and the scallops. Worth every penny!
author: Brianna M.

description:
Linguine con granzo e pesse, salsa de pomodoro fresco e aio 
Soup of the Day - Asparagus soup
Costolette de aniel - Rack of Lamb

I had their asparagus soup. It was yummy and alot creamier then I expected which is a good thing at least for what I like. Their seafood linguine dish was amazing! Normally when I do italian, I usually never order red sauce pastas since I believe those are easy to make at home. But this was simply a good choice. Very light tomato, perfectly seasons and right amount of olive oil. And to top that with seafood...Amazing! Then next to the rack of lamb...I love rack of lamb and this was cooked to perfection. It was marinated perfectly and definitely one of my fave places now for lamb. I will definitely be back!
author: Helen V.

description:
Had some friends in town who wanted to experience some Italian food in North Beach... SO, I turned to Yelp for help picking the right spot! 

This place was good... I guess I had just expected maybe a BIT more after having read all the raving reviews. 

Service actually could have been better - we waited 45 minutes after having our drinks delivered to have the guy even take our order. The people who came in after us were served before us. 

The menu if def a bit out there, not your typical spaghetti and meatballs. The bread rolls to start we great and are made in house daily. 
I had the Pappardelle con galeti, panseta e bisi con salsa de pomidoro - A pasta that we delicious! My boyfriend had the pork which was fantastic. Also the Strudel con pasta fatta in casa was great and the seafood stew was good. 

The ambiance of the place is very quiet and not for large groups. Overall the experience was good -
author: Kelly B.

description: Had an amazing dinner tonight. Quiet, intimate and the gnocchi was stunning. Don't hesitate to dine here. One of the beat dinner experiences ever!
author: Annie B.

description:
A decent restaurant ruined by overpriced entrees and too small of a menu.

Food - average
The stuffed calamari appetizers were good.  Not only the calamaris were fresh and juicy but the marinara sauce was perfect.  It has just the right bite and consistency.  I had to have every drop of it, resorting in the end to soaking it all with my dinner roll.
The prosciutto risotto was disappointing.  The cheese sauce was too salty and it overpowers everything else.
The seafood stew entree was a major disappointment.  The ingredients (calamari, fish, mussels, scallop, etc) were all very fresh and good.  However, the sauce and seasoning were just flat.  There's no lingering after taste that makes you want more.

Service - good
This is a small restaurant with a very good waiters-to-tables ratio.  They also have free valet service which is very useful in North Beach.

Price - not worth it
$29 for that disappointing seafood stew; about $25 for the risotto.  Dinner for two (with one glass of wine each) set me back $130.  Not worth it for the quality of food that I'm getting.

Overall - average
This is a place you can consider if you care less about the food and care more about dining in a small cozy restaurant.  I don't see myself being a regular patron.
author: Andi H.

description:
Albona is a quiet, upscale restaurant tucked away in a dark residential neighborhood in North Beach. It's your typical restaurant that you would imagine for your grandparents' anniversary or for a business dinner to which you want to treat your most valuable 50-year-old clients. Frankly, it's for the older crowd (ages 50-99). There's a lack of excitement and that wow factor that only the older crowd would be satisfied with completely.

Don't get me wrong, I thought it was a very good dinner. I enjoyed my braised veal shank with soft polenta very much -- it was as tender as an infant cow can be, and the polenta was great. Could it have been a bit tastier? Yeah, it definitely could have been a little sweeter and more flavorful. I tried a bit of the rabbit, which I thought was much tastier than my veal shank -- I probably should have gotten that.

We had a pretty good waiter -- recommended a great wine for us (the Montepulciano red wine) and checked up on us quite frequently. I was impressed with a busboy who helped us out by giving us a bowl of baking soda & club soda for a red wine accident.

All in all, I enjoyed my dinner, but I wasn't excited by it. There was nothing astounding -- it all just seemed very safe and boring, something that I think only those in my grandfather's age bracket can truly be satisfied with. I know it's fancy and upscale, but that should never be synonymous with "boring".

It's one of those restaurants where you have good food with good wine at good prices -- and then you leave and the entire experience just melts away into the darkest corners of your subconscious. If you ever hear the word "Albona" again, you think: "Oh, I think I went there once. I remember it was good." But you never really remember the experience, you just remember that you may have thought it was good. 

It's a restaurant for those of you who want a simple, elegant meal without all the fireworks and all the wow. And there's nothing wrong with that. You may even prefer that over all the white noise of hip and chic -- fusion this and neo-contemporary that. Then this restaurant is for you.

It's just not a restaurant that you scream at the top of your lungs for and definitely not a restaurant that you recommend to your out-of-towner friends who are dying to see what the SF food culture is all about. The reason is because there is a similar restaurant that exists in every city across America. When you take any out-of-town visitor to Albona, chances are they're saying: "Oh there's this wonderful place in my city that's just like this!" And they're probably right.
author: Roy C.

description: On the pricey side, but great food combined with a cute little romantic setting perfect for a date will have me going back again.
author: Brian D.

description:
This place is what the dining experience should be like.  We arrived for our 7:30 reservations on time, handed our keys to the free valet (what a godsend in SF!), but did not get seated until nearly 8.  While this usually annoys me greatly, they were apologetic and attentive, giving us complimentary wine while we waited.

The restaurant itself is small and cozy, giving the impression you're in someone's house.  While the booth seats were a bit too close, allowing you to hear other people's conversation and vice versa, I was mostly comfortable.

Bruno, as mentioned by other Yelpers, was a delight.  He came by and gave us detailed descriptions of the minestrone and fish (neither of which we ended up ordering).  We ordered the gnocchi (superb, tasted like it had a faint Indian influence, really interesting), and the braised sauerkraut.  Then I remembered I don't actually like sauerkraut.  But the sausage on top of it was good, and this was probably the best sauerkraut that I have had?

For entrees, we ordered the stuffed pork loin (excellent) and veal shank (also great, not as good as pork loin).  The pork loin came with a side of red cabbage, that tasted sauerkraut-ish, as in it was kind of sour.  I'm not sure I like this much sour/sweet in my food, but overall I was pretty pleased.

We passed on dessert, and Bruno called the valet to get our car ready, and then escorted us outside, asking us to please join them again.  I soo appreciated that.  Our car was ready and waiting for us as he opened the door.  For $83 (2 appetizers + 2 entrees + tip + valet tip), not too shabby.
author: Liz L.

description: Wonderful, I had a salad and the ravioli while on business in San Francisco. Great atmosphere. The food was only matched by the service. I have been to several places in fisherman's warf on this trip but this is by far my favorite!!
author: Matthew H.

description: Excellent Italian food with even better service... Highly recommended. If you're looking for a dinner where you feel as though you're at home, this is the place to be.
author: Joe Z.

description:
Although we live in the east bay, I wanted a special dinner for my wife and immediate family  on her birthday.  We've eaten at Albona several times in the past, and have never been disappointed by the quality of their food or the warm, gracious service of their entire staff.  Our experience this past weekend was no exception.

Sam, the executive Chef and owner has to be one of the most engaging, caring restaurant owners in The City.  Making a point to personally greet each guest, the dining experience at Albona is more akin to dining at a friend's home, than it is at a restaurant.  We have always been warmly welcomed, the menu and specials are carefully explained, and then Sam and the staff make sure that the service and dining experience is exemplary.  

The quality of the Italian/Croatian cuisine is exceptional, as is the presentation of each dish.  I won't go into the details of every dish ordered at our table for 7, however everyone was effusive with praise for the cuisine.  You will find plenty of restaurants that charge the same or more money for the privilege of dining, but you won't find better food or a more welcoming experience anywhere in the City!   

Don't forget to order desert, either!  Sam's wife is the pastry chef, and everything our table tasted was extraordinary.  If only she could craft them without so many calories! LOL

You should not hesitate to make a reservation and patronize this wonderful gem in SF!
author: Ron R.

description: My first time coming here was Great! I took my Gf for our One Year anniversary and they treated us like royalty! we met the chef a great guy we spoke to him about our first time there and we came from napa and where he was from in total he was very friendly and made us feel more than welcomed. the food there was great! and reasonably priced, i recommend going there, not so much as a one year date only because it was packed and small and not to romantic (bt then again if you have the right company, its all gravy) bt more as a casual date or an evening out with friends. They gave us a lot of things on the house which made it that much better we will definitely be going back soon.
author: Martin M.

description:
Albona Ristrante is a small restaurant that will certainly please you. Ambiance won't blow you away. Location won't blow you away-- on a residential street, but their food and service certainly will. The servers really try to provide great service and I appreciate that. We ordered veal shank and the rack of lamb. The veal shank just melted in my mouth. I would certainly go and ask them to go light on the gravy the next time around. Now... the rack of lamb... oooh so good. I don't usually enjoy lamb, I find it gamy and the aftertaste sometimes too overwhelming. Albona's lamb was cooked to perfection and it was hardly gamy. The star of the dish had to be the puree/ the sauce. I wanted to take the puree from the lamb dish and pour it over my veal. I didn't, but I imagine it would have been scrumptious. We also ordered the crab salad as an appetizer and the tiramisu for dessert. Both were tasty. 

The night was cold and they have a curtain that divides the restaurant from the entrance so if you get chilly easily, I would suggest asking for a table further in. I also suggest making reservations. It was a full house on a Sunday night at 8pm. 

Street parking is possible, but valet is complimentary! (No valet on Sundays)
author: Rosa L.

description: Enjoyed my seafood linguine.  It was packed with a nice selection of creatures and had great flavor in the sauce without being overbearing.  Nice variety on the menu, though for me personally, I didn't see a ton of other stuff I would try except for the rabbit should I return.  Bread could be a little better.  Nice staff.  In the upper price range, tough for me personally to go 5, but I'll put them on watch for possible upgrade if / when I go again and try the rabbit.
author: Marc S.

description:
i came to this restaurant thinking that it would be delicious. i love italian food, i have been to the istrian peninsula before and loved it so, i thought it would be a shoe in.  we walked in on valentines day( i know i know, busy night) right on time for the reservation, and we were greeted, and told to please wait while they reset our table.  another couple arrived, and yet another.  ten minutes passed and the host(?) sat the other couple, even though they had no reservation, before us, we waited an additional ten to fifteen minutes (total of half an hour, with a reservation).

once at our seats, we ordered the cream of mushroom soup ( because the soup in italy was my favorite), and it was bland and tasted of dried porcini mushrooms (all packagey, and cardboard tasting).  when the mains came i had ordered the pork loin stuffed with sauerkraut, prunes, and prociutto, wich was sweet and savory which i except the sauce already had a skin on it. 

after dinner we waited for the check (dessert was declined) for just a little too long.

this is a small place, i get it.
they were busy, i get it.
but i doubt i'll go back again.

and there was no valet.
author: corey p.

description:
Quite the gem I must say!  The best part of the night was the great service.  I was pretty surprised by the menu, since it's heavily czech influenced.  However, after a history lesson by the server, it all made sense.  The food was delish, pasta was fresh.  The gnocchi was reallly really good.  They had some great wines for a reasonable price as well.

It's not a cheap date spot, but definitely worth at least one meal since it is truly a San Francisco establishment.  It is worth every penny!
author: Helen C.

description:
Great restaurant with awesome atmosphere.  Small dining room creates an intimate setting.  Wine selection leaves a little to be desired for a restaurant of this quality but the list certainly covers the basics.  One of the chefs came out to discuss our orders and I was conflicted between the sardines app and the stuffed squid... At first he suggested the sardines but after hearing my main entree he suggested the squid which I went with.  When the apps came out, he accidentally gave me the sardines... They were very happy to correct the error and they gave us the sardines gratis (both were very good).  Entrees that came out were the seafood risotto, saffron risotto, braised rabbit, and salmon special... All were very well received.

I would definitely come back in a second without hesitation, though I would probably bring my own wine.
author: Justin N.

description:
The food was amazing.  I wish the portions were a tad bigger as I left still very hungry.  I had the veal and most of my date's chicken, which was the special.  It's a tad pricey but worth it for me as finding good italian in this city is hard to come by.  The setting is nice - weird it's like in the middle of a neighborhood.  It felt like I was just walking down the street and someone opened up their house to cook.  

Definitely make reservations - I had them and we still had enough time to drink a glass of wine while we waited.  They don't turn tables fast.
author: Hammer Time H.

description: Had dinner at Albona...and I was absolutely floored by the level of service, and the amount of detail and attention that goes into preparing the dishes they serve. If you like Medditeranean dishes - you don't want to miss Albona!
author: Ed C.

description: One of the finest gems found in North Beach of San Francisco. If I could, this place gets more than five stars. The address is misleading by the way. If you ever map it, you get directed in an alley. The entrance is on the opposite side of the street. This restaurant is one of the finest restaurants I have ever eaten at. The space is small, and the establishment is always busy - according to our waiter - but quaint for that romantic evening (wink-wink). I digress, let me get back to the food... dinner was superb and I highly recommend anyone who adores Italian food to check this place out. Menu doesn't change very often (again, according to our waiter) but that's only because what the chef prepares becomes an instant favorite for their patrons, which make them come back all the time. Great wine selection, but don't be afraid to ask for your waiter's opinion on one. HAPPY EATING!
author: Rob B.

description: This place is AMAZING. Looks are most certainly deceiving in the case of Albona. It's a small restaurant on a residential street, very little signage on the outside. Make a reservation as they really don't have that much space. The quality of the food is amazing, you can tell the chief really loves what he does. The servers are also wonderful, and happy to provide recommendations for food and wine.
author: Tara T.

description: Overpriced, over hyped. I came here for dinner once around 5 ish. The place is not crowded at all and the service isn't the greatest. The food isnt the greatest for the price I paid as well.
author: Ricki H.

description:
came here after buying a bloomspot coupon, 2 apps, 1 pasta, 2 entrees and 2 desserts for $69. best deal ever!

not only was the food spot on, the staff was very attentive, (but not overbearing) and friendly.

i particularly enjoyed the gnocchi although it wasn't the traditional gnocchi i am used to but regardless it was delicious. the scallops and the panna cotta were also great!

this restaurant is nestled on a side street away from many of the other north beach area and really feels authentic and homey. had a great experience, definitely recommend it!
author: Jae C.

description:
I hate to give it a bad review but I have no other choice. 

I had a yummy pumpkin ravioli meal and really enjoyed it - my boyfriend on the other hand, threw up all night from food poising. The only thing we didn't share was the venison so I lucked out. It's a terrible situation, since everything about this place lends itself for a cute, romantic dinning experience. It's dimly lit, the waiters are exceptionally nice and it has a very Italian feel to it, but after the night my bf had there is no way I will be returning.
author: johanna a.

description:
Why this place has such high rating I really don't know. you got to make reservations. The place is very small. The furniture is old, so you feel it has been there for a long time and no face lift has been done.
The food is average italian food, but expensive price wise! I had the lamp, medium rare, but it still felt dry. My friend had the chiken, nothing special either... The pastas were not that interesting either...
The desert was ok, I have had better ones!
author: Arash H.

description:
Excellent, excellent place. The food is deliciuous: first it's very hard to find an Istrian restaurant with peculiar dishes mixing Italian and slavic flavors, second they were cooked to perfection. We had the " Chifeleti de mia nona con sugo de carne al cumin " (fried gnocchi with a spicy meat sauce), "Stinco de videl a la Triestina" (braised veal shank) and "Involtin de porco con capuzi garbi e prosuto"(pork rolls with sweet filling and side). We did not order dessert, but the owner treated us with freshly made peach sorbet, which was really good. 

The sizes are abundant, the place is small, yet it's not noisy and the service is good. The owner and chef, Samuel, is so sweet and polite. We'll definitely go back.
author: Manu T.

description:
Dish: Salad, Gnocchi, Stuffed Calamari, Pancetta Risotto, Braised Shank of Veal, Rabbit.

Atmosphere: Quaint, snug restaurant, dimly-lit and perfect for the affluent older crowd looking for a familiar dish.

Like: Calamari and the sauce that came with it.

Dislike: 
- the careless throwing of utensils onto our plates by the waiter in charge of resetting tables.  
- the $9 salad looked and tasted like something you could throw together with Costco ingredients.  The cranberries used in the salad were incredibly reminiscent of soaked Craisins.

Thought: I don't understand why this is a 4.5star establishment.  The food wasn't anything spectacular or particularly exciting.  The protein sits atop a puddle of polenta which is surrounded by a sauce that masks the flavor of the dish.  The ever-popular cumin-laden Gnocchi was something you could probably throw together yourself.  While portions are decently sized, for the amount you're paying you could do much better elsewhere.

Conclusion: Come for the atmosphere if it's your thing.
author: Chase C.

description:
We went here for our anniversary, and we couldn't have asked for anything better.  Everything was wonderful.  I was only sad I didn't get to talk to Bruno, but I did get to talk to the new owner.

We loved the Istrian wine.  For an appetizer, we got the gnocchi in cumin and brown sirloin sauce -- delicious, and apparently Grandmother's specialty!  Derek got the special that night -- salmon filet over whipped mashed potatoes and shiitake mushrooms.  It was as if the meal was invented just for him.  I ordered a pasta recently put on the menu for fall, featuring a tomato-bechamel sauce and mushrooms.  I've craved it since!

For dessert, I got a triple mousse gelato -- the flavour was espresso and vanilla bean.  It was a good dessert and well done, but I would've liked another flavour.  Derek ordered a dark chocolate flan and found it pretty good, tasty, and very rich.

The atmosphere was intimate and warm, especially after the long, windy and cold walk up from Montgomery BART.  But it was worth it.  And we even got to ride the trolley on the way home!

Both of us would love to go back; we just have to find the reason and money for it ...
author: Dana G.

description:
This place is simply wonderful!! The owner/chef personally greeted us with champagne as he knew we were celebrating a birthday.  He spent time to discuss the fresh fish he had purchased that morning and even took our order!  

The food was amazing.  The service was amazing. I would highly recommend.
author: Niki B.

description:
Had an amazing dinner here. Mike was super helpful in setting up a great table for us when we wanted just a lil privacy. (some of the two tops are extremely close together.)

The lamb shank and creamy polenta was to die for! And my bf's breaded chicken was light crispy and moist. Very simple and classic but done really well.  The wine was great taboot!

The homey feel and the authentic food will surely bring us back here in the future!
author: ella a.

description:
Albona has become my favorite neighborhood joint (there are hundreds, no *thousands* of places in North Beach!), and I've introduced many people (friends and clients), who also love it. 

Michael is a gracious host, the venue is intimate and cozy, and the food is consistently delicious.  Even if I move out of the 'hood, I know I'll still be a "regular" here.
author: Kimberly Q.

description:
luckily made a reservation early on in the week because they went fast. had it set for 8:15, but called on the day of and tried to reschedule to an earlier time. said they couldn't, but would call me if anyone cancelled.

still went in a little early, and were very nice in trying to sit us as soon as a table opened up.

complimentary valet. it only moves to the sidewalk, but sure beats trying to find parking in that area.

the scallops were amazing, the veal shank started out great then got a little chewy. that pasta my gf got was delicious. gelato to end a fantastic meal.

service was above excellent. came out to describe everything we were going to eat and came by frequently, but not overly in-your-face.

take a date there and have a meal that you won't forget.
author: Andrew A.

description:
Hubby booked a table for us here on a weeknight.  Free valet parking is nice but otherwise it feels like a tourist trap - sort of a poser in the SF restaurant scene.

The service was pleasant and prompt, but the food was very meh.  My meh I mean I could have done each dish better on my own at home.

Crab 'cake' (really a salad of crab in a ring mold) was lovely, so we had high expectations.  But the asparagus soup was tired and overworked, and bland.  House ravioli was dry and flavorless, and swimming in the brown butter sauce.  

Dessert was nice but at that point I was reeling from the mediocre-bordering-on-lousy main course so I was none too happy that it cost $7-8.  And it hac walnuts in it, which was not listed on the menu, so my date couldn't partake.  (they list pine nuts).

Crowd was in their 50's and at least half tourists.  The couple sitting next to us (from Baltimore) thought the meal was delicioso! 

For this SF food snob, it really didn't cut the mustard.  Unmemorable, especially for SF.  2 stars.
author: Margot L.

description:
RESTAURANT REVIEW

HIDDEN BUT NEVER FORGOTTEN

By Carol Peterson

Albona, 545 Francisco St., San Francisco, 
CA 94133  415.441.1040   

 Buried in the five hundred block of Francisco Street, is a small restaurant with a rich history. Daringly, 21 years ago Bruno Viscovi opened Albona, named for his home town on the culturally complex Istrian Peninsula and featuring the foods of that region located on the Northern Adriatic Sea near Trieste.

           Viscovi was certainly taking a chance opening a restaurant across the street from some of the most dilapidated and crime ridden public housing in the city. (The projects have now been replaced by the spiffy subsidized housing of North Beach Place.) I visited this restaurant in the late 80s and was very impressed with the food and the intimacy of the space. Bruno came to your table and told you the tale of his family's history of food and how many of the recipes were drawn from Bruno's memory growing up in Albona. It was the restaurant's location, not the quality of the food that I worried about. They will never make it, I told myself after each satisfied visit. But the restaurant did make it, appearing regularly on the San Francisco Chronicle's list of 100 Best Bay Area Restaurants. 
 
          After twenty years of running this very successful restaurant, Bruno Viscovi retired. His nephew, Michael Bruno, who had worked every job in the restaurant but cook long before he began to shave, took over. Michael brought on as his partner Viscovi's chef, Samuel Hernandez who had worked at many famous local restaurants, including Bix in our neighborhood. It was the freedom of being Michael's partner that expanded Samuel's ideas. The recipes have stayed the same but the presentation has been brought to a new level.

          In a way, Michael emulates his uncle as he talks to diners at each table, welcoming them. "Unlike my uncle, I didn't grow up in Istria, so my stories are different," Michael said. "Mine are of the history of the years I have worked and been around Albona."

           Tasting the four different appetizers we ordered, the mushroom soup was the standout. It has a stock of chicken and prosciutto, reduced. Yellow onions and Yukon Gold potatoes are added to form this rich, creamy soup that surprisingly has no cream. If you are a mushroom lover, this is your dish. Michael tells me the most popular appetizer is a recipe from his grandmother, pan fried potato gnocchi, with a brown, cumin laced, sirloin sauce. When the dish arrived, the gnocchi were so brown, I thought the dish must be overcooked, but the crunchy outside split to reveal a soft potato inside. Michael said, "My girlfriend calls these Pillows of Heaven". Swirl them in the rich sirloin sauce and 
you'll get her point.

        One of the signature pasta dishes at Albona is the strudel con pasta fatta in casa. This creamy dish speaks of Bruno's search for the perfect ingredients to replicate his ancestors' recipes. After trying many cheeses, he found that a Finnish cheese called Lappi worked the best for melting.  In a 550 degree oven, the cheese never turns stringy or dry, creating a devine texture. The fresh pasta rolls are stuffed with Lappi and proscuitto and covered with a creamy, buttery tomato sauce. Toasted bread crumbs and béchamel are added prior to baking. This incredible pasta dish can easily be shared, as it is a generous portion for a dish this intense.

         One of my favorite dishes at this restaurant is the Fish of the Day. The evening we went, it was halibut. I was surprised at the generous portion of fish that almost filled the plate, a thick piece of fillet cooked to perfection, the outside golden brown, the inside moist and flavorful. It was served with a delicate white wine, shallot and butter sauce. I liked the small platter of steamed vegetables served separately. Usually unembellished vegetables like this are not particularly tasty, but these were the perfect compliment to this wonderfully prepared simple entree. 

        One of my hard and fast rules about a restaurant is, "If the bread is no good, the food is not going to be good." Albona's dinner rolls pass my test. Made fresh daily by Chef Samuel's wife, Beatriz, they are among the best I have had in the City. Beatriz also makes the desserts. One of her specialties--from an old Istrian recipe-- is the apple strudel, served with vanilla ice cream. When it was brought to the table, its aroma arrived first. The dessert's apples and nuts are infused with sugar, cinnamon, lemon zest and rum, then tucked in a strudel,

        Congratulations to Michael and Samuel (and Uncle Bruno) on the 21st anniversary at Albion. Thank you for having this unique, special restaurant in our neighborhood. Your little hideaway on Francisco Street may be easy to miss, but the locals who love great food aren't going to forget you.
author: Carol P.

description: The service is fabulous... The chef so kind! We have never been treated as great as this place treated us... The gnocchi was amazing!! Love this place and the food!!
author: Laila G.

description:
I totally recommend this place.  This is the second time coming and the quality was still as good as the first time.  I came here with BF and roommate.  We had a bloomspot deal, which is a 4-course meal for 2.  My roommate ordered an extra appetizer and entree and we all shared.  It was way more than enough food for all of us.

Here is the quick breakdown:
Appetizers:  scallops (the best appetizer of the night...so good...), gnocchi (I wanted more!), and calamari (delicious and slightly spicy)

Pasta (BTW, pretty big portions):  seafood risotto (decent) and seafood linguine (I enjoyed this more and there was a lot of seafood in it too)

Entree:  rabbit (sweet and not tough) and rack of lamb (nice crust on the outside and tender meat)

Dessert:  dark chocolate flan (super rich in a good way) and gelato (more subtle, but tastes just right).  When you mixed these together though...AMAZING!

Anyways, the staff is super friendly and the place is nice and intimate.  It is a little pricey, but not really considering the quality (and for some dishes the quantity too).  Be warned that the place is a little cramped and quiet, so your neighbors can hear your conversation.
author: A W.

description:
Tucked into a neighborhood street in the uber-touristy North Point area, Albona is a hidden gem that serves up Italian food with a slight Eastern European twist.

A couple of stand-outs:
-Pan-fried potato gnocchi. A sizable appetizer that perfectly suited sharing amongst the three of us.
-Strudel con pasta fatta in casa. I haven't quite tasted anything quite like this, and it's a very hearty pasta dish that perfectly suited our dinner.

We also ordered the housemade gelato mousse (also rather ingenious and unique) as well as the braised rabbit. The $25 restaurant.com gift certificate is always a great teaser for those inclined to use discounts.

Since the F-streetcar brought me to the area about 15 minutes early, I took the occasion to walk around Pier 39 and Fisherman's Wharf. I stumbled across an odd restaurant/island and, of course, the glorious sea lions, which are in fact back in sizable numbers. I was sad that so many were spending their dinner dollars on greasy burgers or tasteless shrimp melts, rather than taking a few minutes stroll to enjoy a mini-vacation to the Istrian Peninsula.
author: Randy M.

description:
We went with some friends, who were in from out of town, and we were hoping that all of the great reviews would be right.  We are happy to report, they are! 

Pre-Meal
We loved the rolls that were served to the table, they seemed like a mixture between a biscuit and a light roll.  We ordered two appetizers- the gnocchi and a special salad with green apple and prosciutto.   They put the prosciutto, on the side, as I am a vegetarian.  It was very tasty.  The table loved the gnocchi, they are in a meat sauce, so I am going by their review.  They thought they were different, because they had a crust.  They were fried and the table thought that the sauce was the highlight.  

I had a butternut squash soup and it was thick, smooth and ultra tasty.  They had macadamia nuts in it and I was so surprised when they said it didn't have any cream, as it was so creamy!

We really enjoyed our entrees and desserts.  The restaurant is small enough to feel intimate, but became so busy that we knew we picked a good spot.  We loved everything we ordered and they are listed below.

Great time, with great friends and yummy food.  We are happy that we listened to all the yelpers.  Thank you, thank you.

Entrees:  
Three Cheese Ravioli in a Brown Butter Sauce- yummo!
Streusel:  Cheesy Salty Goodness
Veal Shank: Cooked to perfection on top of awesome Polenta
Lamb- Cooked perfectly

Desserts:
Pana Cotta: The chef's favorite and oh so tasty.
Sorbetto: White Peach- It tasted like I was biting into the perfectly ripe fruit.
author: Steal R.

description:
Albona is off the beaten path of the hustle and bustle of the North Beach/Telegraph hill area and well worth the extra steps. It is by far the best gnocchi I've had in the city. One helping wasn't enough. I never lick my plate, but I did after every plate. 

The service is superb. Even down a server, we enjoyed a perfectly timed meal.  Mike, the owner, is the friendliest and most down to earth guy. He knows his food and his clientele. 

If you need to go out to celebrate a birthday, anniversary or just have guest in town, this is the best choice in the city, hands down.

Make sure to get reservation - its very small dining room, and it fills up fast!
author: Allison A.

description:
Went here for dinner last night (thanks Yelpers) and loved it.  First of all, it was walking distance from Cobbs Comedy club (where we were to head after dinner)!  
We started with a 2007 Cab which was quite good and reasonable priced.  
I had the crab salad and Strudel con pasta fatta in casa.  The pasta dish was aaamazing! Crab salad - very good.  Tiramisu was good- nothing to blow my socks off but still a solid dessert.  The place is on the smaller side and the tables are kinda close together (hence minus one star) but overall it was a great find!
author: Shobhana A.

description:
Different and delicious.  The cuisine is apparently from the Istrian region in Italy that has been owned or occupied by several different European countries over the years.  You can really see and taste the influences each culture has added to the dishes.   All of the previous yelpers are correct in the must try dishes.  Order one of each of the following for a party of two to share and you will leave happy:

1. Proscuitto and endive salad
2. Gnocci (Chifeleti de mia nona con sugo de carne al cumín)
3. Strudel con pasta fatta in casa 
4. Stuffed Pork loin (Involtin de porco con capuzi garbi e prosuto)

It's a cozy (small) and charming (outdated) place with a mature crowd (40+).  Their free Valet is fantastic in this neighborhood where parking is difficult.  Prices are very reasonable and you can find $25 gift certificates on restaurant.com for just a few bucks.
author: Kris N.

description: We celebrated Valentines and our anniversary at Albona last night - INCREDIBLE!!  We had the calamari al forno, mushroom risotto, strudel con pasta.... perhaps one of our top 5 favorite meals EVER! The friendly and attentive service is equal to this fabulous food. To the owner, Sam - THANKS for a perfect night.
author: DJ S.

description:
Hidden Gem!

Found this place because they had a restaurant.com promotion (essentially pay $2 for a $25 gift card, minimum food purchase of $35).  Otherwise I never would have noticed it, definitely does not look like much from the outside.

Went on a Saturday night at 6:30 without reservations and the host was still able to squeeze us right in (seemed lucky for us though, I would recommend making a reservation).  Gnocchi appetizer was delicious, I agree with previous postings that they are reminiscent of croquettes but nevertheless delicious.  I had the seafood linguine which was just perfectly spicy and had generous portions of fish and crab.  My date had the Studel Con Pasta Fatta which he really enjoyed as well.  The bite I tried of that was rich without being too heavily creamy. 

Ambiance was great, the dining room is small but well decorated and not overly packed with tables.  

I will definitely be back! (for a special occasion... it is a bit pricey!)
author: Katie M.

description:
we reserved thru yelp seatme. worked great.great food and service.nice small rest. atmosphere.wine list is very limited but not expensive.rocio is very attentive waitress.other waiter a bit curt/hurried.
calamari app was delicious.porcini  risotto was slow cooked to order properly- very good.rabbit was quite good, but just slightly oversweet.we ordered it and it was on the table within 2 minutes--precooked or??slightly dried out on one end--with polenta cakes and carrots-all good, all lying in the sweet onion purple sauce. we would definitely go back! jim
author: Jim R.

description: Excellent food, service and even the dessert was pretty good.
author: John L.

description: I had the half-braised rabbit and gnocchi, which were delicious.  What made the night memorable was that we were chatting with the owner/chef outside the restaurant and he offered (which we took) to drive us to the show we were seeing afterward!  Random acts of kindness deserve mention, so here it is.
author: Dan N.

description:
The food is top notch and very unique.  I had a tough time deciding what to eat so everyone at our table ended up with something different and we all tried each others.  I'm being completely honest when I say EVERY dish was delish and I really can't recommend any one over the other.  

This place has a very home like feel to it not to mention it's in the middle of a neighborhood.  I highly suggest anyone to go here, but be prepared it's about $23 a dish.
author: Heather S.

description:
First, make a reservation!

3 remarkable points here are even chaotic North Beach location, they have valet parking service and it is FREE, open until late night and very quiet.

Northen border Italian cuisine.

Wild mushroom risotto and strudel are awesome, hoever, strudle is gone fast. Better to keep some at the time of reservation or go earlier to the restaurant.
author: YO m.

description:
We came for dinner last Thursday...reservations needed but not a problem when we called about 3 hours ahead of time.

Left happy and FULL.  Try the braised rabbit and arugula salad!  Also, we were happy to be able to chat with the chef (owner?) Sam who checked in with us a few times to see how things were going.
author: Sara O.

description:
This place was a huge dissappointment.  The food was not very good and the atmosphere was not boisterous and rather stale.  Thank god, I was with friends and the wine that we brought was excellent.  Katherine Kennedy - Lateral - a solid Meritage.  On the plus side, the valet parking was nice.  I think this is a good place to bring grandparents or non-foodies.  

Go to 54 mint or Sodini's for better italian fare.
author: Moe J.

description:
This is a cute restaurant with an intimate family feel to it.  I especially liked the pan fried gnocchi and mushroom risotto.  I also had the taierini misto de mare (linguini with red sauce and seafood), which was good but not spectacular.  I think it could have used a little more tomato flavor.  My husband's halibut was prepared well but it was super buttery.  So mine was too subtle and his wasn't subtle enough.  Hm...

Anyway, it's a nice date place but the food was not as good as I had hoped.  Maybe I need to give it another try.  Their service was decent and our server handled our party of 7 well.  They also didn't kick us out at the end of the night and valet parking is free.
author: Nina L.

description: Very good for what I was able to eat. I had roasted veggies and chicken with cherries. They don't do much to accommodate gluten-free but are at least aware of them!
author: Elizabeth F.

description:
It's not like this place needs any more reviews - but I just cant help myself. Albona was amazing...from the service (we were lucky enough to have the owner as our waiter) to every single dish - I was pleasantly surprised and excited about the food. Grandma's gnocchi is completely different than anything I've ever had - it made me giggle. i ccouldn't decide on an entree, so \i had our waiter choose for me. The pork loin stuffed with sauerkraut may not sound like an italian dish - but it was delish and perfectly paired with the other things we were eating. The wine had just been added to the wine list - called educated guess - and we all loved it! My huz and his parents all had the strudel - because it was SO highly recommended - and they were all psyched they weren't sharing bites. I'm not a huge cheese person - but it was still delumptious. 

Bottom line; go here and be ready to have a most surprisingly delicious experience...
author: Mandy M.

description: We went here recently with my parents on a recommendation from their friend. Overall a decent meal but we had higher expectations. I had the seafood stew but felt the squid was a little rubbery. My wife wanted to try the pork but it turns out it was not available so she had chicken, which was good. We got lucky on parking as we found parking right across the street. Ambience was nice. Wait staff was good not great as wet could have had a little more attention,  given the restaurant was half empty as we ate early in the evening.
author: andy w.

description:
I've just had a thoroughly enjoyable evening at this restaurant.  So much so, that I joined Yelp just to give the place a review.

They were busy, and we didn't have a reservation, but they found us a table.  The service was great, despite them warning us that they might be a bit slow due to the sudden influx (a fair and sensible warning).

The food was delicious - from the sardine starter to the heavenly chocolate and amaretto desert.  The staff were friendly and the service was excellent.  The atmosphere was friendly and comfortable while still giving a feeling of occasion.  This is a place that I will return to without hesitation.
author: Sannse C.

description:
Unbelievable Trieste cuisine.  Very Northeaster Italian fare, with alot of potato, pork, and root veggies.
Went there for a business dinner while in town for a conference, the owner kept the place open for a few hours after their typical closing time.
Definitely get directions, it is on a side street with not many other joints, but well worth the trip.
author: Todd S.

description: Decent Italian spot but nothing to write home about.
author: Robby W.

description:
I was visiting SF last weekend with my girlfriend and I wanted to find a nice Italian place for dinner. It was about 8pm already and I called to see if they had any reservations available. Even though it was late the owner/host/waiter told me he could fit me in about 9:30.
