We showed up right about 9:30 and there were a few large parties lingering around so the owner told us it would be a few minutes, apologized for the inconvenience, and offered us a free glass of wine while we waited.

A few regulars who didn't have reservations and were waiting for a table were very friendly and offered us some suggestions on what to order.

After a short wait we were seated and the owner was very  friendly offering insight on wine and food choices. I ended up ordering the Penne Arribiata which was hands down the best pasta I have every eaten (aside from my grandmothers spaghetti). It wasn't to heavy but was still filling and had just the right amount of spice.

We didn't really have room for dessert but everything was so good we decided we had to try the dessert as well. We tried the Panna Cotta at the owners recommendation. It was creamy sweet and delicious.

All in all, this was a great restaurant. It had a very welcoming feel, and great food, what more can you ask for. The next night we tried Gary Danko, and my girlfriend and I both agree that the food was much better at Albona.
author: Brad R.

description: We had my Mom's birthday at Albona and it was great.  The owner and his team took care everything we needed.  The food was so good and service was amazing.  Our entire party raved.  Thankfully we found this little out of the way spot because they really made everything from start to finish perfect.  Thanks again Albona for an amazing evening!
author: Paul Z.

description:
What a great find! We came by this little unassuming, but amazing and delicious restaurant for an early dinner. We were going to watch a show at Cobb's a little later in the evening.

We ordered the Minesetre stagionali ( soup of the day.) Today it was a cream of asparagus with tomato soup; but no cream was used, instead they used Yukon gold potatoes. The soup tasted light and very fresh. Delish! Then we ordered a yelp fav: Calamai al forno con salsa marinara (squid stuffed with toasted bread crumbs, parsley & garlic; roasted in an amazing, with just a hint of spiciness, marinara sauce.)  We took some of our fresh sourdough bread to scoop up the sauce, but had to restrain ourselves to save room for our entrees.
I got the wild boar pappardelle. It was good and not too heavy. We had tried the same dish at Firenze by NIght also, which was also good, but a much more savory dish, more sauce heavy.  Tony got the Stinco de videl a la Tristina (AMAZING Braised veal shank with Burgndy wine and rosemary glaze with soft polenta). This was so delicious. The meat was tender and flavorful, the meat fell off the bone. Dessert: Crema de gelato (a light as air Triple cream gelato mousse topped with Maraska cherries in Brandy - the gelato was Espresso and Vanilla, it tasted like a tiramisu mouse. YUM)

The food was great. The service was great also. The owner Michael Bruno took the time to talk to each table, whether it be newbies like us, or to the regulars. The service is attentive and nice. There were 2 elderly lady-regulars celebrating a birthday. One of them ordered the lamb, and she didn't like that it was undercooked (medium rare). So MIchael took the dish back and had them re-cook it. When she got impatient, she told them that if it still wasn't ready that she didn't want it anymore. So Michael brought out a brand new lamb for her, and apologized that it time for them to cook a new one. All the while you can hear the servers say "What can you do? You gotta keep the regulars happy." The regulars got risotto con funghi compliments of the chef, and an extra dessert with a candle (the panna cotta) in addition to their strudel because the candle would have melted in the hot strudel. You can't ask for better service than that.

This is a small intimate dinning room. The staff is friendly and attentive. The valet service is complimentary, and Michael knew which car belonged to us! It's a great find.

We will be back  - I must try the gnocchi that everyone from yelp to zagat and the onion is raving about.
author: Annie Y.

description: Food is good and not the typical fare you get at most Italian restaurants.  Service was Excellent.  There was a particularly loud table while we were there which definitely put a damper on the whole meal.  Without anyone complaining, the owner came by the other tables and apologized.  He even comped our dessert, which was completely unnecessary, but definitely ensured that we will return next time we're in the Bay area.
author: Theresa B.

description:
The best! Everyone I have ever taken with me to Albona has loved it. To be clear, this is Istrian food. Not your conventional Italian with belligerently heavy pasta, endless canned tomato sauce and flavorless cheese. Istrian food is a fusion of Italian, Croatian and Austrian, even some Greek/Eastern Mediterranean elements.  Istria is on the sea and tucked in between all of those.  (Here's Albona today http://www.istra.com/rabac/eng/labin.asp).  The food reflects the region which is a cross-roads of all of these people and places.

Start with the stuffed squid, then lamb noisettes and don't pass on the desserts, especially the (strudel de pomi) - home made apple strudle.  Everything on the menu is a home cooking recipe, the way grandma made. Not some corporate chef inspired fabrication. Now since we are nowhere near the fresh daily catch from the Adriatic Sea or delicious fruit and tasty meats from around the town of Albona, you have to accept what California grown ingredients can deliver. And that's not bad. 

Reservations are a must. Books up fast. Small and cozy. Best suited for parties of 2-4, but I've had parties of as big as 13 there. Avoid bringing a large crowd because you'll overwhelm the kitchen and miss out. It's quality not quantity at Albona. It's always busy and the small staff can get busy fast. But, this is a family operation and Michael, that's there hands-on every day, is awesome and will make sure you have the best service. 

I love this place.

A San Francisco classic. The way SF restaurants used to be, authentic. You can't go wrong and will want to return more than once to try out everything on the menu.
author: Vladimir J.

description: Food was good.  Service was great.  I had mushroom soup as a starter and the flavor and consistency were wonderful.  Dinner was Pork Loin stuffed with pork loin stuffed with sauerkraut, prosciutto, apples, and plums and served with a fantastic red cabbage sauté.  Great local restaurant.  I would make this a regular spot if I lived close by.  Very welcoming environment.
author: Doreen D.

description:
Outstanding taste!  Stopped by here thanks to other yelp reviews.  Tried the Strudel con pasta fatta in casa, and it was fantastic!  I've never had an italian dish like it.  The pasta was fresh and the prosciutto with the lappi cheese were great!

Service was very good.  The dining room is small, and it seems a reservation would be necessary on the weekend.  Being a late Tuesday night we had no problem without one.
author: Corey S.

description: First word of advice, make a reservation - this place is tiny.  But the food and the staff is wonderful!  There was a slight mishap with our reservation and they more than made up for their mistake.  They treated us like royalty and our entrees were nothing short of perfect!   I will absolutely return and recommend this place to anyone who enjoys an unusual culinary experience with a cosy atmosphere.  (ps.  i had the rabbit and it was to die for!)
author: Sherri H.

description: This place was amazing!  It's a small restaurant, but very romantic and intimate.  It was just what we were looking for on the last night of our honeymoon.  The staff was inviting and attentive.  We mentioned it was our honeymoon and Sam brought complimentary champagne and dessert for us!  We had the gnocchi for an appetizer which was cooked perfectly.  Crispy on the outside and soft on the inside.  For our entrees, I had the fillet, which was delicious, and my husband had the special which was salmon and he looooved it!  This would definitely be a place we would have to eat at again on a return trip to San Francisco.
author: Keely D.

description: The food was delicious and the wine menu was very reasonable. I would suggest this restaurant  for a date with your significant other or for when your parents are visiting, not for like, girls night out. The restaurant is quiet and intimate but not necessarily romantic. The veal shank was SO GOOD!
author: m t.

description:
Our couple friends invited us out for "a nice italian" dinner as they had  a $25 restaurant.com gift certificate for this place.  Seeing a 4.5 star review on yelp set this place up for great expectations.  

Let me start off by saying, we did have a very nice time.  The waiters were great and spent time telling us about their favorite wine pairings and attending to us nicely.  The atmosphere was cozy and relaxed.

The main disappointment must have been the veal that both boys ordered - it was a sadly presented sliver of meat that left much to be desired.  this was served with a side of sauteed mushrooms that also screamed for want of taste.

Other dishes were decent: the 4 pieces of lamb chops were done just right with a nice stack of eggplant/potato acompaniment.  I wasn't in ecstasy over them though and I would have liked to be for $27.  The veal shank over polenta was probably the best dish on the table: a generous, tasty hunk of meat.

For starters, we tried both risottos: mushroom and prosciutto - both were good, but a little firmer than I like my risotto - both the half and full portions are good sizes, but then again, you're paying entree price for the full.  The soup of the day was a blended asparagus - this I enjoyed.  The fresh bread on the table was good and I liked the texture of the whipped butter - nice and light.  

Dessert was a major let down: the strudel de pomi was an unexciting slab of slightly dried out apples in a non-descript crust with a ball of ice cream for $10+. Boo.

Anyway, with the $25 coupon, each of the 4 of us paid $50 for: wine, appetizer, entree, shared dessert and tax and tip.  Slightly overpriced in my opinion.  I would like to try the stuffed pork loin and linguini but I don't know if I really need to go back to this place with so many other places to try.  I like the homecooking style but not at fine dining prices -and if it doesn't leave me purring in comfort.
author: Mel L.

description: Its ok, little small and service is a bit slow. Food is good though!
author: Kenneth D.

description: Unbeliavable, service. Had a reservation, went in to ask if they had any suggestions on parking. Very limited in that area. So one of the staff members parked our car for us. The food and service were great!
author: Marlon R.

description:
My friends and I visited Albona back in August. Two of us were California natives and the third was visiting from Australia. We decided to splurge on a nice dinner, and after looking at reviews around our hotel we ended up here. We could not have made a better choice. 

The waitress was incredibly attentive. The moment a glass of water was empty it was refilled, and as soon as we set our menus down she came over to take our orders.

Our appetizer (soup) came out extremely quickly. It was delicious. I'm not a huge fan of tomato soup, but this had a deep, rich flavor that was amazing. All three of us ordered a chicken entree that included mashed potatoes, and we all basically licked our plates clean. The chicken was crispy yet juicy, and the sauce was swoon-worthy.

At this point the chef came out to thank us for visiting. It was great speaking with him and learning about the history of the restaurant. All in all it was a wonderful meal that I will remember. I get up to San Francisco once or twice a year and I will make sure to stop by at every visit.
author: Erica L.

description:
Went here with the family for a b-day dinner. Overall experience - great!!
The interior is very cozy/romantic. Small room with only 10 or so tables. Only one waiter who new a lot about the dishes on the menu and pairing wines. 
We had salad with caramelized figs and cheese as well as ratatouille for the appetizers to share. Very different taste but both are great!! My husband had crab-cake and cozze instead of the main dish - both he enjoyed and he's a big seafood lover ))
For main dish we had salmon (catch of the day), veal, pork and seafood pasta. All very different. Our favorite was the salmon. but other dishes were great as well.
We had a bottle of white wine (mix of chardonnay, sauvignon and pinot grigio).
For deserts - pana cotta (good, but not outstanding), gelato (good) and tiramisu (classical good).

Would go there again for an event of some kind. Really enjoyed the experience.
author: Katerina K.

description: Excellent Italian food with a twist!! Intimate & cozy with personal attention to your taste buds!! Friendly personable service and the best tirimisu I've ever had!!
author: Laura C.

description:
Three years later, I will frame my updated review with three questions: if your answer to all of them is 'never', you will have given this restaurant the highest numbers of stars. Here is why:


-How often do staff at a restaurant ask you for your coat the moment you enter?
-How often do you go to a restaurant and do not feel rushed by: 'can I take your plate away' while you are still chewing or, worse yet, your partner is still eating?
-How often does it happen that you are waiting to go to the bathroom and a waiter passing by asks you if they can help and open the door to a second bathromm to minimize your waiting?

I have seldom experienced these points elsewhere...

Foodwise, this is not the place where you'll get the usual ingredients in different shapes and forms (namely cheese, eggs, tomatoes and bread); neither is it for the strict vegetarian. Rather, it is for the worldly citizen who enjoys a res-tau-rant where soft music is a background addition to the main focus of the dining experience.

Prices are high; but valet partking is complimentary (again, a rarity).
Enjoy, San Francisco!
author: Nena G.

description: This place is great. Went here with a travelzoo voucher and we were treated amazing. I've had a lot of restaurants give sub-par service when you come in with a 1/2 off deal from groupon or travelzoo but this place was way different. Our server was very helpful explaining some dishes to us, and at the end of our meal he served us complementary port! I will definitely go back again for a special occasion.
author: Em R.

description:
Too much sauce on everything drowns any taste.

Ok - this is the first time that Yelp let me down in a serious way! I read all those wonderful reviews in Yelp and elsewhere and we were really excited about this place. Until we got the appetizers that is ...  Maybe the good things first: Yes, the service is friendly, albeit maybe a little tiny bit unprofessional, but one could call that 'family style'. And yes, free valet parking is great in SF. 

We had the 'Antipasto misto' which were ok, the 'Sardele in saor a la Veneziana' which were good (probably the best dish that night). We also had the 'Chifeleti de mia nona', those Gnocchi-style pan-fried things hailed by many reviewers here as if they were cooked in ambrosia. They are actually quite awful. They are pretty much eight deep-fried balls of mashed potatoes with a lot of sirloin sauce. It took four people to finish them all. Luckily the bottle of Montepulciano was great and pleased us enough to dissolve this disappointment quickly.

The main dishes were the 'Stinco de videl' (braised veal shank), the 'Peto de polo' (chicken breast), the 'Capriolo a la cacciatora' (venison), and the 'Brodeto de pesse' (Adriatic seafood stew). First, do not expect any vegetables, at most you get some thoroughly cooked ratatouille. Then, do not expect light or particularly fancy sauces: all were heavy, oily, brown sauces, even on the seafood stew was some sort of forest-mushroom sauce (it says red wine, balsamic-tomato sauce in the menu, which we could not identify on our dish). The sauces were so thick and plentiful that we had trouble identifying the venison as such. Additionally,  everything was very, very well cooked, if you know what I mean. After these disappointing entrees we felt we would rather have our espressi and gelati elsewhere and left without trying any deserts, something that rarely happens.

I am not sure what had happened that night. All these praising reviewers here sound, like they had eaten in a different restaurant. Maybe we just do not appreciate Istrian cuisine enough, or the chef had a really bad day, or they just had accidentally purchased a 100 gallon tank of brown sauce base and have to cook it away until the end of the month ... I don't know, but we will not try this again any time soon. It is not bad food, just not good food either. The bill for four was still two of those rare big green notes one hates to part from so much and I can think of many places where I would have been much happier spending that money.
author: Phil J.

description: The staff at Albona could not have been friendlier, I was extremely impressed.  We booked late on a Friday evening and there were two small adjoining table, which they put together for my fiancée and I so we could sit side by side.  A very thoughtful touch, especially since they were the only two tables left. The environment was very comfortable, classy and warm.  I will be back and highly recommend Albona.
author: Tony D.

description: Lovely, lovely, lovely. A very unique and great restaurant experience. Excellent service and wonderful food. Came on the recommendation of my friend Paul who's been coming here for decades. That really says something when it's been that great for that long.
author: Robert C.

description: Amazing little place! Excellent service, delicious menu, I had such a hard time choosing. The salmon was TO DIE FOR. To boot, they serve Illy coffee as well :]]
author: Elin M.

description:
After seeing the great reviews on this place I thought it would be a good call for a valentines day dinner. When I made the reservations the person on the phone did not seemed rushed or drowned out by background noise, which seems to be more and more common when calling restaurants these days--- the fact that he could actually hold a small conversation when telling me about their valentines dinner was a plus.

They have free valet which is nice (no parking to be found in the area), and the location itself is in a nice small neighborhood. Plus

The wait staff was all very courteous and nice, and our waiter (michael) did a great job recommending wine. We ordered the calamari stuffed with fish in marinara sauce appetizer, Rissoto con funghi and 3 cheese raviolis for dinner, and gelato and flan for dessert.

The calamari was out of this world, in my opinion. The squid itself had great texture comlimented by the ground up fish inside. The highlight however was the sauce--- I've never had a simple red sauce taste that good; I made sure to get extra bread just to make sure I could get it all off my plate. The girlfriend didn't seem to like the dish as much though, so YMMV?

The Risotto con funghi was good but not AMAZING. I'm not exactly sure but it seemed like all they used were normal button mushrooms--- I kind of expected some different types (maybe there were though? I'm no expert...).

The raviolis were amazing. I'd never had such a blend of flavors in a pasta dish--- the cheeses, nutmeg, raisins, pinenuts--- all were in perfect balance, taking the stage for a moment and then giving way to a new flavor. Fantastic. 

Desserts were equally amazing. The gelato was extremely creamy with VERY strong liquer soaked berrys on top. The flan was deliciously rich and left a great chocolate taste that lingered for an hour after the meal. They were even nice enough to comp the flan when they gave us the bill before accidently before realizing we had ordered 2 desserts. 

Overall, this is a great place to take someone for an upscale meal. The atmosphere is very comfortable and the food is phenomenal. Also, for the day of the event and what we got, prices were very reasonable. Great job, Albona.
author: T A.

description:
LOOK!!! This is my 2nd review... Almost a year to the date my husband & I finally get to Albona Ristorante !! We even used our dining card!
The dining area is small and would of never accommodated all 20+ friends we tried to get together. (a year ago)
Very tasty Italian food. I had the salmon, and would have it again.
The service was awesome, very attentive to the diner!!
Make reservations in advance... we lucked out! Bruno said "someone no showed", 
Give yourself time for parking also.
Enjoy!! (we did)
author: Beth R.

description:
When is an update really an update?  When something has actually changed and people need to know about it.  Like this, for instance.

Albona has always been my go-to place to take people for an amazingly impressive experience.  Fantastic food, excellent ambiance, tiny, intimate, romantic.  Plus, for....a year and half, I've been greeted by name every time I walked in the door.  If you didn't know me, you'd think I was someone important.  This past weekend, I needed a refresher in tiny, intimate and romantic, so it was time to go to Albona.  We were seated, and no sooner had the water been poured than we were given a round of proseco, "compliments of the house."  Now, it had been....almost six months since I had last visited, so I was a bit surprised.  But proseco on a hot day in SF?  Can you say, perfect?  I knew you could!

Several minutes afterward, Michael (more in just a second) wandered over, greeted wifey and I by name, and welcomed us back.  Michael then shared the big news: he had recently bought the restaurant from his uncle, Bruno (the founder).  As I told Michael (right that minute, because I am suave like that), that probably didn't increase his workload any, since he was already doing all the work as far as I could ever tell.  Laughs all around.  This is why you invite me to parties: charm, class, and wit.  Also, I usually buy.

Michael walked us through the several changes he and his chef have made to the menu, and all were very positive.  I had the special, a Muscovy duck breast with a cherry glaze, which was excellent.  Wifey had the ravioli, which we couldn't ever remember having before, and was also wonderful.  For dessert, 20-year port and a fresh fruit compote.

I've said it before and I'll say it again: Albona continues to be the most impressive restaurant in SF that you aren't aware of.  On one hand, that suits me just fine, because it means I can continue to get same-week reservations for prime dining spots.  On the other hand, I want to see this place continue to prosper.  So take my advice (for once), and go there.  And tell Michael I sent you---I need more free drinks.
author: Ben P.

description: Great place! the service and food deserves 5 stars if you love Italian this is the place to go. It's almost like sitting in someone's house dining in. We were unsure which wine to get and the waiter suggested 2 that would go great with the pasta we were getting. We got a new glass for every wine taste. Their pasta is homemade and you can taste it! Also they provided us with a complimentary dessert and what a joy. Go here it's the best place I ever tried for pasta and service
author: Malaika H.

description:
The food here is delicious! They must make their own pasta because it tasted so fresh. The service was great and the waiters were really nice. They never let my glass of water go less than half full.

The only reason I docked a star is because  me and my best friend made a reservation for 6pm on a Tuesday night, and we were there early, they didn't seat us until 6:15, even though the restaurant wasn't packed. The setting is nice and small, very cozy. I definitely recommend anyone to come, other then the lateness, the food and experience was great!
author: Annie S.

description:
I went to this restaurant by myself because I am trying to eat at all Zagat reviewed restaurants in alphabetical order and I couldn't get anyone to come with me to this one.  I approached the restaurant at 5:10PM and had a conversation with the valet person and it  went something like this:

Valet:  Are you eating here tonight?
Me:  Yes, I am.
Valet:  Are you with somebody?
Me:  No, I'm not.
Valet:  You are eating alone?
Me:  Yes, I am.
Valet:   Let me check inside to make sure they can accomodate  you.
Me:  Okay. (I wait approxiamtely 2 minutes in the freezing cold)
Valet:  They are checking right now to see if they can accomodate you.
Waiter:  (Comes outside) Did he tell you that we can't seat you?
Me:  Uhh, not exactly.

The waiter then brings me inside and the restaurant is completely empty except one family eating in the middle of the restaurant.  I couldn't believe it.  The valet made such a big stink about being able to accomodate me eating there and every single table was available.  The waiter was super nice and completely made up for the unusual experience I had outside with the valet.  I had a sauerkraut soup that was interesting and the sea bass which was the best fish I've had in a long time.  I wasn't too thrilled with the atmosphere.
author: Toni C.

description:
I am so glad that I bought a Bloomspot certificate for a 4 course meal. What made this place special is the owner/cook Sam came out and visited  each table to greet us and see how we liked the food.  I had the crab cakes - really good - like eating fresh crab with seasoning.  It is not the breaded crab cakes but lumps of crab and a good size portion. My husband had the mussels - 18 of them and all gone in a short time.  We split a pasta and had the linguini with seafood - very tasty.  For entrees  I had rack of lamb - seasoned well and very good.  My husband had the veal shank with polenta and said the meat was tender and flavorful.  For dessert we were pretty full but had the strawberry sorbet which was refreshing.  I ended up boxing up my apple strudel and had it later - it was good but not something I would crave to order again.

We loved the neighborhood and the intimate feel.  The restaurant is not very big so it made for a very intimate and relaxing evening .
author: D C.

description: I can't say enough good things about this place.  Great atmosphere, great staff and unbelievable food.  Everything we've had there in 3 visits has been amazing.  Don't miss the pear-gorgonzola appetizer or panna cotta for desert.
author: David G.

description: If I could give less than one star I would. We were one of 3 tables, should of been my first clue. Fig salad great but ALL four of our entries were bland and uninteresting.  To top it off. "Grandma's" homemade tiramisu was frozen and probably from the grocery store.  DONT  waste your money.  A HUGE disappointment.
author: Linda K.

description:
We must've came on an off night because the food was not as good as what the reviews would indicate.  When we arrived at the restaurant, we were greeted by a friendly staff.  My first impression of the decor was that it was a bit outdated and plain.

We started off by ordering the soup of the day which was a creamy asparagus soup that is not made with cream.  The waiter told us the creamy texture of the soup was made from pureed potatoes.  There were a few chunks of asparagus and croutons.  The soup was quite unique and tasty.  Next was the arugula  salad with prosciutto.  This salad was actually my favorite dish.  The prosciutto had a nice color and texture to it.  It was kind of fresh yet dried.  Apparently, it had a white truffle vinaigrette in it, which was very good.  So, we're off to a good start.

But then it kind of fizzled a bit when the main course came around.  Our last two dishes were the penne and  arosto de coniglio aka rabbit.  My friend read in the Yelp reviews that the rabbit was good.  I figured if I was going to eat a cute cuddly little rabbit, it better taste good!  Sad to report that it was the contrary.  I'm sorry little rabbit.  The meat was too dry.  I'm not sure if that's the texture of rabbit meat since it's not something I usually eat, but it had the texture of an overcooked chicken breast.  The seasoning was a bit too sweet for my liking.  The rabbit was served with polenta which tasted and looks like grits to me.  As for the penne, eh, it's penne.  Nothing special.  

Lastly came the dessert.  This will either make or break the experience which it did neither.  We got the panna cotta and the tiramisu.  The tiramisu was pretty good, not spectacular, but good.  I didn't know much about the panna cotta since I've never really had it before, but it did not impress.  So, in that sense, the dessert didn't help the cause nor did it hurt it.

Overall, I give this place 3 stars for the food, then add one star for the service, and take one star away for the price to taste ratio so we're back at 3.
author: David T.

description:
This is a review by a vegetarian

Do you like stories? doesn't matter. Bruno is going to tell you a story about the food, about Istria, about how he and his food came from Istria, perhaps even Snow White and the Seven Istrian Dwarves eating their deep-fried gnocchi in sirloin sauce.

Personally, I don't mind the story part of a meal if it comes in between ordering and food delivery. Bruno tells his prior to ordering which makes me antsy but entertained the DCs.
He's good about identifying the tables' veggies and telling which dishes are compliant.

The salad was nothing special. Skip it. Bland and hardly dressed (not "lightly" dressed, hardly dressed). The ravioli with fried sage and butter was popping with flavor, though a little on the small side. DCs fish was just ok, the veal was raved over. Desserts were satisfactory but made me wish I'd stopped at XO truffle before they closed.

3.5 stars for food. Half a star for having free valet parking and for good service (apart from the story telling timing)
author: Bob R.

description:
Our UK colleague was in town so we treated him to a night out (or in) town of drinking and dinner.  

We were open to try something new until it was suggested that we try an Italian place up in North Beach to try out.  It was a long 25 minute walk up to find this place, but it would've been worth walking an hour for.  I could say a million wonderful things about this place, but I'll use asterisks to make my point quickly and efficiently:

*No waiting for a table on a Tuesday night--there were only two other parties beside us.  Made for great conversation.  However on a weekend a reservation would be recommended.
*Nice decor inside.  Clean, well arranged, respectable decoration for a relatively small place.  
*Great servers/waiters.  Our guy was incredibly friendly, knowledgeable, and definitely sold us on the selections.  They even called cabs for us afterward.
*AMAZING appetizers.  We got the squid and sardines and they were the most amazing squid and sardines ever.
*Equally amazing food.  My lamb was very well prepared, and I would love to try something else next time.
*And the desserts, oh man.  I'm not a big dessert guy but the gelato and apple strudel were amazing.  And even though I was completely full I still found room for these amazing dishes.

Only negative I could think to give this place is the price...however I didn't have to put anything in to the $300+ bill that was split among the 5 of us, so, five strong stars it is..
author: Tien N.

description: Had a coupon deal for 4 course meal for 2.   Dined on a Sunday evening, which I understand is one of their less busy nights, so the vibe was particularly intimate and romantic.  I believe it was Sam who waited on us -- he was in a chef's coat and when I asked whether he was the owner he said he was the one who pays the bills.  He was very gracious; thanked us for using the coupon deal.  He gave  us wine recommendations and everything we ordered was wonderful.:  scallops and gnocchi for  appetizers, mushroom risotto to share, veal shank and lamb chops as the entrees, tiramisu and biscotti (which we took along with us since we were so full) for dessert.   Our server's passion for  his restaurant and its food  was obvious and infectious. Just a delightful dining experience.
author: Lorraine M.

description:
OMFG!!!!  An absoletely amazing meal!  Everything we had was excellent at a minimum, and some things were an 11.  We has the pastina en brodo soup was a 9. The arugala-walnut-apple-prosciutto salad a 10.  The saffron prosciutto risotto was an 11, and second only to a risotto I had in NYC, and then only because the one in NY had shaved fresh white truffle on it.  The veal shank was a 10 and the pork loin in brown sauce, stuffed with apple and mild sauerkraut was not only an 11, but maybe in the top 10 entres of my life. .remarkably, they also dont gouge you on the price of the wine  A truly unforgettable meal. 10 stars!

Just to show I'm not a shill, the bread was so-so, the tables very small and the space cramped. You are very close to the adjacent tables.

About the risotto, it is an 11 but it's also very rich. I don't think I could have eaten a whole serving. I suggest an appetizer- sized serving to share. It was plenty.
author: Vernon M.

description:
Hidden away at the intersection of North Beach and FIsherman's Wharf, Albona gets none of the tourists from either place. They fill fairly rapidly with locals.  I receive a warm greeting to a bright room and am steered well by the proprietor.  

A soup of corn and potatoes in a chicken broth is so thick it is nearly porridge.  Nice, and it would be even nicer when the weather turns colder.  A half order of seafood linguine is bounteous.  The pasta is al dente but some of the seafood is mealy,  the scallops on the other hand stringy.  Just OK.

Pork loin is stuffed with sauerkraut, prosciutto, accompanied by apples and plums and served with red cabbage sauté.  The pork is overdone, and the cabbage and sauerkraut are redundant tastes.  The apples and plums are a nice, sweet counterpoint but the sauce below the pork is overly reduced.  Too bad.

This food is a throwback.  Heavy whilst the rest of California has gone light.  With some up-dating Albona could be very much  better.
author: David D.

description:
We were looking for a small, intimate Italian restaurant and after searching Yelp found Albona. It lived up to all the very positive reviews we read before. 
The staff was incredibly warm and attentive. The menu is based upon unique dishes the kitchen prepares to perfection. The chef was extremely friendly and shared his recipe secrets with us. 
The calamari appetizer was very good and prepared unlike anything we had before. We then had the stuffed strudel made with homemade pasta, a soft cheese, with a tomato flavored béchamel sauce...excellent.   The two entrees were still the highlight...the sauerkraut stuffed pork loin was tender, the kraut very tasty but subtlety flavored, resting on the most delicious meat flavored gravy; Red cabbage on the side. My husband had the rabbit, which was moist, tender, tasty with sautéed polenta in another wine based, slightly sweet sauce that complemented the meat. 
We were too full for dessert, but the chef brought out one of his wife's dessert creations...I forget the name but she used fresh vanilla bean, in a flan like dessert, but not as sweet. Again great, wish we had saved more room to finish it!
We both highly recommend this restaurant...bring your appetite, you won't be disappointed!  They have a nice international and domestic wine list to choose from.
author: Mary M.

description:
Sadly did not live up to the high expectations set by the 70+ rave reviews on Yelp. Took my parents for my mom's bday. Looked like a good pick in North Beach (we needed something close to Beach Blanket Babylon).

We were the first to arrive when the restaurant opened at 5:00. Even though there were only 3 tables full while we were there, service was somewhat slow. We might've been okay with this if we didn't have to be at BBB by 6:30. Still, if I'm hungry, and I'm sitting there with my menu closed like I'm ready to order, then please, come take my order and let's get this meal going.

The food was just okay. None of the entrees were interesting, delicious, or well-executed enough to bring us back for a return visit. More specifically, the meat part was usually fine -- well cooked and pretty tasty -- but then taken down a notch by the uninspired, bland side dishes that came with them, like totally tasteless polenta, and the kind of boring, lifeless steamed vegetables that make me think, no wonder Americans hate their veggies. Also, a couple of our dishes came in sauces that had already started to form a crusty layer on top by the time they arrived at the table... honestly, how hard can it be to time the entrees right when we were the first table to be served that evening?

This also feeds my pet-peeve with higher-end, "authentic" Italian restaurants... or I just don't understand them. We were trying to avoid the type of touristy spaghetti and fettucine alfredo type stuff served on the main stretch of North Beach, but alternatives like this place are totally non-descript and boring to me, and not worth the extra cost.
author: Jen Y.

description: I saw this place on trip advisor and yelp.  We picked it because my parents, girlfriend, and I were staying in the fisherman's wharf area and wanted a good italian place to eat at.  What a great choice!  What amazed me is how they lived up to their expectations.  Being a small business owner, I was glad to see Sam (Owner/Chef) come by through out our dinner to see that we were enjoying it.  It started off with bread that seemed to come right out of the oven to our table.  We had the pear salad, arugula salad, and gnocchi to begin.  Impressive.  It didn't stop there.  I had the fish special which was delicious.  My Mom and Girlfriend had the strudel con pasta which is a delicious baked dish.  My dad had the adriatic stew which was delightful.  Then we had desert that blew us away.  It was a great night from great food, good company, and great service.  I would highly recommend going to this restaurant.
author: Ryan T.

description: Love Albona!  Love, love, love Albona!  Been here several times over several years.  Last night was among the better visits.  Table was ready when we arrived (that had been an issue the last couple of visits.)  Service was spot on, and the food was delicious.  My spouse commented that, but for a few specials, the menu is largely unchanged over the years.  But really, that's OK.  I  am a big fan of the dishes I have here, and would be disappointed to see them gone.  Getting a taxi afterwards was much easier than in the past as well.  All in all, another great night at Albona.  When people ask me where in the city to eat, and they don't want to spend a fortune, this is where I send them.
author: J.D. W.

description:
I just can't get there on this place.  We clearly were there on an off day - perhaps the chef had a stand-in or whatever, but the food was mediocre at best and the ambiance and service were certainly nothing special either.

The mushrooms in our soup hadn't been cleaned well enough, hence there was a thin layer of fine sand in the bottom of the bowl.  The scallops were fantastic as a mid-course.  But the main courses ranged from my wife's pork loin (good but definitely not fantastic) to my ravioli with a meat sauce that had definitely been under a heat lamp way too long.
author: Bert R.

description: I been to this restaurant a few times when I happen to be in the city. The ambiance in the restaurant is small and homey. The food is yummy and melts in your mouth. I love their gelato! I will continue to go back to this fine establishment.
author: Sherry M.

description:
Sunday night we got lucky, Albona was open!
Where do we even begin...we were greeted by Joe who is usually making magic in the kitchen. Along side his mentor, Samuel who is a true genius. Jesus, our waiter was so knowledgable and lovely.

After toasting with a great glass of wine the journey began.
We tried the asparagus soup, topped with croutons and a dollop of creme fraiche, great flavor. An Arugula salad accompanied by Granny Smith apples, mushrooms with a white truffle dressing unbelievable taste. Our entrees, risotto with saffron and prosciutto, three cheese ravioli's with pine nuts, golden raisins with a sage butter sauce. 

Incredible dinner rest assure it didn't stop there. We finished with a 
Tiramisu that was made by Samuel's wife. Oh my goodness this was surely a night we won't forget. We look forward to visiting again soon. We will just have to make sure we don't eat for at least a day or two.

Thank you Albona we loved it!!!!!
author: Annette P.

description:
4.5 Stars

What a fabulous neighborhood gem! I stumbled upon it a few weeks back while paroozing some Yelp reviews and after reading peoples responses, vowed that I would try it within the next month. 

The rigatoni with pork ragu sauce was the best pasta dish I'd had in a long time. It came out piping hot in a ceramic bowl covered in melted mozzarella cheese. My friend and I shared that dish along with the lamb, which also tantalized the taste buds. However, (and this is my only complaint of the evening) when they brought it out it had already cooled off considerably. I expect that when you're at a high quality restaurant such as this one, that they don't leave it out long enough to get cold before it's served. The chocolate tart was all sorts of yummy. My friend and I were fighting over the last bite.

The service was impeccable - Michael and company were fabulous. The owner of the restaurant was gregarious and friendly, thanking us personally for dining at the restaurant. He was also the first to greet us when we arrived.

Overall, it was a fantastic experience. I'm not entirely sure that everyone knows about this place yet, but I have a feeling they will soon!
author: Julia N.

description:
ORDER: two new items (that weren't on the online menu at http://www.albonarestaurant.com/menus.html#), so I can't really remember the exact names of our dishes. One was a roasted lamb with assorted vegetables in a red wine sauce (~$29) and the other was a thick pasta served with chicken, assorted vegetables, and peas (~$18). 

TIP: Reservations recommended

GOOD:
+ Service: Host and servers were very friendly. 
     + He asks if you want to hang up your coat and is attentive. However, there were times that they seemed a bit short staffed because it was a bit difficult to get their attention when more customers start rolling in, but it makes sense for a smaller sized restaurant.
+ Atmosphere: was nice. Cozy. 
+ Parking: Valet parking service available, which is good if you're driving here because street parking is terrible. However, we walked here from the pier, which is just fantastic that it's within walking distance.

BAD:
- Atmosphere: The restaurant is a bit small/tight, so I wouldn't recommend coming with a large group. It's more for small intimate dates.
- Food: I hate to say it, but food was only so-so. I came here with the thought that the food was going to blow my mind!!! and for ~$30, I was disappointed that I barely thought a "Huh. Interesting."
     - The pasta tastes like chicken soup. They should have kept their seafood linguine.
     - The lamb was nice, but I guess I like the gamey taste of lamb and the red wine made the gameyness disappear. It was like eating 8 small pieces of beef filet mignon. Perhaps it's just my preference, but I like white wine sauce with my lamb because it enhances the natural flavor instead of mask it to be boring.
     - The plating didn't have any wow-factor whatsoever either. It was bland and predictable.
- Parking: There's no private lot or anything to park here. At least none that I've seen.


OVERALL: It was a nice experience, but for those portions and those prices I was fairly disappointed my mind wasn't blown. I guess I was under the wrong impression after reading others' 5-star rating.
author: Yuchii C.

description:
If I could give 6 stars I would.  Here's why:

1)  A half a block from home  :)

2)  Amazing food without the crowds, expense or bells and whistles of the famous fancy spots.  Can often get in without a res.  

3)  Unique Istrian cuisine you wont find anywhere else.  Italian and Austro-Hungarian influences (among others), for example:

4)  Pork loin stuffed with prosciutto, sauerkraut, caramelized onions, etc.  This dish is amazing.

5)  Good, affordable wine selection.

6)  Service.  Much has been said about Bruno, but his nephew Mike is taking over the restaurant in 2008 and is fantastic in his own right.  Knowledgeable, helpful, funny and informative without being intrusive or overbearing.  

A perfect choice for a delicious, unpretentious intimate meal.
author: Brad C.

description:
What's not to love about Albona?  The moment we stepped through the door, we were warmly greeted by the owner Bruno, who immediately made us feel like family.

The dining room is a dimly lit cozy space, in my opinion a great setting for a date. The lighting makes everyone look absolutely fabulous and there are no distractions offering safe harbor from bad conversation or terrible chemistry...optimal conditions for anyone to judge whether or not the person sitting across from him/her really makes the cut.  No pretense anywhere to be found, just delicious food and impeccable service.   It was as if  Mike, our server, was an old friend.  The type of guy you want to share a couple of cocktails with and introduce to your single hot friends.  

I could've eaten two more plates of our pan-fried potato gnocchi appetizer.  My entree, the pork loin stuffed with sauerkraut, prosciutto, apples, and plums accompanied by a red cabbage saut  made me do a discreet little dance in my seat.  None of the flavors overpowered the dish but, rather, together worked in harmonious splendor .  My husband and I polished off a bottle of wine and still managed to have dessert, but the bill was still very reasonable.  

I totally recommend this place.
author: Ann L.

description: I've been here twice and will continue to go every time I am in the City. To start, the gnocchi were amazing in a perfect gravy. I was lucky to catch their seared salmon (only if they've received a shipment from the Columbia River), which, with it's crispy skin, was as good as I've ever eaten and I eat salmon a lot. Last time, I had the lamb...still drooling thinking about that meaty delight.
author: George D.

description:
By far the highlight was the Strudel con pasta fatta in casa.  Think tender, gourmet, lasagnaesque.  Or, ravioli crossed with melt-in-your-mouth panna cotta, crossed with schnitzel.  

After this I needn't have eaten any more, but even so the main dish (Involtin de porco con capuzi garbi e prosuto - pork stuff with sauerkraut and other goodies) was tasty and I'm *almost* glad I stuffed myself.  

The service was attentive, and I appreciated chatting with Michael, the founder Bruno's nephew.  Also appreciate the out-of-the-way-yet-close-to-everything location.  Will be back!
author: Carlton S.

description: The restaurant is a small neighborhood affair with white table cloths and friendly staff.  The wine was wonderful, the carmelized pears with cheese appetizer was unique and very good, and my rabbit was okay.  The rabbit sauce was too heavy with a strong vinegar taste.  The meat was not tender and the plate could have used some more vegetables.  My husband enjoyed his veal shank and polenta.  I can't say that this is exceptional cuisine, but it is good and the restaurant was lively and I enjoyed myself.
author: Christine S.

description:
Go there if you are not on a diet and want to eat the full course, other wise you will be insulted!

I invited my sister and her husband from LA to this restaurant and we went there for Saturday Dinner, we had booked before but had to wait 15 min. for the table...how embarrassing...
After taking the order the waiter pointed to me that YOU WANT JUST AN APPETIZER.......how embarrassing... 
My husband had the lamb which was tasteless, my sister had arrabiata with penne which was good and her husband had a tasteless breaded chicken....how embarrassing...

The Wine was good and the owner was nice, but the whole experience was Terrible!
author: asal s.

description:
Wow! very surprised. The interior is not much to look at but the food is amazing! I have Italian family that cook well so I find it is seldom that an Italian restaurant catches my attention. This cuisine is more accurately Croatian-Italian. Beautifully done, kind, humble waitstaff, seafood, antipasti, pasta, seafood, sardines, all perfection. Definitely a must try for an excellent dinner. Alas! there is good Italian in North Beach.

BTW- the waiter was amazing, he poured us wines off of the glass menu and treated us like gold, it was definitely worth taking a trip again and would recommend.
author: J B.

description:
I rarely give 5 stars, but this restaurant kicks serious butt.  I had a lamb shank and it was bar none the best lamb I've ever had, and probably one of the best-prepared meat I've ever tasted.  The low-lit atmosphere in its small dining room is perfect for small parties---don't expect to seat 20 of your bestest friends in here.  I spoke to Bruno, the owner and originator, over the phone and he was very polite and helpful.  Reservations were easy, and they included free valet parking.  Other people's meals at our table were also very good in terms of taste and quality.  Definitely pair your meal with some wine and just take it easy.  I had a creme brulee dessert and was very pleased with that too.  Definitely a place worth checking out.

Times visited: 1
author: Amy L.

description: We dropped in on our way through San Francisco to Sonoma.  I wasn't expecting much but I was delighted by the personal service, and menu suggestions.  The food was delicious and very unique.  Ask your waiter for advice and try the house specials - you won't be disappointed!  It is old school service in an old school atmosphere.
author: K. D.

description:
The food is certainly an interesting combination of Eastern European and Italian and the owner is not nearly as annoying as many people make him out to be.  Well...I don't know that I needed such a specific and detailed explanation of exactly how they make their mushroom soup, but other than that, he generally left us alone.

Know where you're going...if you blink, you'll miss this place.

I wasn't totally blown away by the flavors or the atmosphere, particularly for the price.  It was good and solid and homey, though, and I suppose that's what counts.
author: Frankie D.

description:
Awesome food.....check

Awesome staff......check

parking.................check

tourists?..............no check! 

SWEET! 

But seriously folks.  This place is really good.  The fried gnocchi (as mentioned before) are to die for.  Molten yummy goodness.  I almost had a Rachel Ray moment right in the restaurant...YUM-O.  Fortunately I kept it in check because I was all boozed out from the delicious wine they served and was totally charmed by Michael, the waiter.  I tried everyone's food at my table and all dishes were very good.  Their halibut was superb and I don't even like fish generally.  This would be a great restaurant for an anniversary or date.  It's small and intimate.  It's also someplace I'd feel comfortable at with my family.  

You will probably need a res with a group.
author: Katie E.

description: We were visiting from the east coast and chose Albona based on reviews and what an AMAZING choice it was!  When asked if we ate good food on our trip, Albona is the restaurant we talk about.  The savory potato gnocchi appetizer is a must!  The fresh salads are big enough to share.  The pasta is perfectly cooked and seafood is deliciously fresh.  Make sure you save room for desert because they are homemade by the owner's wife and are to die for!  We indulged in both the strudel and panna cotta.  The servers make you feel right at home and are helpful in choosing the perfect dish.  Our next trip to San Fran will definitely involve a return to Albona!
author: Michelle M.

description:
We went here using the bloomspot coupon.

The staff was very nice and accommodating, but unfortunately the food was lacking.

We had to send back the veal, as it tasted very off- kind of iron-y like liver.

They were very gracious about it, but overall the food was average and I likely would not take a trip back.
author: Saikat P.

description:
We had a fantastic dinner at Albona the other night. It was our first time at this restaurant -- we had tickets to a show in North Beach and picked Albona because it seemed like the only place in North Beach where Yelp reviewers hadn't resoundingly complained about the service and/or food. Albona has pretty consistently positive reviews, and I must say that I totally agree with everyone who raved about this place. 

To start, I had the basic dinner salad (which was perfectly fine but not necessarily anything to write home about). My husband had the fig salad which he loved. I had a little taste and I agree, it was great. Only complaint about it is that it's pretty huge, so if you ate the whole thing, you might spoil your appetite for your entree. Which you really truly don't want to do... we both had the Strudel con pasta fatta in casa  and OMFG it was freaking AMAZING. Delicious pasta with proscuitto and cheese and tomato cream sauce in a piping hot casserole dish. Sooo tasty. 

The staff was super friendly and attentive. 

I'd definitely go back next time I'm in the area... loved it.
author: R D.

description:
I thought this place was only just OK, when we tried it for the first time.

I had sardine appetizer (very good), and the rack of lamb in mustard sause. The lamb was good, but came to the table a bit cold. My husband had the gnocchi in sirloin sauce (excellent!) and the risotto w/saffron and prociutto. That was just ok -- a little too al dente, and also not piping hot. Not sure what happened -- maybe the servers didn't bring the food when there are ready.

Overall, much better Italian choices in the city.
author: Judy D.

description:
Went here on Valentine's Day with my girlfriend and I have to say that this place was five stars all the way.  The ambiance of the restaurant was very inviting and the service was great from the very start.  It was elegant, but you almost felt as though you were in someone's home because there was a very personal touch to everything they did.

It was a pre-set menu with four courses that gave us multiple options for each course.  All the dishes were great, but a few stood out as truly amazing.  

First off, the Ortolana, or grilled eggplant, was fantastic.  I was a little hesitant since I normally don't like eggplant, but I could have eaten two more of these appetizers by myself.  

For our entrees, we had the strudel con pasta fatta in casa and stinco de videl a la triestina (veal).  The strudel won the main course battle, but be forewarned, it is VERY RICH and filling.  We were already getting full by the time this dish came around and we were unable to finish it between the two of us.  The flavors from the strudel were great, but it was a little too much to have as your only dish.  I'd recommend sharing this dish with someone else who ordered something different.

For dessert, we had the crema de gelato and the bonet.  The bonet was good, but the gelato was amazing.  I mean, really, truly amazing.  We were both stuffed already but we somehow managed to finish it.  I don't know how to describe it any other way...you really just have to try it for yourself.

Overall, this was one of the best restaurant experiences I've had in recent memory.  I'll definitely be back next time I'm in San Francisco!
author: Dustin L.

description:
We came here after an early show at Cobb's and ended up having a great dining experience.  The space is cozy and very "homey"...It felt like we were having dinner at a friends house....The wait staff was friendly, fast and attentive...Micheal was great....always took a moment to check on us.....

On to the food: For an appetizer, we had grandmother's specialty: the pan-fried potato gnocchi in a brown sirloin sauce...very tasty and the portions were perfect....tater tots this ain't.....

For the Entree, I had the Stinco de videl a la Triestina" the 
braised veal shank in a Burgundy wine sauce and  served with polenta....that dish was so good I could have had another serving..The shank was tender and full of flavor ....I could have gnawed on that bone all night....and there was a little marrow oozing out...yum!!!!.

My wife had the one of their specials of the day ....Snapper in white wine sauce...amazing as well...fish was perfectly cooked and the sauce had a whiff of the fish...nice!!!

Didn't have dessert...wife was too full....so at least we have something to look forward to on our next visit.
author: Poncho M.

description: Had a wonderful meal at Albona this evening following a long business day.  Tanya was a delight, very personable and knowledgeable about the menu.  She sold me on the soup of the day, a tomato cream made without cream or butter and it was delicious! She also sold me on the strudel pasta which was unique and wonderful.  Samuel, the owner, spent some time with us and was very hospitable. He makes a mean chocolate flan that was one of the most delicious deserts I've ever had.  I will definitely return to this charming restaurant.
author: Terri W.

description:
North Beach has longed been panned for being a tourist trap with very few legitimate good dining options.  So when you find a great restaurant off the beaten path (read: not on Columbus between Broadway & Union), it's damn near a cause for celebration.  

This is a quaint family-owned restaurant that truly embraces the concept of a dining experience.  From the moment I walked in, I was greeted warmly and led to my table.  As my habitually late friends didn't get there for another 15 minutes, the wait staff went out of their way to make sure that I was comfortable (offered drinks, gave me a menu to peruse, etc.) while I awkwardly sat by myself at a five person table.  I must have looked like a total loser.  Awesome.

Once my friends got there, the waiter (who was also the same person who greeted me) told us their specials and got us started with some wine.  He was extremely knowledgeable and had a very cool, relatable personality.  

When our food got there, it was soooooo good.  I ordered the pork loin which was fantastic.  My friend who ordered the rack of lamb special was totally in his happy place.  I took a bite (or two or three) of someone else's veal shank which was excellent as well.  To be honest, there wasn't anything that I tried that wasn't delicious.  

Turns out our waiter/greeter is also the owner.  Bruno (who I've read tons about from other Yelpers) has apparently retired, and Michael, his nephew has taken over the business.  From the food to the ambiance to the overall dining experience, Albona does everything perfectly.  I can't wait to come back!
author: Norm U.

description:
This place sounded interesting from a little research I had done, looking for a place near North beach with some old world flair but not a tourist trap  or the latest trendy spot. The key was the  proprietor and long time owner , Bruno, who is gracious, warm and welcoming. 
He made everything sound superb  and when it was served it was. That is the magic of Albona, the food is very good, don' t get me wrong , but the ambiance,the attention, the service and presentation make it so much more special.
They are extremely accommodating, explaining  to the very last detail the preparation history,  differences between the Italian version and if you are not sure what to order, Bruno will fix you up with the perfect sampling of his best dishes.
I have been dining in San Francisco for 23 years, and this guy is up there with the best of them as a world class restaurateur.
author: Aaron Z.

description: First and only (ie last) time here.  Had the scallops (average) appetizer.  Had the seafood risotto for main course.  It was the blandest thing I've had in a while.  Almost no taste to the point I put salt on it, and I never think to put salt on anything.  Risotto was really pretty bad.
author: Richard Y.

description:
I liked how stoked the owner "Bruno" was when, while confirming my reservation, he informed me that they had a free valet. A definite perk, granted.

I have been within 20 yards of this place a hundred times and never heard of it. And that is the beauty of it. Quiet. The server, Michael, was extremely gracious, totally catered to our pace, displayed excellent knowledge of the food and vino, and even slid us the old hook up. 

The scoop.. The gnochi, the gelato, and the Nebbiolo (in no particular order) were both quite memorable. The lamb, risotto, sardines, and salad were good. Prices? Wine 22-70$ and pasta/entrees 13-24$.

Bottom line... thank the food gods for an ancient (21 years old) hole in the wall that serves up a great alterna-Italian (Istrian) meal,  throws in a valet, and (wait for it...) is not a scene.
author: Jeremi M.

description:
Loved this place!
We visited after a long walking tour up and down the hills of San Francisco and we were hungry.  To be honest, the restaurant didn't look like much from the outside, especially compared to the cute pictures on the website.  But from the moment we stepped inside, we had a flawless, special experience.  We were greeted, seated and served by the owner himself.  The place is small and cozy, it was pretty busy even though it was a weekday.  The owner took lots of time to explain the menu to us, highlighting certain dishes and returned often to check in with us.  We had the soup, gnocchi, penne arrabbiata and ravioli filled with raisins and all the dishes were so delicious, perfectly seasoned, fresh and warm and service was very fast.  After we were done eating, we continued to chat about our recent trip to Italy because the food reminded me so much of a meal we had eaten in Maranello, Northern Italy.  (I don't think the man was Italian though, actually, lol)  Also, we mentioned right away that we had a restaurant.com certificate, and we were still treated very well, even though I am sure they didn't make much money on us.  We greatly recommend the restaurant and will be back soon.
author: Susanne B.

description:
Really I would have given 4.5 stars but if I have to choose between 4 and 5, I will round up.

We were going to Cobbs so I wanted to find a restaurant on the northern side of North Beach.  I asked a coworker and was given this among other suggestions.  I chose this because of the location really.  All of the suggestions were 4+ stars on Yelp so I wasn't going to go wrong.  Anyway, we ordered off of the Yelp suggestions and was pleasantly surprised by how good everything was.  Bruno was a crackup and our waiter was really friendly.  The supporting staff was extremely attentive too.

We had: 

We stared with a glass of Prosecco with appitizers and brought one of our bottles of zinfandel for dinner

we ate:
minestre stagionali - celery potato soup (shared) - AMAZING
chifeleti de mia nona con sugo de carne al cumn (shared) - REALLY AMAZING
strudel con pasta fatta in casa (shared) - HOLY SHIT AMAZING
braseola de  porco con capuzi garbi e prosuto (Liz) -  I enjoyed the bite I had
lombo de agnel ai ferri (Me) - Lamb was perfectly cooked the sauce didn't detract from the meat but didn't add to it either.  The vegis were a bit over done thus limp and soggy (causing my 1/2 star deduction - what can I say, I like raw or slightly cooked vegis)

We WILL be back and will bring friends here in the future.

Bruno's parting words for us, "Thank you and have a good life".  It felt like we were leaving a friends house after a dinner party, not a restaurant.  It was a very warm and inviting atmosphere and Bruno is one hell of a character - it was a blast to see him chatting with each table.
author: Aberdo G.

description: Definitely a neighborhood gem. Small, intimate, romantic and the food is excellent. Many of the reviews mention Eddie, but our server was Jose. He did introduce us to Eddie though and I told him he is very popular on Yelp, LOL. Jose was friendly, professional and attentive. My mom and I shared the gnocchi which was outstanding, we both had rack of lamb and shared the apple strudel for dessert. Delicious food, great service from all of the staff and wonderful ambiance, what more could you ask for?
author: Susan B.

description: Every dish we had here was delicious. We had the stuffed calamari, stuffed pork loin, rack of lamb, and dark chocolate flan. The only one thing I would say I did not like was the amaretto on the flan, other than that, all the dishes were delicious and a perfect portion. The portions weren't too big or too small. The service was good here too.
author: Cindy C.

description:
One of the top places I've been to in North Beach as far as Italian restaurants goes. My boyfriend had the rabbit and I had this pasta, prosciutto, cheese, breadcrumb baked thingy with a cream tomato sauce that was to die for. It's a very small place so you have to get a reservation, and its kind of hard to spot from the street (between houses and not very noticeable).  

The people who run the place are very nice and attentive and you feel right at home. The menu isn't huge so don't expect a lot of variety but there is enough to be satisfactory.
author: Brittney E.

description:
We had an amazing meal here last night.  The restaurant is small and comfortable.  It feels like more of a neighborhood joint compared to a lot of the touristy places in North Beach.

Michael is the owner and recently took over the business from his uncle.  Last time I was here, he was just starting to transition in. Since then he has made a few changes to the menu and promised a few more changes on the way - he's trying to update the menu a bit and adding a bit more seafood.

We were a large group and starving so asked our waiter for recommendations for appetizers to share as soon as we sat down.  We ended up with:

* Pan-fried gnocchi in brown sirloin sauce - the house specialty.  They melted in our mouths...so good.
* Peperonata - a mixture of vegetables, capers, olives and raisins.  Definitely good and a little different, but not as memorable as the rest of what we ate.
* Scallops - they were small and came 4 to an order.  I don't usually like scallops but liked these.
* Fried sardines - one of my friends said they were the highlight of her night!

As for entrees, we had several home runs:

* Strudel con pasta fatta in casa - the house specialty of a pasta roll filled with cheese and prosciutto with bread crumbs.  So tasty, so good.
* Seafood linguini - this is one of the new dishes that Michael added and the dish I ordered.  Simply amazing.  It overflowed with seafood - clams, fish, shrimp, mussels... The sauce was a white wine, tomatoes, garlic and chili and was bit spicy but not overwhelming.  

Other folks ordered the veal shank and seafood stew, but I didn't get a chance to try it since they were at the other end of the table (and I was so focused on my pasta dish!)

We ordered two desserts, which were fine but not necessarily highlights of the night.

Service was simply amazing.  They were attentive and helpful and continued to check in and answer questions about the food throughout the meal.

With roughly 1 appetizer and 1 entree per person, a couple of desserts and several bottles of wine the meal came to about $60 per person.  Not bad value for the quality and overall dining experience. 

I will be back, if only for the seafood linguini. It was THAT good.
author: Todd S.

description:
Warning: it's been quite a while since I've been, but the fam used to frequent. 

Albona offers cuisine as close to Croatia as SF gets (as far as I know), and since my dad is from there, discovering Albona 10+ years ago was a treasure.

Walking in the first thing I recall was the free valet, even though there was plenty of parking all around. Next were the projects across the street. Well that explained the free valet, but sparked important convo and understanding of what was really happening. Over time as we got to know B and his wife (who randomly taught at the school behind dad's casa), it hit me that having his restaurant in a place with no foot traffic, not so desirable surroundings, and cheap rent represented so much more than a dining establishment trying to survive. Albona represented perseverance, cultural diversity, and community awareness in an area in which the city was attempting to hide the unpleasantries. Well Bruno didn't give a shit about unpleasantries and set up shop. Since eating here I never knock a spot based on location, nor do I judge food by the view....I leave that to those real estate folks.

Dinners at Albona tended to last at least 3 hours. Between Bruno and my dad it was really hard to get food on the table between their endless chatter. As they reminisced I actually learned a lot about where I come from through food, which is a huge part of why I heart food and travel today.  

Oh yeah, the food! Albona's cuisine fuses regional classics from Italy, Croatia and Istria with local Cali ingredients. This results in tasty concoctions I find nostalgic, while heavier than my mom's cooking. We used to fight over the  pan-seared gnocchi, while the melt in your mouth lasagna from homeade pasta, bechemel and prosciutto is responsible for the few extra pounds I gained around age 15 (sooo worth it). Although the menu may have changed, I bet Bruno is still the same crazy, fun, loud, cool man he was back in the day (along with his lovely wife).

Thanks Albona for the sweet and savory memories.
author: debbie h.

description:
OK, when was the last time you went to a restaurant and walked out having had a blast? A BLAST -- not having been bowled over by the decor, or the "ambiance", or the scene, or tiny plates of odd fusions -- but having just had an old fashioned daggum good-ass time? 

I seem to recall seeing Bruno's feet, or at the very least his socks -- which isnt what one might generally expect when dining out -- but it was part of a funny story he was telling as we (a large group of about 10 folks) were sitting down to our first (and hopefully not last) meal at this charming little gem. Bruno was howl and an excellent tour guide through his menu and wine list, and oh yeah, the food was fantastic. Check it out
author: Sean G.

description:
I'm not a fan of italian food.  But I recommend this place to anyone-- if only to meet Bruno, who is the most energetic, charismatic 70 year old-- a true inspiration that will make you want to eat pasta and sip on wine every night.

If the butternut squash soup is the special, you MUST try it.
author: Zuzzi E.

description:
Best italian in SF?
Despite the fact that I don't usually like italian food, this place offered an great dining experience. 
Fried gnocchi was to die for.
Order staffed pork loin! I think it is the best entree in the menu. 
Great service with good wine. They gave us complimentary champagne and kept me in a great mood.
author: Mika G.

description: Our favorites were: layered baked pasta with proscuittto and gnocchi -- though it was not your not traditional pasta - more similar to potato croquettes. Salmon clean and simple and there was delicious caponata. I recommend it if you are in the mood from something different with a quiet atmosphere and great service. PS- chocolate flan was amazing!
author: Jessica H.

description: Based on reviews in Yelp and Yahoo, I decided to celebrate my birthday at Albona. My friends and I had a wonderful time - great service and the feeling we were in a small town where people cared about their customers. The food was outstanding - I had the special of the day - lamb chops and they were perfectly cooked. The Chocolate Bonet dessert was the perfect ending to dinner. A great time was had by all and we will certainly return
author: Que T.

description:
This became one of our favourite restaurants in SF after the first visit.
We had booked a table on OpenTable, and with the only information being "italian" and "north beach", we expected a typical noisy, uber-italiano style eatery serving a thousand different pastas and gelato.
Instead, we were pleasantly surprised by this quaint restaurant down a dark, quiet street, far away from the gaudyness of North Beach proper.

The service was perfect from the get-go. We had to wait a few minutes in the tiny entry way, as our table was prepared, but Bruno, the owner, graciously took our coats and kept us company.

Bruno's great service continued all night, with excellent menu suggestions, history of the Istrian cuisine, and friendly conversation.

We were all impressed with our food and wine. 

The saffron rissotto is amazing.
I was also lucky enough to have the rabbit... I haven't seen rabbit on a menu since i lived in Paris last year, and Bruno's variation was better than anything i'd had there.

If you're looking for an intimate dinner, with excellent food and service, don't go past Bruno and his team at Albona.
author: David H.

description:
This place is old school European - in decor, food, and of course Bruno included.  We went there for an early Valentine's Day dinner and had a very enjoyable time - the dining room was small but didn't feel overly cramped.  Bruno, of course, was a total hoot - if you're hungry and/or in a rush, don't come here....  Bruno will just talk your ears off and you'll just be hungry and annoyed.  This is the place to come if you want a relaxing and enjoyable dinner.  

Re: food - Ryan had the rabbit, which was excellent.  I have the saffron risotto - I was disappointed, I thought the flavors weren't that interesting but it was still good.  Gnocchi appetizer was quite delicious but tasted really fatty...  yum but after the 3rd one I was done... 

But overall a great experience and a good date spot.  Valet parking was a huge bonus!
author: Hayley L.

description:
Yay! I'm a fan.

This place is good, really good.  In fact it is definitely in my top 3 Italian places in the city (with Tomassos and Ristorante Milano).  I found this place on Yelp and all the times I've walked down Taylor, never knew it was here.  

Intimate, warm, homey feeling as I stepped inside.  Wine was very reasonable.  We ordered a bottle of white for $26.  Not bad at all.  The service was awesome 5 stars for sure.  Everyone was super friendly.  I really felt like I was in my Italian Grandma's house eating homemade Italian food.  Too bad my grandmother wasn't a very good cook, nor are we Italian.

We all ordered something different.  I had the Sausage Rigatoni baked.  This dish was out of this world.  Super hot when it came out.  I could taste the quality and the flavors.  It was just so delicious.  Cheesy, juicy, saucey- Sooooo good.  Others in my group got the halibut (very good), the Risotto (OK but I'm not the biggest Risotto fan), and cheese ravioli (also very good).

We were so stuffed we couldn't bare to order dessert.

This place is great date place or/and a small group birthday dinner place. I will be back!
author: Rachel S.

description:
Yes! I'm definitely a fan!
When I first walked, I wasn't really expecting much.  But the minute we were greeted, I couldn't wait to taste their food. Their dishes are as good as their friendly service!  

The dishes are regional (from what I understand) italian flavors; very very "non-standard american" italian!  I ordered seafood stew as entree, and had calamari, gnochi and scallops as appetizers.  The flavor was light, and not heavy like a lot italian dishes tend to be.   Calamari was sooooo good!

The service was superb as well!  We order a bottle of wine, but when he uncorked the bottle, he thought the fragrance wasn't right, so he immediately opened up a second bottle for us right away.  We were all very pleased with it.

Usually I'm not into italian cuisine; but if I have to pick one, this would be the place!
author: N. C.

description: Best dish EVER....the Strudel con pasta fatta in casa! The wait staff is very accommodating and friendly. My hubby and I have come here every year for our anniversary. Small atmosphere but still awesome.
author: Jessica O.

description:
What a great find!  The food was excellent, the staff was welcoming and helpful and the ambiance was charming.  I couldn't  have asked for a more enjoyable and tasteful evening. I started with the dungenous crab salad which was yummy! They were very accommodating in splitting this salad for my husband and I to share and they did so making each individual serving look beautiful -- not like they had just split one serving in half.  I had the braised veal shank as my entre -- highly recommend it!!  The meat was extremely tender and full of flavor...it just melted in my mouth.  My husband had the home made ravioli and loved it as well.  Even the dinner rolls were delightful...tasted like there was buttermilk in them...light, warm and great flavor.  The risotto side dish was heavenly!
The waiter recommended a delightful italian pinot noir that had wonderful flavor and fit well with both our meals.
Can't wait to go again!!
author: Mary L.

description: This review has been long in coming. We were a party of 15 I think, my husband and I plus several members of his extended family. The staff very nicely accommodated the large party despite the small size of the restaurant (I think we took up 1/3 of the place). Wine, appetizers, and food flowed freely...I can't remember any specifics beyond that the food was super tasty and the service was amazing. I think the owner was serving us. I don't get over to that part of SF too often, but next time I'm there I'll be hitting up Albona again.
author: Sarah S.

description:
What a wonderful place -- the sort of spot that offers solid and interesting food, charming service, and a healthy mix of tourists and locals crammed into a very small dining room. Even given the tight space, the table are not crowded and the pace is as leisurely as you want to make it.

This is not what most people would consider "eye-talian" food. They do a couple standard red sauce dishes, but probably only to meet the expectations of dazed tourists who wander in and assume, given its North Beach-centric location that the food is your stereotypical Italian. Not so. 

Mostly, this menu offers intriguing ingredients like raisins, saffron, and juniper berries. The Istiran region of Italy is more closely related to Vienna than to Palermo, and its ingredients prove this. 

The service was charming - Bruno is not the only employee who really cares about diners. Everyone from our waiter to the valet parking dude were smiling, friendly and genuine. They love working here, and it's a pleasure to eat here.

P.S. Without us even asking, they offered to split our appetizers for us -- and didn't charge us. Plus, if you order wine by the glass, they bring the bottle to your table and pour you a taste before pouring you a full glass. This ensures you'll never have to drink wine from the one bottle that's been open for days. Very cool.
author: Maureen G.

description:
